questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the casualty with complaints of nausea, vomiting and disorientation. On examination, Kernig's sign is positive. A spinal tap is performed and the findings of CSF wet mount microscopy are shown below. In which manner would this patient may have acquired the parasite?

choices.text: Taking bath in a hot spring
Consuming cysts with faecally contaminated water
Ingestion of cysts in non-chlorinated water

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing amoeboid trophozoite form with pseudopodia is suggestive of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. It is caused by Naegleria fowleri and this patient would have acquired this infection following a bath in a hot spring.

Naegleria fowleri is also known as brain-eating amoeba. It occurs in 3 forms: cyst, amoeboid trophozoite and flagellate trophozoite forms.

The infection usually follows swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. The amoebae invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges. The incubation period is 2 days-2 weeks.

Although most cases lead to a poor outcome some sources have reported successful treatment with intravenous amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B: Consumption of cysts in fecally contaminated water can contract infection from parasites such as Entamoeba histolytica, Cyclospora and Cryptosporidium. 

Option C: Consumption of improperly cooked fish can contract infection from parasites such as Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis.

Option D: Ingestion of cysts in non-chlorinated water can contract infection from parasites such as Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: Your friend experiences feeling heavy and bloated with early satiety, and nausea after a fatty meal. You suggested it may be because of delayed gastric emptying. Which of the following factors most likely contribute to delayed gastric emptying?

choices.text: Presence of fat rich contents in the duodenum
Stimulation of the parasympathetic nervous system

questions.solution:
The most likely factor contributing to this delayed gastric emptying is the presence of fat rich contents in the duodenum.

When fat enters the duodenum, it triggers the release of hormones like cholecystokinin (CCK), which slows gastric motility to allow for more time for fat digestion and absorption. This delayed emptying can lead to symptoms such as bloating, early satiety, and discomfort, especially after consuming high-fat meals.

Regulation of gastric emptying is mainly by the inhibitory feedback signals from the duodenum that include enterogastric reflex and hormonal feedback by cholecystokinin.

Enterogastric reflex: When food enters the duodenum, multiple nervous reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall. They strongly inhibit the pyloric pump's propulsive contractions and increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

These reflexes are mediated by three routes:

  • Directly from the duodenum to the stomach through the enteric nervous system in the gut wall (major role)
  • Through inhibitory sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach (minor role)
  • Vagus nerves to the brain stem where they inhibit the normal excitatory signals transmitted to the stomach (minor role)

Hormonal feedback: Cholecystokinin is released from the mucosa of the jejunum in response to fatty substances in the chyme. This hormone acts as an inhibitor to block increased stomach motility caused by gastrin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with severe headache and reduced urine output for the last 2 days. She had a 2-year history of color changes in her fingers in response to cold and a feeling of skin tightening. On examination, her BP is 190/100mm Hg. Which of the following antibodies is strongly associated with an increase in the risk of this complication?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with 2 year history of skin tightening and color changes in fingers on exposure to cold (Raynaud's phenomenon), reduced urine output along with blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg (Hypertensive crisis) is indicative of Systemic sclerosis (SS) complicated by scleroderma renal crisis. Anti RNA Polymerase III is strongly associated with scleroderma renal crisis.

It is characterized by life-threatening accelerated hypertension accompanied by acute kidney injury and progressive failure. Risk factors includes male gender, diffuse SS, <4 yrs of disease onset, steroid usage ( recommended is <10g/day), and anti RNA Polymerase III positivity.

The clinical features include elevated blood pressure, headache, and blurring of vision due to papilledema and hypertensive retinopathy changes, as well as pulmonary edema.

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers are the drugs of choice for managing scleroderma renal crisis. 

Other options:

Option A: Anti centromeric antibodies are protective against renal crisis in SS.

Option C: Anti Scl 70 antibody is associated with progressive Interstitial lung disease in SS

Option D: Anti PM Scl is associated with overlap syndrome with ILD, myositis & malignancy.

questions.text: A nurse who tested positive for hepatitis B after a needlestick injury developed facial puffiness. The histopathological image of the kidney biopsy is shown below. What type of deposits will likely be seen on an electron microscopy image?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and biopsy image showing a uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall indicate membranous nephropathy and it is characterized by subepithelial deposits.

It is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It occurs commonly in men aged between 30-50 years. The majority of cases are idiopathic/primary and occur due to the autoantibodies against the renal antigen phospholipase A2 receptor. These autoantibodies are absent in secondary membranous nephropathy.

The various conditions leading to secondary membranous nephropathy are:

  • Drugs: captopril, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs NSAIDs, penicillamine, etc.
  • Infections: hepatitis B and C, syphilis, malaria
  • Malignancy of lung, colon, and melanoma
  • Autoimmune diseases like SLE, Sjorgen syndrome, sarcoidosis, primary biliary cirrhosis, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes and dome pattern on silver staining as shown below.

Immunofluorescence microscopy: Granular deposits containing IgG and complement proteins along the glomerular basement membrane. IgG4 is the principal immunoglobulin deposited in most cases of primary membranous nephropathy.

Electron microscopy: Electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epi membranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes as shown below.

Management is primarily by the administration of immunosuppressive drugs such as Steroids, Cyclophosphamide, Chlorambucil, and Mycophenolate mofetil.

questions.text: A patient who presents with difficulty hearing and vertigo only with loud sounds. He was subjected to a vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) test which shows reduced threshold. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with hearing loss and vertigo only with loud sounds along with reduced threshold in eliciting a vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) is suggestive of third window trauma also known as superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD).

SSCD is defined as a gap in the bone overlying the superior semicircular canal, thus creating a third window either congenitally or due to any trauma. It causes conductive hearing loss because some sound waves will be lost via the gap, leaving less sound waves to reach the organ of Corti. Patients often have positive tullio phenomenon(vertigo due to loud sound) and hennebert sign(vertigo due to pressure changes). Diagnosis is made by HRCT.

questions.text: A 35-year-old father develops itchy, eczematous, exudative, papulopustular lesions along with excoriations for 2 weeks. His 9-month-old child also develops similar lesions. However, superficial burrows are seen in the father but not in his child. Which of the following sites will be spared for the father but involved in the child?
questions.solution:
The lesions described and the findings of superficial burrows indicate scabies in the father. Scabies in adults differ from that of infants in that it spares the face, scalp, palm and soles.

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infection caused in humans by the Sarcoptes scabiei. Allergic sensitivity to the mite or its products appears to play an important role in determining the development of lesions other than burrows, and in producing pruritus. The pruritis typically shows nocturnal exacerbations. Scabies are transmitted by close contact from human to human or from pet animals to humans. Thus, there are usually several cases in the same household.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension for a year is being evaluated for loin pain. On examination, there is an abdominal mass felt on palpation. A  CT scan was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a CT image showing multiple cysts in both the kidneys points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) and hepatic cysts are the most common extrarenal manifestation of this condition. 

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of renal failure in this disease is faster in males.

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Hematuria
  • Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

It is associated with a number of extrarenal manifestations like polycystic liver disease, where cysts are usually asymptomatic but symptoms may occur due to the mass effect of cysts, intracranial berry aneurysms are seen in approximately 10% of patients with ADPKD and mitral valve prolapse, the most common valvular abnormality observed in patients with ADPKD can be diagnosed by echocardiography.

Intravenous pyelography shows a characteristic spider leg pattern, as a result of narrowed and stretched calyces and elongated, compressed renal pelvis. Ultrasonographic diagnostic criteria for individuals at 50% risk for the disease include two unilateral or bilateral cysts in those younger than 30 years of age or two cysts in each kidney for those between 30 and 59 years of age or four cysts in each kidney at ages 60 and over.

Treatment includes management of hypertension using ACE inhibitors like lisinopril or angiotensin receptor blockers like telmisartan. Narcotic analgesics should be limited to episodes of acute pain. V2 receptor antagonists like Tolvaptan have been observed to slow the decline in renal function over a 3 year period.

USG-guided CT aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic; surgical unroofing of multiple or large cysts may alleviate symptoms of pain. Nephrectomy is indicated for symptomatic patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urinary pregnancy test presented with mild pain abdomen and slight bleeding per vaginum for 5 days. She was diagnosed with cervical pregnancy. Which of the following criteria is used for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cervical pregnancy can be diagnosed using Rubin's criteria.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where the implantation occurs in the cervical canal at the level of or below the internal os.

Rubin's criteria for pathological diagnosis of cervical pregnancies:

  • Soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus.
  • Uterine bleeding following amenorrhea, without cramping pain.
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix.
  • A closed internal cervical os and a partially opened external os.

Transvaginal sonographic findings of cervical pregnancy include:

  • An hourglass uterine shape and ballooned cervical canal
  • Gestational tissue at the level of the cervix 
  • Absent intrauterine gestational tissue
  • A portion of the endocervical canal is interposed between the gestation and the endometrial canal.

Treatment: Medical management with methotrexate if vitals are stable and it is diagnosed in the first trimester. Surgical management with suction curettage or hysterectomy is done if vitals are unstable, bleeding uncontrolled, or if the gestation is advanced.

Prior to any procedure, uterine artery embolization, local methotrexate injection into the amnionic sac, ligation of the uterine arteries, or cerclage at the internal os to compress feeding vessels may be done to control bleeding.

The image below shows an ultrasonogram of cervical pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Spiegelberg’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of ovarian pregnancy.

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • The gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall

Option B: Godin's sonographic criteria is for the diagnosis of a cesarean scar pregnancy

  • Empty uterine cavity
  • Empty cervical canal
  • A gestational sac in the anterior part of the uterine isthmus
  • Absence of healthy myometrium between the bladder and gestational sac

Option D: Studdiford criteria is used in the diagnosis of primary abdominal pregnancy. It includes:

  • Presence of normal tubes and ovaries with no evidence of recent or past injury/pregnancy.
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula.
  • Presence of a pregnancy-related exclusively to the peritoneal surface and early enough to eliminate the possibility of secondary implantation after primary tubal nidation.

questions.text: A female with prosthetic heart valves is on long-term warfarin therapy. The action of which of the following factors will remain unaffected by Warfarin?
questions.solution:
The action of Factor V will remain unaffected by Warfarin. (option D)

In the given image, the correctly labeled parts are as follows:

1: Factor II 

2: Factor V

3: Factor VII

4: Factor IX

Activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and proteins C, S, and Z is done by carboxylation of their glutamate residues, with the help of the reduced form of vitamin K as a co-factor. The enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase helps keep vitamin K in reduced form and this enzyme is competitively inhibited by warfarin. 

The indications of warfarin include prosthetic heart valves, APLA syndrome, etc.

The image below shows warfarin's mechanism of action.

questions.text: All of the following variables of Well’s score for clinical prediction of Pulmonary Embolism carry a score of 1.5 points except
questions.solution:
Among the given options, hemoptysis carries a score of 1 point. 

Pulmonary Embolism is a potentially fatal condition resulting from thrombus formation within the deep venous circulation of the pulmonary vasculature. Approximately 50–70% of patients who have symptomatic pulmonary emboli will have lower extremity Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT) when evaluated.

Well’s score is a clinical predictive tool used to stratify the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in individuals,

The risk factors contributing to PE are the variables taken into account are:

Variable Points
 Clinical symptoms and signs of DVT (leg swelling and pain with palpation of deep veins) 3
 Alternative diagnosis less likely than PE 3
 Heart rate > 100 beats/minute 1.5
Immobilization for > 3 days or surgery in the previous 4 weeks 1.5
Previous PE or DVT 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Cancer (with treatment within the past 6 months or palliative care) 1

Based on this, the risk of developing PE is classified as :

  • High > 6.0
  • Moderate 2.0 to 6.0
  • Low < 2.0

Or a two-tier probability scoring :

  • PE likely > 4.0
  • PE unlikely < or = 4.0

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male is brought into the emergency department following trauma to his head. His GCS is E1V2M3. Neurologic examination reveals a dilated left pupil and left-sided hemiparesis with a Babinski sign on the left side. What is the most likely pathophysiological explanation for the patient’s neurologic findings?

GCS - Glasgow Coma Scale

choices.text: Left gangliothalamic hemorrhage causing mass effect on the brainstem
Left-sided uncal herniation compressing the contralateral cerebral peduncle
Transtentorial herniation leading to compression of the upper brainstem
Cerebellar tonsillar herniation impacting the medulla

questions.solution:
The most likely pathophysiological explanation for the patient’s neurologic findings is left-sided uncal herniation compressing the contralateral cerebral peduncle.

The patient's presentation of left-sided third nerve involvement and ipsilateral hemiparesis aligns with Kernohan’s notch phenomenon. Uncal herniation causes ipsilateral third nerve involvement and compression of the contralateral cerebral peduncle resulting in ipsilateral hemiparesis.

Uncal herniation involves the impaction of the anterior medial temporal gyrus (uncus) into the tentorial opening adjacent to the midbrain. This herniation can compress the oculomotor nerve, causing ipsilateral pupil dilation as the first sign due to disruption of the parasympathetic fibres on the nerve’s outer edge. 

The displaced midbrain and parahippocampal gyrus shift laterally, compressing the contralateral cerebral peduncle and resulting in coma, a Babinski sign, and ipsilateral hemiparesis. This paradoxical compression effect causing hemiparesis on the same side as the herniation is known as the Kernohan-Woltman sign. Additional complications can include infarction from compression of the anterior and posterior cerebral arteries, as well as obstructive hydrocephalus.

Other options:

Option A: Gangliothalamic bleeds are typically seen in hypertensives and present with contralateral symptoms.

Option C: In central transtentorial herniation, there is symmetric downward movement of the thalamic structures through the tentorial opening, initially compressing the upper midbrain. This condition typically begins with miotic pupils and drowsiness, differentiating it from unilateral pupil dilation in uncal herniation.

Option D: Tonsillar herniation primarily impacts the medulla, often leading to respiratory arrest and is typically rapidly fatal without immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. The size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. On examination, the external os is closed. USG shows a well-formed gestational sac with fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows a well-formed gestation ring indicating a healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Treatment involves bed rest, analgesics to relieve pain, and progesterone.

questions.text: An immunologist has arranged a series of tubes for an experiment on precipitation reaction. The tubes contain equal amounts of antiserum, while increasing quantities of antigen are added from left to right. One of the middle tubes shows maximum precipitation. What is the phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon observed in the tubes to the left of the middle tube is called the prozone phenomenon. Here, antibodies are in excess compared to antigens leading to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

  • The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test (tubes on the left side in the question stem).
  • In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced. (tube in the middle in question stem)
  • Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation (tubes on the right side in the question stem).


Prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Flocculation: It is a type of precipitation reaction in which the precipitate remains suspended as flocculus, instead of sedimenting.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man on your ward underwent a bowel resection for colonic carcinoma 8 days ago and has been unable to establish on oral feeds. Your consultant has asked you to arrange for parenteral nutrition to be started today, and you spoke to the dieticians about it. They agreed and asked to arrange for regular blood tests. The nurse cannot remember which blood tests had to be done weekly. Can you remind her which one that could be?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, the blood tests that had to be done weekly while receiving parenteral nutrition (PN) were liver enzymes.

When a patient receives PN, they should have a daily set of electrolytes and serum glucose, a triglyceride level before initiation of lipid emulsion, and a weekly set of blood tests as listed below. 

Weekly blood tests while on PN:

  • Blood counts
  • Blood urea nitrogen level
  • Liver enzymes
  • Phosphate and magnesium levels

The urine or capillary blood glucose level is checked every 6 hours during the first few days of the infusion before changing it to daily tests. This is to monitor for metabolic complications of administering PN. Pancreatic enzymes are not routinely tested. 

Metabolic complications of PN:

  • Refeeding syndrome - hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia
  • Overfeeding - electrolyte imbalances, hyperglycemia, and hypertriglyceridemia

Refeeding syndrome occurs secondary to full caloric administration after a period of starvation and can be avoided by slowly introducing calories and increasing to full caloric requirements over time.

questions.text: A 44-year-old HIV patient presents with a non-productive cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates along with a pneumatocele. Microscopic examination of the bronchoalveolar lavage shows the following. What is the special stain used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the staining showing the black-colored stained cysts, resembling the crushed ping pong balls, are suggestive of Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. The stain used for staining the causative organism is Gomori’s methenamine silver stain.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and cough that is usually non-productive. Finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

Treatment: Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient is diagnosed with Stage 1 breast cancer with a high recurrence score. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. What is the preferred medical management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given immunohistochemistry is positive for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors and suggests triple positive or luminal type B breast cancer.  Medical therapy for triple-positive breast cancer includes hormonal therapy, Trastuzumab along Chemotherapy as indicated by the high recurrence score.

The Luminal B subtype of breast cancer is more aggressive and expresses relatively higher levels of the proliferative Ki-67 protein. Hormone therapy is used for ER/PR-positive breast cancer, while Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody developed to target the extracellular domain of the HER-2 receptor. Chemotherapy is added to increase the efficacy of the treatment. Trastuzumab combined with chemotherapy is more effective than single-agent therapy for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

When positive, the estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors; hence, the nucleus is stained brown and the human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor; hence the cell membrane is stained brown.

Newer molecular tests for breast cancer have been developed, which help in predicting the advantage of adding chemotherapy. These are:

  • Oncotype Dx (21-geneassay)

Oncotype Dx can only be used in hormone (ER, PR) receptor-positive cancers, while mammaprint can be used in both hormone receptor (ER, PR) positive and hormone receptor-negative cancers. 

These tests are used for T1,2 N0 M0 breast cancers – (node-negative, metastasis-negative). Using these molecular tests, a recurrence score (0 – 100) is calculated.

  • If the score is low, then there is no advantage of adding chemotherapy
  • If the score is high, then chemotherapy should be added

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and chest pain. He also has a cough and shortness of breath. CSF analysis reveals encapsulated budding yeast cells. The organism is identified as Cryptococcus gattii. What is the primary environmental reservoir for this pathogen?

CSF- Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
In this patient with fever, headache, neck stiffness, chest pain, cough, and shortness of breath, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals encapsulated budding yeast cells, identified as Cryptococcus gattii. This basidiomycetous yeast is primarily found in tropical and subtropical regions, with its environmental reservoir linked to eucalyptus trees and decaying wood.

Both Cryptococcus gattii and Cryptococcus neoformans are environmental yeasts that produce large polysaccharide capsules, which serve as a key virulence factor. While C. neoformans is more widespread globally and commonly found in dry pigeon feces, C. gattii is less common but has been increasingly recognized in areas like the Pacific Northwest, particularly associated with eucalyptus trees. Once inhaled as desiccated cells or smaller basidiospores, these yeasts can cause infections, particularly affecting the central nervous system (CNS), where they often result in meningoencephalitis.

The pathogenesis of cryptococcosis begins when the yeast cells are inhaled into the lungs, where they may cause an initial, often asymptomatic infection or a mild flu-like illness. In immunocompromised individuals or those with no apparent immune deficiencies, the yeasts can disseminate to other organs, including the CNS, skin, eyes, prostate, and bones. The most significant clinical manifestation of Cryptococcus infection is chronic meningitis, which may resemble other CNS disorders and can lead to severe complications if untreated. Cryptococcosis is primarily diagnosed through the detection of fungal antigens or the characteristic encapsulated yeast cells in CSF and other specimens.

Cryptococcus gattii is distinguished from other species by its ecological niche and clinical behaviour. Although infections with C. gattii are rare compared to C. neoformans, it has been associated with seemingly healthy hosts, unlike C. neoformans, which typically affects immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with complaints of pain in the scrotum for the past one day. He gives a history of relief of pain when he supported his scrotum with a pad. What is the name of this clinical sign experienced by the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical sign described in the given case where the patient has relief in pain when the scrotum is supported by a pad is suggestive of Prehn's sign.

Prehn's sign is a clinical indicator used to differentiate between testicular torsion and epididymoorchitis. In epididymoorchitis, supporting and elevating the scrotum relieves pain, indicating a positive Prehn's sign. Conversely, in testicular torsion, pain worsens with elevation, making the sign negative.

Other options:

Option A. Aaron's sign is associated with acute appendicitis, where applying pressure to McBurney’s point elicits referred pain in the epigastrium.

Option C. Angell’s sign is observed in testicular torsion where the testis on the opposite side lies horizontally because of the bilaterality of the mesorchium between the testis and epididymis.

Option D. Deming’s sign is seen in testicular torsion, where the spasm of the cremaster muscle and the twisting of the cord cause the affected testis to be positioned higher.

questions.text: The images below display the gross and microscopic features of a brain tumour in a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross features (cystic tumor) and microscopy (microcystic and fibrillary areas) suggest pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytomas typically occur in children and young adults. It is located in the cerebellum, floor, and walls of the third ventricle, the optic nerves, and cerebral hemispheres. It is often cystic. Tumors are often biphasic, with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. Bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork are seen.

Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings. Necrosis and brisk mitotic activity are uncommon.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient came with complaints of neck and upper limb pain. She also gives a history of weakness, incoordination, and clumsiness of upper limbs. Her CT scan is as given below. The diagnosis is

choices.text: Ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament
Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament

questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an ossified posterior longitudinal ligament. 

Patients typically present with symptoms of neck and upper-limb pain, weakness, incoordination, clumsiness, muscle wasting, and bladder-bowel dysfunction, etc and are typically older than 50 years of age

It occurs mainly in the cervical spine, most commonly at the level of C5. It can result in spinal stenosis and cervical myelopathy causing pain and weakness in the limbs. X-ray shows dense ossification along the back of the vertebral bodies in the mid-cervical spine. Cervical spinal cord injury can be induced by minor cervical trauma in these patients.

Treatment is needed if the symptoms are progressive. Posterior decompression is the operation of choice.

questions.text:
Which of the following glucose transporters are primarily responsible for the facilitated diffusion of glucose across the placenta?

  1. GLUT- 1
  2. GLUT- 2
  3. GLUT- 3
  4. SGLT- 1
  5. SGLT-2
questions.solution:
The glucose transporters primarily responsible for the facilitated diffusion of glucose across the placenta are GLUT- 1 and GLUT- 3.

Glucose transport may be active or passive.

Passive absorption of glucose occurs through facilitated diffusion. This is carried out by Glucose transporters (GLUT) 1 -7. 

Active transport of glucose takes place through Sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT 1 and 2). SGLT 1 helps in glucose absorption in the small intestine and renal tubules. SGLT 2 primarily facilitates glucose absorption in the renal tubules.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient underwent hysterectomy a week ago. Postoperatively she complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On examination, a vesicovaginal fistula is observed. Which technique of fistula repair is suitable in this case?
questions.solution:
The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by a cancer cervix. It can lead to the narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

Other options:

Option A: Chassar Moir technique widely separated the vagina and bladder all around by the flap-splitting method and suturing the bladder and vagina separately into two. It has the advantage of tension-free sutures and avoidance of the superior position of the bladder over the vaginal suture. 

Option C: Ureteric implantation is considered in cases with extensive loss of bladder tissue, or repetitive failures to close the fistula. Here ureters are implanted into the sigmoid colon creating an ileal loop bladder, or rectal bladder. The disadvantage of this procedure is the high incidence of ascending infection to the kidneys and the risk of electrolyte imbalance.

Option D: Kelly's repair is the anterior colporrhaphy with bladder neck plication done for stress urinary incontinence.

  • Laparoscopic surgeries

Related Pearl: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: A 39-week pregnant young woman with a history of one previous cesarean section presents with sudden abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, an abnormal fetal heart rate is seen with loss of uterine tone. USG shows an irregular uterine contour and a defect at the previous cesarean scar site. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Uterine Scar Rupture: Partial separation of the uterine wall
Scar Dehiscence: Partial separation of the uterine wall
Uterine Scar Rupture: Complete separation of the uterine wall
Scar Dehiscence: Complete separation of the uterine scar

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman at 39 weeks of gestation with a history of previous cesarean section presenting with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, abnormal fetal heart rate, and loss of uterine tone is suggestive of uterine scar rupture.

Uterine Scar Rupture refers to a complete rupture of the uterine wall, which may lead to fetal demise, maternal hemorrhage, and severe abdominal pain. It typically occurs during labor or after any traumatic event. and can be a life-threatening condition.

Risk factors include:

  • Previous history of classical cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor
  • Manual removal of placenta
  • Dilatation and curettage 

Clinical features are:

  • Maternal tachycardia
  • Fetal bradycardia
  • Maternal hypotension
  • Uterine scar tenderness
  • Bleeding per vagina
  • Hematuria
  • Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following this, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus. Early recognition of uterine scar rupture is important for preventing maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality.

Uterine scar dehiscence refers to a partial separation of the uterine scar without complete rupture. It is usually asymptomatic, often discovered incidentally during a cesarean delivery or routine examination. There is no fetal compromise, and it may not involve significant hemorrhage. Scar dehiscence can be managed conservatively if discovered early but still requires careful monitoring for signs of progression to rupture.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. You notice that the senior resident uses the trauma scoring system which involves the energy of the injury as one of the components. Which of the following trauma scoring systems is being used here?

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a thyroid swelling underwent thyroidectomy and the histopathological examination of the specimen shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen on histopathological examination of a neck swelling in a middle-aged female suggests a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy with a female preponderance and peaking in the 3rd-5th decade.

Risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Mostly, patients are asymptomatic or they might present with a palpable thyroid nodule. It mainly metastasizes through the lymphatic route.

Comprehensive thyroid ultrasound with bilateral central and lateral neck lymph nodes mapping should be done as part of the imaging workup. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI of the neck and chest and intraluminal imaging (laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, or esophagoscopy) may be required in patients with potentially more advanced local and regional disease.

Management includes

  • ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy for a low-risk, unilateral, 1-4 cm tumor without extrathyroidal extension/ evidence of metastatic disease as well as for a tumor that is < 1 cm in size. 
  • total thyroidectomy if high risk of recurrence.

The below image shows orphan Annie eye nuclei-

Histopathological features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin  
  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcified structures within the papillae

 

Other options-

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

 

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma shows large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and, mixed cells. The below image shows anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came to the ophthalmologist with complaints of limited eye movements and decreased vision in the night for the past few weeks. On examination, you notice bilateral ptosis. He gives a history of frequent syncopal attacks. Given below is his fundus picture. What is the likely diagnosis?

The fundus picture has the bony spicule pattern of pigmentation of the retinal periphery, as seen in retinitis pigmentosa. This when combined with chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia with ptosis and cardiac conduction defects causing syncopal attacks as given in the clinical scenario is suggestive of Kearn–Sayre syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is posted for surgery under general anesthesia. Which of the following inhalational agent cannot be used for induction of anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane cannot be used for the induction of anesthesia in this patient since it produces laryngospasm when used for inhalational anesthesia. Laryngospasm is because of the pungent nature of the gas. The incidence of laryngospasm following desflurane induction is almost 50%.

Desflurane has a rapid onset of action and also rapid emergence from anesthesia. Therefore, it is of particular value in neurosurgical and spinal fusion procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment. It is also used for the maintenance of anesthesia.  Desflurane has no hepatic metabolism.

Other options:

Option A: Halothane is the preferred drug for gaseous induction of anesthesia in children. However, the incidence of halothane hepatitis and myocardial depression has reduced its use in children.

Option B: Sevoflurane is the preferred inhalational agent for induction in the pediatric age group. Cardiovascular depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias are less frequent with sevoflurane than with halothane and hence the former is preferred.

Option D: Nitrous oxide is the least potent as it has the highest minimum alveolar concentration. It is combined with other potent inhaled anesthetics to reduce their dose. It can be used to hasten the induction of anesthesia along with other induction agents.

  • Neonatal circumcision is done under General anesthesia.

    • Manifestation-bradycardia (most common)
    • Treatment-temporary cessation surgery until heart rate increases, IV Atropine.
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy :
    • High risk for malignant hyperthermia so succinyl choline and halothane should be avoided
    • Choice of anesthesia is propofol, nitrous oxide for maintenance.

questions.text: A patient presents 4 months post-bariatric surgery with complaints of dizziness, sweating, and weakness that develops a few hours after meals. She is diagnosed with late dumping syndrome and subcutaneous octreotide is started. All of the following are adverse effects of the drug, except:
questions.solution:
All of the following are adverse effects of octreotide, except hyperthyroidism, as it inhibits the release of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), potentially leading to hypothyroidism, especially with long-term use.

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analogue, given via a subcutaneous route (50-200mcg every 8 hours). It can be used in the following conditions:

  • Acromegaly
  • Secretory diarrhoeas associated with carcinoid, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, or diabetes - by the suppression of hormones that enhance intestinal mucosal secretion.
  • Bleeding oesophagal varices- reduces hepatic blood flow and helps stop bleeding.
  • Dumping syndrome in post-gastric surgery patients
  • Gastrinoma, Glucoganoma, Insulinoma, VIPoma and ACTH-secreting tumor. 

Adverse effects of octreotide include:

  • Hypothyroidism 
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea
  • Steatorrhea (option B)
  • Gallstones (due to biliary stasis) (Option D)

When given in patients with underlying heart disease, it may lead to bradycardia(option A) and QT prolongation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the following laparoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
The findings seen in the given laparoscopic image are powder burn spots over the peritoneum. This is seen in endometriosis.

  • Typically, there are small black dots, the so called "powder burns"/"gunshot appearance" seen on the uterosacral ligaments and pouch of Douglas.
  • Fibrosis and scarring in the peritoneum surrounding the implants is also a typical finding which is known as "Allen Masters syndrome".
  • Other subtle appearances are: red flame shaped areas, red polypoid areas, yellow brown patches, white peritoneal areas, circular peritoneal defects or subovarian adhesions.
  • These lesions are thought to be more active than the “powder burn” areas.

Other pathology in Endometriosis:

  • Peritoneal cavity: contains yellowish brown fluid which has prostaglandin repsonsible for the pain of endometriosis.
  • Ovary: "Chocolate cyst" (True cyst with columnar epithelium lining)

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD  with complaints of lower limb weakness. He was diagnosed with neurolathyrism. Which of the following vitamin supplementation may prove useful in reversing this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with lower limb weakness and diagnosed with neurolathyrism may benefit from vitamin C supplementation to help reverse the condition.

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to a red gram or Bengal gram. It is mostly consumed by poor agricultural laborers because it is relatively cheap. Lathyrism is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour). 

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

In the case of neurolathyrism, administration of vitamin C at doses of 500-1000 mg may help reverse the damage.

questions.text: A barium meal study of a patient showed the following. What is the most common carcinoma to develop in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this case, the barium meal study shows the bird-beak appearance and the likely diagnosis is achalasia. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common carcinoma to develop in achalasia due to long-standing, retained, undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation.

 Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction. 

Esophageal manometry shows:

  • Incomplete LES relaxation in response to swallowing
  • High resting LES pressure
  • Absent esophageal peristalsis

On performing a timed barium study, barium will be retained for more than five minutes. The fluoroscopic examination will reveal a dilated esophagus that tapers to form a 'bird's beak' at the gastroesophageal junction as seen in the image above. 

Endoscopy and biopsy are usually carried out to rule out cancer. 

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in the radiology department. The resident asks you about the diagnosis based on the chest X-ray film shown below. The patient is a known case of Marfan syndrome and complains of shortness of breath and cough. What is the preferred management?
questions.solution:
The given chest x-ray shows a widening of the mediastinal shadow and compression of the trachea with complaints of shortness of breath in a known case of Marfan syndrome suggests the diagnosis of the thoracic aortic aneurysm and the preferred management would be endovascular stent grafting.

Management of thoracic aortic aneurysm:

Beta-blockers and angiotensin receptor antagonists are helpful in reducing the rate of aneurysmal expansion.
Surgical management is required in

  • All symptomatic cases
  • Ascending aortic aneurysm - ≥ 5.5 cm in diameter or growth rate of >0.5 cm/year
  • Descending aortic aneurysm - > 6 cm in diameter or growth rate of >1 cm/year
  • Marfan's syndrome - 4-5 cm in diameter

Thoracic aneurysms at the arch or distal to the arch are preferably managed using a percutaneous approach via the femoral artery, with the insertion of an endovascular stent graft. The given image below shows the technique of EVAR: 

Marfan syndrome is associated with thoracic aneurysm due to cystic medial degeneration. It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by fibrillin gene mutation on chromosome 15. Patients are tall and thin, with notably long limbs and digits. An anterior chest deformity known as pectus excavatum is sometimes seen, and vertebral abnormalities include scoliosis and lordosis. In addition, a high-arched palate and crowding of the teeth may seen. Cardiovascular complications include mitral valve prolapse and mitral regurgitation. Cystic medial necrosis can lead to the dilation of the aortic root and aortic regurgitation. Life-threatening complications are aortic aneurysm and aortic dissection.

Other options:

Option B: Endovascular coiling is used in the management of cerebral aneurysms. 

Option C: Symptomatic patients of aortic aneurysm are never managed conservatively.

Option D: Sclerotherapy is used in the management of venous insufficiency.

questions.text: Two patients have been posted for a tracheostomy procedure. The operating surgeon performs tracheostomy through the level of 2nd - 3rd tracheal rings in the first patient and  4th - 5th tracheal ring in the second patient. What is the type of tracheostomy procedure conducted in these patients respectively?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy is done in both patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests that Mid tracheostomy and Low tracheostomy is performed by the surgeon in first and second patient respectively.

Mid tracheostomy is done through the 2nd and 3rd ring and Low tracheostomy is done below the level of isthmus i.e through the 4th and 5th tracheal ring.

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text:
A pregnant woman is scheduled for a nuchal translucency scan. Which of the following serum biomarkers will be useful as a screening tool for aneuploidy at this period of gestation?
  1. Beta HCG
  2. PAPPA
  3. MSAFP
  4. Inhibin A
  5. Inhibin B

HCG: Human chorionic gonadotropin

PAPPA: Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A

MSAFP: Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
questions.solution:
The serum biomarkers that are useful as a screening tool for aneuploidy during the time of the nuchal translucency scan, that is the first trimester, are Beta HCG and PAPPA.

A nuchal translucency scan is ideally scheduled as part of a routine anomaly scan at 11-13 weeks of gestation. At this period of gestation (i.e., first trimester), only Beta HCG and PAPPA are found to be useful in screening for aneuploidy in the fetus. These two serum biomarkers done together in the first trimester are also termed the Dual test.

The various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

  1. Dual test (1st trimester)
    1. Beta HCG 
    2. PAPPA

This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG.

      2. Triple test (2nd trimester)

    1. Beta HCG
    2. Unconjugated estriol
    3. MSAFP

      3. Quadruple test (2nd trimester)

    1. Beta HCG
    2. Unconjugated estriol
    3. MSAFP
    4. Serum inhibin

Note: Inhibin B  is produced by granulosa cells of the ovary and inhibits FSH secretion from the anterior pituitary. It is also used as a marker for granulosa cell tumours.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a child's developmental milestones. She is able to stand with support and says words like mama and dada. The doctor hands an object to her and lets her play with it. When she takes the object and hides it under the towel, the child searches for it. What other milestone is attained by the child at this age?
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the age of the child is 9 months and at this age, the child waves bye-bye.

At 9 months of age, a child is able to stand with support (motor milestone), can say bisyllables like ma-ma, da-da (language milestone), and the child would have attained object permanence. 

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when not seen. When the pediatrician hides the object, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age would not search for it and quickly gives up, while a baby of 9 months of age understands that the object is hidden and continues to exist, and therefore searches for it.

The other milestones attained at this age are waving bye-bye (social and adaptive milestone) and immature pincer grasp and probes with forefinger (fine motor milestone). An immature pincer grasp is grasping the object from the radial side of the hand. A mature pincer grasp is using the index finger and thumb to approach any object and it develops at the age of 12 months.

Other options:

Option A- A child points to objects of interest by the age of 15 months.

Option B- A child copies or mimics parents in tasks by age of 18 months.

Option D- A child understands simple questions by age of 12 months.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally invasive gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic ultrasound is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally advanced gastric cancer.

Endoscopic ultrasound is the most sensitive investigation used to assess the preoperative local staging of gastric carcinoma. Five layers of the gastric wall can be visualized and the depth of invasion (T component of the staging) of cancer can be assessed with more than 90% accuracy. It can also show enlarged perigastric and celiac lymph nodes. In addition, it can identify liver metastases and assess gastric emptying. 

The limitation of this investigation is operator dependency and it may underestimate the lymph node involvement as normal-sized nodes (<5 mm) may harbor metastasis.

Other options:

Option A- MRI has a higher sensitivity in detecting liver metastasis of gastric carcinoma than conventional CT imaging.

Option B- CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast is the best in preoperative staging of gastric cancer. However, it lacks sensitivity in detecting smaller lesions and is less accurate in T staging than endoscopic ultrasound.

Option C- Barium swallow is up to 75% sensitive in gastric tumors but has been replaced with endoscopic ultrasound in most centers as it is the gold standard for the diagnosis of gastric carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

questions.text: A child is brought with symptoms of fever and sore throat. On examination, he was found to have blisters in the mouth and greyish oval vesicles on the palms and soles. Infection by which of the following organisms is typically associated with the above presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a child presenting with symptoms of fever, sore throat, blisters in the mouth, and greyish oval vesicles on the palms and soles is consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease and the associated organism is the Coxsackie virus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is an exanthematous fever that commonly affects children below 10 years of age and is caused due to infection by the coxsackieviruses, with the A16, A9, and B 1-3 serotypes most commonly implicated.

The incubation period is around 5-7 days and children usually present with symptoms of low-grade fever, sore throat, and malaise. An early feature of the illness in adults is stomatitis, characterized by painful blisters in the mouth.

These blisters may break down to form ulcers. Greyish oval vesicles may be observed on the palms and soles and these are more likely to be seen in children. They fade after 2–3 days.

Laboratory diagnosis involves the isolation of the virus from the lesions or feces and inoculation into suckling mice. serodiagnosis is not useful, as is tissue culture. Management is supportive with intravenous immunoglobulin reserved only for severe cases.

Below is an image of a child with hand-foot-and-mouth disease.

Other options:
Option B: Epstein-Barr virus causes infectious mononucleosis. It commonly affects young adults and manifests as fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and mild, transient rash.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus type 2 is responsible for the majority of genital herpes infections. It is a venereal disease that can give rise to vesicular-ulcerative lesions affecting the genitalia.

Option D: Varicella-zoster virus can cause chickenpox and herpes zoster. The former usually affects children and presents as a rash that is centripetal in distribution, mainly involving the trunk and sparing the distal parts of the limbs. Herpes zoster is usually observed in adults after the fifth decade of life and the rash is unilateral and confined to the area supplied by a single sensory ganglion.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY) is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state of less than full health

questions.text: An anxious mother brought her son to the doctor. She says that her son complains that he does not like the school environment and scores poor grades. On further history taking, it was found that the boy attends a sports club after school and excels in sports. What is the defense mechanism seen in this boy?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the boy compensates for the dislike and poor performance in school by excelling in sports, the defense mechanism involved here is compensation. In this type, the person unconsciously deals with fear or conflict by putting extreme effort into some other area of his life.

Other examples of compensation defense mechanism include excessive bodybuilding to prevent the feeling of inferiority, a patient with dementia noting down excessive details in his diary, etc.

Other options:

Option B- In splitting, the person unconsciously categorizes self or others as either good or bad, without actually considering the whole range of qualities. 

Option C- In suppression, the person voluntarily stops focussing on the thought, conflict. Eg. A person stops focussing on the quarrel in-home while he is working in the office.

Option D- In rationalization, the person provides a logical explanation for irrational behavior. It is motivated by unacceptable, unconscious wishes. Eg. A student blames his teacher for getting low marks in the exam.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms that operate in various diseases

  • OCD - reaction formation, undoing
  • Phobia - displacement
  • Neurosis - repression
  • Grief - denial
  • Borderline personality - Splitting
  • Schizophrenia - projection
  • Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman with Alzheimer’s disease presents with worsening memory and cognitive abilities despite being treated with cholinesterase inhibitors. Her medical history includes hypertension and diabetes, both controlled by medications. Her neurologist suggests a newer drug that reduces amyloid beta plaques. Which medication is he referring to?
questions.solution:
The newer drug for treating Alzheimer’s disease that reduces amyloid beta plaques is Donanemab. 

Donanemab is a humanized monoclonal antibody developed from mouse mE8-IgG2a.  The FDA has approved Donanemab (Kisunla) for treating Alzheimer’s disease in patients with mild cognitive impairment or early-stage dementia. It is administered through an intravenous infusion every four weeks.

Clinical trials showed that Kisunla significantly slowed cognitive decline by targeting amyloid beta plaques in the brain, a hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease. However, the treatment carries a risk of amyloid-related imaging abnormalities (ARIA), particularly in patients with certain genetic factors (ApoE ε4 homozygotes), as well as infusion-related side effects such as headaches and flu-like symptoms. Regular MRI scans and monitoring are advised to manage these risks.

Other options:

Option A: Memantine is an uncompetitive NMDA receptor antagonist used to reduce neurotoxicity in Alzheimer’s disease by preventing the overstimulation of glutamate receptors, which leads to neuronal damage. It helps maintain normal synaptic transmission and is commonly combined with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors for a synergistic effect. While generally well-tolerated, side effects like dizziness and confusion are common. Special caution is needed for patients with renal or hepatic issues due to potential drug interactions affecting clearance. 

Option B: Blarcamesine is in trials for Alzheimer’s disease, showing promising outcomes with a 38.5% reduction in cognitive decline in early-stage patients taking a 50 mg dose. It is not yet FDA-approved. The drug works by activating the sigma-1 receptor, which is thought to promote neuroprotection and help clear misfolded proteins, potentially offering a novel approach to Alzheimer's treatment.

Option D: Brexpiprazole, an atypical antipsychotic used for schizophrenia and major depressive disorders, acts as a partial antagonist of dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors. It is metabolized by CYP3A4 and CYP2D6, with minimal risk of liver toxicity and rare cases of elevated liver enzymes. Common side effects include restlessness, sedation, and weight gain, while severe risks include tardive dyskinesia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

questions.text: A child, previously diagnosed with an endocrine tumor, presented with conjugate eye movements and myoclonus. Which of the following tumors must have led to this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of conjugate eye movements and myoclonus indicates opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (OMS). It is associated with neuroblastoma.

Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome is rapid, conjugate eye nystagmus with involuntary spasms of the limbs, and is also called dancing eyes-dancing feet syndrome.

Causes:
  • When opsoclonus and myoclonus occur together, the cause is a tumor until proven otherwise.
  • In approximately 50 percent of affected children, neuroblastoma is responsible for the symptoms associated with OMS.
  • In other cases, the disorder has been designated ‘idiopathic’ or attributed to various mostly viral infections, such as Coxsackievirus B3 or St. Louis encephalitis virus

The main treatment for OMS is early and sufficient immunotherapy with the goal of gaining a durable complete neurological remission. If a tumor is present, surgical resection is standard. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignancy arising from the neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia. It typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass. The etiology is unknown, however, familial predisposition is associated with mutations in the ALK gene (anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene).

It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. Clinical features include mass effect due to the tumor (spinal cord compression, bowel obstruction) and metastatic disease. Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis. In neonates, multiple cutaneous metastases cause deep blue discoloration of the skin called blueberry muffin baby. Children may present with fever, bone pains, and failure to thrive. Elevated blood pressure is seen due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood. 

Histology shows small round blue cells with dark nuclei and scanty cytoplasm and Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. 

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.
