questions.text:
A 60-year-old man who is a current smoker with COPD & chronic bronchitis experiences multiple exacerbations including 1 hospital admission for the same despite being on a combination of inhaled corticosteroids + LABA + LAMA. Which of the following is the next line of management for him?

LABA - Long-acting beta agonist

LAMA - Long-acting muscarinic antagonists

ICS - Inhaled corticosteroids
questions.solution:
For a patient who is a current smoker with COPD & chronic bronchitis on LABA + LAMA + ICS with exacerbations, the next line of management is adding roflumilast.

Roflumilast is a PDE-4 selective inhibitor approved for use in COPD. It has proven advantages of minimizing inflammation & reducing cardiovascular risks in these patients.

According to the latest GOLD 2024 guidelines for the management of COPD exacerbations:

Other options:

Option B: Adding azithromycin would be the next step for someone who is a former smoker on LABA+ LAMA + ICS with exacerbations.

Option C Increasing the dose of ICS may have no added benefit when already used in combination with LAMA & LABA

Option D. Adding systemic steroids is not recommended in long-term management due to their side effects

questions.text: A young man comes with complaints of sudden redness, watering, and photophobia in his eye, as shown in the image. Examination reveals follicles in the lower palpebral conjunctiva and a palpable preauricular lymph node. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette of a man with sudden redness, watering of the eye, and photophobia with the examination findings suggests the diagnosis of Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis caused by adenovirus.

Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus. They are linked to infections of the respiratory tract, eyes, and intestines. Different serotypes are implicated as the causes of different clinical manifestations:

  • Respiratory disease in children: 1,2,5,6
  • Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia: 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
  • ARD in military recruits: 4, 7, 21
  • Follicular (swimming pool)conjunctivitis: 3, 7
  • Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis(shipyard eye): 8, 19, 37
  • Diarrhea: 40, 41

Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis is a type of acute follicular conjunctivitis associated with superficial punctate keratitis and usually occurs in epidemics, hence the name EKC/shipyard eye. it is caused by adenoviruses type 8, 19, and 37 with type 8 being the most common cause. This spreads through contact with contaminated fingers and solutions. The incubation period after infection is  8 days.

Symptoms include Redness, profuse watering, mild mucoid discharge, Ocular discomfort, and Photophobia. On examination, Chemosis of the conjunctiva and Follicles involving the lower fornix and palpebral conjunctiva is characteristically present. Pre-auricular lymphadenopathy is frequently seen.

Treatment: Supportive treatment cold compresses, and sunglasses to decrease glare, decongestant and lubricant teardrops. Topical antibiotics help to prevent superadded bacterial infections.

Other options:

Option A:  Chlamydia trachomatis is the causative agent of adult inclusion conjunctivitis and trachoma. Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis that is characterized by a mix of follicular and papillary conjunctivitis, pannus formation, and cicatrization in later stages. Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is characterized by acute follicular conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient with chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Option B: Moraxella axenfield causes angular bacterial conjunctivitis. It is characterized by mild inflammation of the conjunctiva at the junction of the lid margins and the angles of the eyes. Topical oxytetracycline is used for the treatment. It is also called diplobacillary conjunctivitis.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis.

Option C: Enterovirus 70 (picornavirus) causes acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis characterized by marked red-eye and pain with conjunctival congestion, chemosis, and multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva along with lid edema  The disease is self-limiting, however, antibiotics may be given to prevent secondary infection. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. 

The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: After a diet rich in cholesterol, it is seen that the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver decreases. Which of the following enzymes is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the enzyme HMG CoA reductase is involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

Other options:

Option A: Acetoacetyl CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction that combines two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense forming acetoacetyl-CoA. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis which converts HMG coA to acetoacetate. 

Option C: HMG CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction where the third molecule of acetyl CoA condenses with acetoacetyl CoA forming beta-hydroxy beta-methyl glutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the OPD with fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy. His lymph node biopsy image is given below. What is the treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the biopsy findings showing nodules of lymphoma cells indicate a diagnosis of follicular lymphoma which is a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) whose treatment regimen is R-CHOP.

R-CHOP stands for rituximab, cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine (oncovin), and prednisone. 

NHLs affect multiple peripheral nodes in a non-contiguous manner. Extranodal presentations are commonly seen. The various types of NHL are DLBCL (DIffuse large B cell lymphoma), follicular lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, etc., of which DLBCL is the most common type. 

Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalized lymphadenopathy. A lymph node biopsy is adequate for the diagnosis of follicular lymphoma. Immunophenotyping of the cells showing CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL2 positive, and CD5 negative is suggestive that the cells originate from the germinal center. The majority of follicular lymphomas have characteristic (14:18) translocation.

Histopathology shows lymph nodes in a nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern. Two cell types are predominantly present in varying proportions: 

  • Centrocytes (small cleaved cells) - Small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm
  • Centroblasts - Large cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm. 

Other options: 

Option A: ABVD regimen standing for adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine is used for the treatment of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. 

Option C: BEACOPP regimen is used in the treatment of lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin lymphoma and it stands for bleomycin, etoposide, doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, vincristine, procarbazine, and prednisone.

Option D: MVAC regimen is used in the treatment of bladder cancer and it stands for methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, and cisplatin.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used in the treatment of overactive urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Tolterodine is commonly used in the treatment of the overactive urinary bladder. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. 

In an overactive bladder, there is an overactivity of the detrusor muscle due to the up-regulation of M3 receptors. Drugs that block these receptors such as tolterodine act by improving bladder capacity, reducing the frequency of bladder contractions, and lowering intravesicular pressure.

Anticholinergics are muscarinic receptor antagonists and parasympatholytics. The important uses of various anticholinergics are as follows:

  • Atropine - for AV block, organophosphorus poisoning, and refractive error testing in children (produces cycloplegic mydriasis)
  • Scopolamine/ hyoscine (transdermal patch) - for motion sickness
  • Ipratropium - for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and rhinorrhea 
  • Tolterodine - for childhood enuresis, overactive and neurogenic bladder
  • Pirenzepine (selective M1 receptor antagonist) - for peptic ulcer disease 
  • Benzhexol/ Trihexyphenidyl - for Parkinson's disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms
  • Dicyclomine (direct spasmolytic effect on GI smooth muscle) - for diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome
  • Glycopyrrolate (reduces secretions) - as a pre-anesthetic medication

Adverse effects of muscarinic antagonists include dryness of mouth, decreased sweating, thirst, mydriasis and blurring of vision, palpitations, and urinary retention. CNS effects include restlessness, hallucinations, and delirium.

questions.text: A male patient presents with gait abnormality. He had sustained a lower limb fracture 3 months back. After a detailed evaluation, he was prescribed the splint as shown in the image given below to correct the gait deformity. Which of the following fractures is responsible for the gait deformity for which he is being treated?

choices.text: Fracture of the lower third of tibia

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing an ankle-foot orthosis brace used for the treatment is suggestive of foot drop. It occurs due to common peroneal nerve injury, which is commonly caused by a fracture of the neck of the fibula.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

  • Fracture of the fibular neck
  • Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula

It is treated using an ankle-foot orthosis brace - a type of orthotic used to support the foot and ankle in foot drop.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided hemiparesis and hemisensory loss of the leg and foot. He is unable to correctly identify objects, is apathetic, and has significant personality changes. The occlusion of which of the following arteries could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery is likely to be responsible for these symptoms. The anterior cerebral artery supplies most of the superior-medial parietal lobes and portions of the frontal lobes. 

Anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid artery and are part of the circle of Willis. The left and right anterior cerebral arteries are connected by the anterior communicating artery.

Anterior cerebral artery occlusion distal to the anterior communicating artery manifests as:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss that mainly affects the leg and foot, due to the involvement of the paracentral lobule
  • Inability to identify objects correctly, apathy, and personality changes due to the involvement of frontal and parietal lobes

Other options:

Option B: Middle cerebral artery occlusion produces

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss mainly involve the face and arm as it supplies the precentral and postcentral gyri 
  • Aphasia if the left hemisphere is affected 
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to involvement of the optic radiation
  • Anosognosia if the right hemisphere is affected 

Option C: Posterior cerebral artery occlusion produces contralateral homonymous hemianopia with some macular sparing (due to collateral blood supply to occipital pole. It also produces visual agnosia and memory impairment. 

Option D: Vertebrobasilar artery occlusion produces

  • Ipsilateral pain and temperature loss of the face
  • Contralateral pain and temperature loss of the body
  • Attacks of hemianopia or complete cortical blindness
  • Ipsilateral loss of gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness
  • Vertigo, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and other cerebellar signs
  • Unilateral or bilateral hemiparesis
  • Coma

questions.text:
An elderly male patient presented with complaints of frequent UTIs and bone pain. His peripheral smear picture is given below. The International Staging System for classification is based on which of the following?

UTI - Urinary tract infection
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and peripheral smear with a mott cell point towards multiple myeloma, and the ISS (International Staging System) for classification is based on the levels of beta 2 microglobulin. 

This classification system is the most widely used method of assessing prognosis in multiple myeloma, and it has three stages. Serum beta 2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis for multiple myeloma. Frequent UTIs and bone pain are due to hypercalcemia - one of the CRAB criteria. 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

  • Serum β2-microglobulin
  • Deletion of 17pITP53 sequences and the translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • A high degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

It usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumours involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected in descending order of frequency are the vertebral column, ribs, skull, pelvis, femur, clavicle, and scapula. 

Radiographically, bone lesions appear as punched-out defects as shown below (skull), usually 1 to 4 cm in diameter, and consist of soft, gelatinous, red tumour masses.

Morphology:

Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus. Rouleaux formation is characteristic but not specific. High levels of M protein in the blood cause red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears, leading to rouleaux formation. Other findings include flame cells, mott cells and dutcher bodies.

The clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma can be done based on the identification of clonal plasma cells in the marrow and the presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anaemia, and bone lesions).

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text:
The mean level of CRP in patients with myocardial infarction was determined in a study. The study included 1000 patients, and one of the purposes was to compare the mean CRP in both male and female MI patients. Which of the following tests should be used to establish whether there is a difference in mean CRP levels between the two groups?

CRP - C - reactive protein
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the Unpaired student t-test would be performed to compare the results obtained as it is used for comparing two groups of patients i.e. male and female patients for a quantitative variable (CRP level).

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. 

Other options:

Option A: Paired t-test is used for a single sample to test the difference between two paired results. 

Option B: Chi-square test is used to differentiate proportions in two or more groups and assess the significance. 

Option D: A correlation analysis employs the correlation coefficient to characterize the linear association between two quantitative variables, such as in a research investigation assessing the linear relationship between cigarette usage and squamous cell carcinoma of the lung incidence.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A woman at her 31st week of gestation presented to the emergency department with lower abdominal pain. The on-duty clinician is concerned if the patient is in preterm labor and asks you to arrange and collect a sample to check for fetal fibronectin. From where is the sample taken?
questions.solution:
Fetal fibronectin in cervicovaginal secretions is used as a marker for impending preterm labor before membrane rupture.

Qualitative and quantitative fetal fibronectin levels are measured using ELISA, and levels >50 ng/mL is considered positive.

Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein present in high concentrations in maternal blood and in amnionic fluid, however, sample contamination by amnionic fluid and mater­nal blood should be avoided.

It aids in intercellular adhesion during implantation and in the maintenance of placental adherence to uterine decidua. It reflects stromal remodeling of the cervix before labor.

Preterm labor (PTL) refers to the onset of labor before the 37th completed week, counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

questions.text: A patient with long-standing CSOM  presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever, chills, and rigor. While examining the patient you notice a rapid rise in the CSF pressure on compressing the left jugular vein but no effect on compressing the vein on the right side. Identify the clinical test being performed.
questions.solution:
The clinical test being performed is the Tobey-Ayer Test and above mentioned clinical scenario suggests lateral sinus thrombophlebitis on the right side.

Tobey-Ayer Test is done to record CSF pressure by manometer and to see the effect of manual compression of one or both jugular veins. Compression of the vein on the thrombosed side produces no effect while compression on the vein on the healthy side produces a rapid rise in the CSF pressure which will be equal to the bilateral compression of jugular veins. 

Lateral sinus thrombophlebitis is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of a thrombus in the sinus. It occurs as a complication of acute coalescent mastoiditis, masked mastoiditis, or chronic suppuration of middle ear cholesteatoma.

Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis:

Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. 
Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to a perisinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction.
Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid. 

Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. 
Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein

Investigations: Blood culture to find out causative organisms. X-ray mastoid shows destruction of bone indicating cholesteatoma. CSF analysis is normal except for increased CSF pressure and helps rule out meningitis.

CECT shows a typical delta sign.

Treatment includes Intravenous antibacterial therapy, Mastoidectomy and exposure of the sinus, Ligation of the internal jugular vein, and Anticoagulant therapy. 

Other options: 

Option A: Gutzmann’s pressure test. It is done in Puberphonia. Pressing on the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched vocal cords and thus low-pitched voice can be produced. 

Option B: Crowe Beck test: Pressure on the jugular vein of the healthy side produces engorgement of retinal veins (seen by ophthalmoscopy) and supraorbital veins. Engorgement of veins subsides on the release of pressure. This test is also done in case of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis.

Option D:  Maximal Stimulation Test type of electrodiagnostic test, useful to differentiate between neurapraxia and degeneration of the nerve. They also help to predict prognosis and indicate the time for surgical decompression of the nerve. Other electrodiagnostic tests are the Minimal Nerve Excitability Test, Electroneuronography (ENoG), and Electromyography (EMG).

questions.text: An autopsy is being performed on the corpse of a 50-year-old HIV-infected patient. The forensic medicine resident uses a technique of in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs. This technique is known as_____
questions.solution:
Rokitansky's technique involves performing in situ dissection combined with en block removal of organs.

It is considered the ideal method for patients affected with highly contagious illnesses like HIV and hepatitis B.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease undergoing long-term hemodialysis presents with a painful lesion on the abdomen as shown below. To identify the underlying pathology, which stain should be used for the biopsy specimen?
questions.solution:
The given chronic kidney disease patient on long-term hemodialysis presented with painful purpuric lesions on the abdomen, suggesting calciphylaxis due to secondary hyperparathyroidism. Hence von Kossa stain should be used to the biopsy specimen for calcification identification.

Calciphylaxis, also called calcific uremic arteriolopathy, mostly affects patients with end-stage renal disease and secondary HPT. There is an imbalance of inhibitors and inducers of vascular calcification resulting in excess calcium deposition in medium-sized arteries. This causes necrosis of the part supplied by that vessel.

Causes of calciphylaxis include medically refractory hyperphosphatemia, a high calcium-phosphate product, high PTH levels, warfarin use, protein C, and protein S deficiency, and other causes of thrombophilia.

It presents as painful violaceous nonhealing wounds on the skin. The underlying microvascular calcification may progress to → ischemic necrosis → ulceration and gangrene → sepsis → death. Commonly affected areas are the fatty areas of the thighs, abdomen, and buttocks symmetrically.

A diagnosis of calciphylaxis is made in a patient with chronic kidney disease and secondary HPT who has the combination of painful, violaceous, tender cutaneous skin lesions, and a skin biopsy demonstrating vascular and extravascular calcifications without the presence of of histologic findings of vasculitis.

Management:

  • Supportive and preventive measures include hyperbaric oxygen therapy
  • Debridement and wound care
  • Antibiotics to treat secondary infection
  • Total parathyroidectomy with transcervical thymectomy
  • Cinacalcet and phosphate binders
  • Intravenous sodium thiosulphate

questions.text: An AIDS patient presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Skin biopsy reveals proliferating spindle cells in the dermis, with slit-like spaces containing the red cells. Which of the following is not associated with the causative organism of the patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
The above image shows red-purple macules and plaques, the clinical features, and the biopsy findings are together suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, which is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8). Adult T-cell leukemia is caused by the human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV-1) and not HHV8.

HTLV is a retrovirus, which is the causative agent of adult T-cell leukemia-lymphomas (ATL) as well as a nervous system degenerative disorder called tropical spastic paraparesis.

HHV8 is associated with:

  • Kaposi sarcomas - HHV8 affects the lymphovascular system and presents as pigmented skin lesions. It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS-defining illness. The lesions appear as red-purple macules or raised plaques over the skin, and the biopsy shows spindle cells in the dermis.
  • Primary effusion lymphomas are body-cavity-based lymphomas associated with AIDS. They occur as an effusion in the pleural, pericardial, or peritoneal cavities without the presence of a mass in the cavity.
  • Multicentric Castleman disease causes symptoms like fever, chills, and generalized lymphadenopathy and is seen in patients with or without HIV/AIDS.

questions.text: A 57-year-old diabetic man presents to the ER with complaints of chest pain radiating to the left arm & sweating for the past 20 minutes. His ECG on admission revealed the following. Which of the following vessels is most likely implicated in his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a diabetic patient with chest pain and ECG showing characteristic biphasic T waves in leads V2 & V3 is highly suggestive of Wellens syndrome. This occurs due to high-grade stenosis of Left Anterior descending artery.

Wellens syndrome is characterized by ECG showing deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in V2-V3 (may extend from V1-V6) and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.

These individuals are at a high risk of developing extensive Anterior wall Myocardial infarction & require emergency intervention for revascularization. 

The ECG showing biphasic waves in V2-V3

Other options : 

Option A: Involvement of the left circumflex artery usually results in Lateral wall MI showing ST segment elevation in leads I, aVL, V5 & V6

Option C. Involvement of the right coronary artery usually results in Inferior wall MI showing ST segment elevation in leads II, III & aVF.

Option D. Involvement of the posterior descending artery usually results in Posterior wall MI  showing ST segments elevation in leads V7-V9 or reciprocal changes in V1-V3

questions.text:
A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient who isn't compliant with ART presents with non-bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite. His CD4 count is 40 cells/cu mm. He also complained of decreased visual acuity. Which among the following is likely to be his endoscopy image?

ART - Antiretroviral therapy
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette represents a case of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in an HIV-positive patient which on endoscopy, is identified by deep, punched-out ulcers as seen in the image 3. 

In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by HSV, CMV, or candida. 

CMV lesions appear as deep, punched-out, serpiginous ulcers in otherwise normal mucosa, particularly in the distal oesophagus. CMV is one of the most common causes of congenital infections and the most common viral infection in solid organ transplant recipients. It is most commonly seen 1-4 months after solid organ transplantation. It can also affect HIV-infected patients, especially when the CD4 count is less than 50 cells/cubic mm. It can cause many systemic infections, including fever, pneumonia, gastrointestinal ulcers, colitis, hepatitis, retinitis, and acute or chronic graft dysfunction.  

CMV retinitis is a necrotic retinal infection that results in painless irreversible vision loss. Patients may complain of blurred vision, floaters, and scintillations. It is usually bilateral and is characterized by perivascular hemorrhage and exudates in the retina (pizza pie appearance or scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance).

CMV colitis should be considered in AIDS patients with CD4+ lymphocyte count < 50/μL, fevers, and diarrhea. It presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and anorexia. Diarrhea is usually non-bloody.  CMV infection is treated with either valganciclovir/ganciclovir or foscarnet for 3–6 weeks.

Note- HSV ulcers can also present as punched-out ulcers which maybe covered by pseudomembrane, and are surrounded by vesicles.

Other options:

Option A: Candida esophagitis which shows white friable plaques and adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes, in advanced form 

Option B: Eosinophilic esophagitis which appears as a series of rings in the esophageal wall. These rings appear as stripes on the cat and are also known as the feline oesophagus.

Option D: Pill-induced esophagitis showing erythematous erosions in the middle third or distal oesophagus due to drugs such as antibiotics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and acetaminophen.

questions.text: An effective prevention program resulted in a 90% decrease in the prevalence of a disease in a community. What change would be seen in the characteristics of the screening test?

choices.text: Its negative predictive value has increased
Its positive predictive value has increased
There is no change in the test’s characteristics

questions.solution:
Negative predictive value (NPV) of a test is inversely proportional to the prevalence of a disease.

If the prevalence falls, the NPV is increased.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the OPD with excessive salivation and wetting of pillows for the past 1 month. She is a known case of schizophrenia and was admitted 1 month back due to her tendencies of self-harm, following which she was started on a new drug. What is the drug responsible for her complaints?
questions.solution:
Clozapine causes wet pillow syndrome. It causes excessive drooling of saliva at night time.

The other side effects include agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and weight gain. Clozapine also has the highest risk of precipitating seizures.

Haloperidol causes the highest extra-pyramidal symptoms, akathisia, and hyperprolactinemia • It can also lead to sedation, weight gain, and hypotension.

Risperidone is known to cause hyperprolactinemia and other metabolic side effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was posted for open inguinal hernia repair. He is a known hypertensive for the past 6 years and is poorly controlled on medications. Which of the following muscle relaxant can exacerbate hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium can exacerbate hypertension in poorly controlled patients by inducing vagal blockade and neural release of catecholamine leading to sympathetic stimulation.

For the same reason, large bolus doses of pancuronium are to be cautiously used in patients with coronary artery disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and aortic stenosis.

Pancuronium is a steroidal non-depolarizing muscle relaxant. It is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted through the kidney.

In predisposed individuals, it causes increased atrioventricular conduction and catecholamines release resulting in ventricular arrhythmia. Individuals who are hypersensitive to bromide can exhibit allergic reactions to pancuronium. 

Other options:

Option B- Atracuronium causes hypotension due to a drop in systemic vascular resistance.

Option C- Vecuronium is devoid of significant cardiovascular effects.

Option D- Rocuronium is cardio stable and shows no changes in heart rate and blood pressure.

questions.text: A sanitation worker presents with high-grade fever and red eyes. On examination, there is icterus, neck rigidity, the sign demonstrated below. Investigations show azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most appropriate drug to be prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient with fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, along with image showing kernig's sign positive and other meningeal signs i.e. neck rigidity is suggestive of a diagnosis of leptospirosis. This along with azotemia and elevated liver enzymes are features of severe leptospirosis- Weil's disease. Intravenous penicillin is most appropriate drug in severe leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

Jaundice, when present, can be profound, and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation or relative bradycardia may also be observed. The bacteria is spread by the urine of infected animals and humans, thus making sanitary workers a high-risk population due to poor working conditions.  

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test. 

Treatment for leptospirosis is based on the severity of the disease. In mild cases, oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin is preferred and in severe cases, intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone is commonly used.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with right flank pain and gross hematuria. He has a family history of renal disease. His ultrasound abdomen reveals multiple cortical and medullary cysts, along with a right-sided renal calculus. What type of renal stone is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient’s presentation of flank pain, hematuria, renal cysts, and family history is highly suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Uric acid stones are the most common type of stones in patients with ADPKD.

ADPKD is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple cysts in both kidneys, leading to progressive renal enlargement and eventual loss of kidney function. It is one of the most common inherited kidney disorders and often presents in adulthood. The disease is most commonly caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 genes, which code for polycystin-1 and polycystin-2, proteins involved in cellular mechanosensation and calcium signalling.

ADPKD often remains asymptomatic until the fourth or fifth decade of life. Back or flank pain is common due to renal cyst complications such as infection, haemorrhage, or stones. Hematuria usually results from cyst rupture. Infection of cysts or acute pyelonephritis affects nearly half of ADPKD patients, often caused by gram-negative bacteria, presenting with fever, flank pain, and sometimes bacteremia. 

Uric acid stones are the most common type of calculi seen in ADPKD patients, followed by calcium oxalate. The predisposition to uric acid stone formation in ADPKD arises from the acidic urinary environment seen in these patients, along with a tendency towards hyperuricemia. The acidic pH promotes the crystallisation of uric acid, making stone formation more likely. Proper management of uric acid stones in ADPKD involves maintaining adequate hydration and alkalinising the urine through dietary modifications or medications like potassium citrate.

ADPKD diagnosis is typically based on family history and renal imaging. Ultrasound is used for at-risk individuals, with criteria based on age and cyst count. Genetic testing may assist when imaging is inconclusive.

Treatment for ADPKD focuses on slowing renal function decline and managing cardiovascular risks, primarily through blood pressure control (target <140/90 mmHg). Dialysis or kidney transplant is eventually needed for many patients, with some requiring nephrectomy to manage symptoms or make room for transplantation. Emerging therapies, like tolvaptan and somatostatin analogues, show promise in slowing cyst growth and reducing renal pain.

questions.text: Barrel-shaped arthroconidia as depicted in the below image is a feature of _______
questions.solution:
Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that exists in two distinct forms, saprophytic and parasitic.

In the soil, the organism exists as a mould with septate hyphae resembling the shape of a barrel. When entering a host, the arthroconidia (spores) break off from the hyphae and evolve into round structures called spherules. When inside the host, spherules grow and undergo internal division, forming smaller structures called endospores.

Around 60% of infected individuals remain completely asymptomatic. The rest 40% have respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain which develop from days to 2 weeks after inhalation of infectious spores.

questions.text: You are an intern in the pre-eclampsia ward, where your role includes administering magnesium sulfate injections to patients. Which of the following is not a proposed mechanism of action of magnesium sulfate in the treatment of pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: Enhances the motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine

questions.solution:
All of the following are the proposed mechanisms of action of magnesium sulfate except that " it enhances the motor endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine", rather it reduces the activity of acetylcholine by decreasing the motor endplate sensitivity to the neurotransmitter. 

Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for managing severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia, and its therapeutic effects are mediated through several mechanisms.

  • Decreases the presynaptic release of glutamate, a neurotransmitter involved in excitatory signalling, which helps reduce neuronal excitability.
  • Blocks NMDA receptors (Option B), reducing excitatory neurotransmission and preventing seizures.
  • Potentiates adenosine(Option D), which contributes to its anticonvulsant effects.
  • Increases calcium buffering in mitochondria  (Option C), helping to protect cells from calcium-induced damage.
  • Blocks voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to vasodilation and reduced blood pressure. 
  • Reduces the endplate sensitivity to acetylcholine, which helps to decrease neuromuscular excitability and prevent seizures in eclamptic patients.

Magnesium sulfate is primarily used to manage pre-eclampsia and prevent eclampsia due to its neuroprotective and anticonvulsant properties. It promotes cerebral vasodilation, dilates uterine arteries, increases the production of endothelial prostacyclin and inhibits platelet activation. However, it is not effective in controlling hypertension during pregnancy, as its main focus is on preventing seizures rather than lowering blood pressure.

The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

  Regimen
   Intramuscular (Pritchard)  Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)
 Loading Dose   4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)  4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute
 Maintenance Dose 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock 1–2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the letter “X”, the second line from the top in the given Snellen’s chart at 6m of distance from the chart?
questions.solution:
The angle subtended by the letter “X”, the second line from the top in the given Snellen’s chart at 6m of distance from the chart is 30 min.

At 36 meters, this letter "X" subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc. Since the viewing distance is reduced by a factor of 1/6, the angle subtended by the letter at 6 meters becomes 6 times larger, resulting in an angle of 30 minutes of arc (5 × 6 = 30 minutes).

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, with each successive line featuring smaller letters. At the nodal point of the eye, each letter is designed to subtend a specific visual angle, allowing for the assessment of visual acuity. The minimum angle of resolution for normal vision is 1 minute of arc, meaning the smallest angle at which the eye can resolve two points separately.

Each whole letter on Snellen's chart is designed to subtend an angle of 5 minutes of arc at the nodal point of the eye, which corresponds to the threshold of normal visual acuity. For example, the largest letter on the Snellen chart is positioned so that it subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc when viewed from a distance of 60 meters. As you move down the chart, the letters get smaller, and they will subtend an angle of 5 minutes of arc at progressively shorter distances: 36 meters, 24 meters, 18 meters, 12 meters, 9 meters, and finally, 6 meters for the smallest letters at the bottom of the chart.

questions.text: A high school graduate went to the army recruitment drive but was not selected because of his flat foot. This condition is caused due to the involvement of which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
A flat foot is caused due to the involvement of the spring ligament.

Pes planus or flat foot is caused to due the collapse of the medial longitudinal arch of the foot and can be either congenital or acquired. Its causes include rupture of spring ligament, tarsal coalition, disruption of tibialis posterior tendon, tarsometatarsal arthritis, and hindfoot degenerative or inflammatory arthritis.

Spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

It supports the head of the talus which if fails or is destroyed, leads to separation of the navicular and calcaneus, in turn allowing the talar head, the highest point of the arch, to descend and leading to a flat-foot deformity.

Other options:

The deltoid ligament is extremely strong and stabilizes the inside of the ankle. Tears of this ligament are most common when the ankle undergoes an unstable ankle fracture. Both the deltoid and spring ligaments are present on the medial side and their injuries are common in eversion sprains.

The anterior talofibular ligament is the “ankle sprain ligament” because it is the one that is most often damaged when the ankle is rolled.

The posterior talofibular ligament functions to stabilize the ankle joint and subtalar joint. Injuries are rare to this ligament unless there is an ankle dislocation or subluxation. The talofibular ligaments are present on the lateral side and their injuries are common in inversion sprains.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is undergoing femoral hernia repair using the Lockwood approach. During the procedure, there is a sudden uncontrolled haemorrhage. The surgeon suspects the bleeding is due to an aberrant obturator artery. Which anatomical structure is most likely responsible for this haemorrhage that may have been dissected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of sudden hemorrhage in Lockwood repair for femoral hernia due to an aberrant obturator artery is most likely due to dissection of the lacunar ligament.

In femoral hernia repair, particularly using the Lockwood approach, the lacunar ligament is an important structure that is located medial to the femoral vessels and adjacent to the obturator foramen, where the aberrant obturator artery may be present. An aberrant obturator artery, which arises from the external iliac artery (from the inferior epigastric artery) instead of the internal iliac artery. During the dissection, especially when securing the mesh, the lacunar ligament could be inadvertently injured, leading to uncontrolled hemorrhage.

Other options:

Option A. The Iliopubic tract is further lateral and does not directly lie in the path of the aberrant obturator artery.

Option B. The obturator artery does not typically run near the medial 1/3rd of the inguinal ligament, so this is an unlikely site of injury.

Option D: The aberrant obturator artery is more medial, and the lateral deep inguinal ring is further from its typical course.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with low-grade fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for the last two months. He also gives a history of arthralgia involving multiple joints for the last two years. An endoscopic biopsy was taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the correct treatment regimen for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with diarrhea and chronic arthralgia and the given slide showing macrophages filled with PAS-positive inclusions points to a diagnosis of Whipple's disease. Amongst the given options, the best-suited treatment regimen for Whipple's disease is ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks, followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 12 months.  Prolonged antibiotics are recommended but there is still uncertainty prevailing regarding the optimal regimen.

Whipple's disease is a multi-system disease caused by infection with gram-positive bacillus, Tropheryma whipplei. Clinical features include arthralgia and arthritis, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Arthralgias and arthritis are present for many years before the appearance of GI symptoms. CNS involvement is common and presents as psychiatric manifestations, memory problems or ophthalmoplegia. Dementia may occur in later stages. Cardiac involvement may be in the form of endocarditis, myocarditis, and pericarditis. Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas may also be seen. Intermittent low-grade fever is present in most of the patients.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is primarily established by endoscopic biopsy and histological evaluation. Infiltration of lamina propria with PAS-positive macrophages containing the bacilli is diagnostic. The remainder of the cases are diagnosed by PCR which can be done on duodenal biopsies or fluids (such as CSF and synovial fluid) or tissues.

questions.text: An elderly male presents with complaints of dizziness and a sense of imbalance. These symptoms are aggravated by the exertion of his left upper extremity. There is associated numbness and claudication in his left hand. The left radial pulse is feeble. What is the pathophysiology of the underlying disease?

choices.text: Compression of subclavian vessels and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus
Stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the vertebral artery
Compression of subclavian vessels and the upper trunk of the brachial plexus
Stenosis of the Vertebral artery proximal to the subclavian artery.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency (dizziness and a sense of imbalance), numbness and claudication in his left hand, and a feeble left radial pulse is suggestive of subclavian steal syndrome. It occurs due to stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery. 

The stenosis depicted above will result in hypoperfusion and decreased blood supply to the ipsilateral upper limb and the vertebral artery. However, due to the presence of abundant collaterals in the circle of Willis the blood supply to the brain will remain unaffected. The most common cause is atherosclerosis in the first part of the subclavian artery.

Risk factors for the condition include hypertension, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia. The symptoms start when the patient exercises the left upper limb leading to increased demand in blood supply. so to meet this demand, the direction of blood flow in the left vertebral artery reverses and the blood supply is derived from the contralateral vertebral artery. 

This reversal and “stealing” of blood from the contralateral vertebral artery results in diminished supply to the basilar artery and thus the brain. Hence the patient presents with symptoms of dizziness and syncopal episodes. Clinically, the affected upper limb will show feeble pulses.

Diagnosis can be made by duplex ultrasound, CT, or MR angiography. it can be managed with angioplasty or surgical bypass of the occluded segment, although angioplasty with stenting is preferred.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and oliguria for 3 days. On examination, swelling around the eyes and both ankles was noted. The results of his laboratory investigations are given below. What is the most likely cause?

Fractional excretion of sodium(FeNa): 0.5%

Urine osmolality: 600mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with nausea, vomiting, oliguria, and swelling around the eyes and ankles along with laboratory values of FeNa and Urine osmolality suggests prerenal acute kidney injury an example of which is cardiac failure.

Lab findings of prerenal AKI are:

  • BUN/creatinine ratio above 20
  • FeNa <1%
  • Hyaline casts in urine sediment
  • Urine specific gravity >1.018
  • Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. He struggles to hear and understand speech despite appropriately fit hearing aids. The ENT specialist decided that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. What is the site in which the electrode is placed?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway a prerequisites for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is being admitted to the ambulatory ward for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and he has been told that he can go home the same day. You are an intern in general surgery and have explained to the patient that there are a few reasons why he might need to stay overnight in the hospital instead of going home. Which of the following would be the most common reason a patient stays overnight after ambulatory surgery?
questions.solution:
The most common reason a patient stays overnight after ambulatory surgery is nausea and vomiting.

Post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common reason resulting in delayed discharge following day surgery in more than 30% of patients undergoing general anaesthesia.

4 main causes of unplanned admission after day-care surgery:

  • PONV
  • uncontrolled post-operative pain
  • social reasons
  • patients going late to the theatre

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented to the outpatient department with a history of headaches and seizures along with hearing and vision problems. An MRI of the brain was done, and the image is shown below. Identify the visual field defect seen in this patient and the pathway involved.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the MRI brain showing a temporal lobe mass will cause superior quadrantanopia due to the involvement of Meyer’s loop.

Superior Quadrantanopia is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibres of the optic radiations located in the temporal lobe, also called the Meyer’s Loop.  The inferior fibres of optic radiations contain fibres from the ipsilateral infero-temporal retina and contralateral infero-nasal retina. This leads to ipsilateral superonasal visual field loss and contralateral superior-temporal visual field loss, causing a “pie in the sky” defect.

The hearing problems experienced by the patient are due to the involvement of the primary auditory cortex located in the temporal lobe.

Inferior Quadrantanopia is caused when lesions affect the superior fibres of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe, also called Baum’s loop. The superior fibres of optic radiations contain fibres from the ipsilateral supero-temporal retina and contralateral superonasal retina. This leads to ipsilateral infero-nasal and contralateral infero-temporal visual field loss, causing a “pie in the floor” visual field defect.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test is used to demonstrate the toxicity of:
questions.solution:
Ascoli's Thermo precipitation test is used for the diagnosis of anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) using a tissue extract and anthrax antiserum.

It is a precipitin test in which the antibody produces visible precipitate when it reacts with the antigen. It is used for detection of anthrax bacilli in animal hides and meat.

But this test lacks specificity because the thermostable antigen of bacillus anthrax is shares by other species of bacillus too.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk of a child with positive Darier's sign, which is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa:

It is the commonest type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. 

The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20-40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features:

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific for mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • Psoralen + ultraviolet light A (PUVA) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called as café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size from 1 to 2 mm to greater than 20 cm in greatest diameter. They may appear at birth or at the first decade.

They may present on any body parts, but most commonly involves the trunk and the extremities. Darier's sign is not seen in CALMs.

They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1, NF2), McCune-Albright syndrome, and tuberous sclerosis.

Image below shows café‐au‐lait spots.

Option B: Juvenile xanthogranuloma is a benign proliferative disorder of histiocytes occurring in early infancy and childhood.

It presents as reddish yellow maculo-papular lesions which may evolve into yellow brown patches/plaques with surface telangiectasis.

They may be single or multiple. Single lesions are the most common. Lesions occur most commonly on the face, head and neck, followed by trunk and extremities.

Darier's sign is positive in juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Image below shows a yellow papule in the right inner arm of a child suggestive of juvenile xanthogranuloma.

Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It present as tense blisters and vesicles, urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels,” "cluster of jewels," or “string of pearls” formation, although this sign may also be seen in bullous pemphigoid. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

The image below shows linear IgA dermatosis at various sites.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented with breathlessness, chest pain, and syncopal attacks on and off for 3 months. Echocardiography showed an abnormality of the cardiac valve. Identify the valvular lesion and the associated murmur from the below image that depicts the heart sounds and murmur of the underlying condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a systolic murmur (occurring in the interval between S1 and S2) are suggestive of aortic stenosis and the associated systolic murmur. 

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It is caused by rheumatic heart disease or by the calcification of the normal aortic valve or a congenital bicuspid valve. Narrowing of the aortic valve causes a decrease in stroke volume. This results in a weak pulse (pulsus parvus), which slowly rises and has a delayed peak (pulsus tardus)—a pattern best appreciated in the carotid arteries.

The clinical features of aortic stenosis are exertional dyspnea due to left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction, angina pectoris due to the combination of the increased oxygen demand and reduced supply, syncope due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation, which lead to a reduction in cerebral perfusion.

An ejection mid-systolic murmur can be auscultated in aortic stenosis. It begins after the first heart sound (S1), increases in intensity toward the middle of the ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is low-pitched, rough, and rasping in character. It is best heard at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

A systolic ejection click can be heard in young patients with a bicuspid aortic valve, but disappears as the valves become calcified. A2 and P2 may be heard at the same time, or A2 may follow P2, resulting in the paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2). The fourth heart sound (S4) is often heard at the apex, indicating the presence of left ventricular hypertrophy.

Other options:

In mitral stenosis, a diastolic murmur can be heard during auscultation.

Other murmurs: 

  • Pansystolic murmur of functional tricuspid regurgitation:
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Louder during inspiration and reduces during forced expiration (Carvallo sign)
  • Graham Steell murmur of pulmonary regurgitation:
    • High-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo-blowing murmur
    • Audible along the left sternal border
    • Occurs with severe pulmonary hypertension

A pansystolic murmur of at least grade III/VI intensity can be auscultated in chronic severe mitral regurgitation. It is heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla. Ruptured chordae tendineae may produce a murmur with a cooing or “seagull” quality, whereas a flail leaflet may produce a murmur with a musical quality. 

S1 is generally absent or soft. Wide splitting of S2 may occur due to the premature closure of the aortic valve. A low-pitched, third heart sound (S3) may occur following A2. S4 can also be audible in patients with acute severe MR.

An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic aortic regurgitation. It is high-pitched and blowing in character. It is best heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. It may be accompanied by a mid-systolic ejection murmur in isolated AR or the Austin Flint murmur in severe AR. The latter is a soft, low-pitched, rumbling, mid-to-late diastolic murmur produced by the displacement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve by the AR stream.

A2 is usually absent, and occasionally, S4 also may be heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

 

Related Pearl: The causes of holosystolic murmur are:

  1. Mitral regurgitation

  • Best heard at the apex
  • Radiates to axilla or base
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • A2 is not heard at the apex

  2. Tricuspid regurgitation

  • Best heard at lower left sternal border
  • Radiates to the epigastrium and right sternal border
  • Increases in intensity during inspiration
  • Prominent c-v waves seen in JVP

  3. Ventricular septal defect

  • Beat heard over left 3rd and 4th intercostal space
  • Radiates widely
  • Palpable thrill present
  • Decreases in intensity with amyl nitrate
  • Wide splitting of S2 seen

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty with increased agitation and random movements as shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient's movement disorder?
questions.solution:
The involuntary, jerky, random, purposeless movements of his head and upper limbs suggest this movement disorder to be that of chorea. 

Chorea is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements that mainly affect the head and upper limbs. The characteristic darting movements in the tongue are visible. The choreic movements are caused by the destruction of D2 neurons of the neostriatum. The neostriatum consists of the caudate nucleus and putamen.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen

Other options:

Option A: Tardive dyskinesia is a late extrapyramidal feature that usually occurs after months or years of antipsychotic treatment. It is characterized by stereotyped, repetitive, painless, involuntary, quick choreiform (tic-like) movements of the face, eyelids, mouth, tongue, extremities, or trunk. This condition is 5 to 6 times more prevalent in the elderly than in younger patients. 

Option B: Sudden, wild flailing of one side of the body suggests the movement disorder, hemiballismus, due to a lesion at the contralateral subthalamic nucleus. 

Option C: Athetosis is characterised by writhing and sinuous movements, particularly noticeable in the digits and extremities and is seen in patients with hepatic encephalopathy.

questions.text: The anti-emetic and prokinetic action of metoclopramide is primarily due to all the actions given below, except:
questions.solution:
Metoclopramide has both antiemetic and prokinetic action. Peripheral D2 antagonism and 5HT4 agonism contribute to the prokinetic action. 5HT3 antagonism may also contribute to anti-emetic action especially at higher doses.

D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor trigger zone is responsible for anti-emetic effects.

Metoclopramide includes the following action:

  • 5HT4 receptor agonism
  • 5HT3 receptor antagonism
  • D2 antagonism
  • Sensitization of muscarinic receptors on smooth muscles

questions.text: A seven-year-old boy presented to the emergency department with high-grade fever, headaches, confusion, and projectile vomiting. A lumbar puncture was done and a gram stain of the cerebrospinal fluid revealed gram-negative diplococci in pairs inside polymorphs. Which of the following is not true about the organism implicated in this condition?

choices.text: It is catalase and oxidase positive
It can utilize glucose and maltose
It can grow in ordinary culture media
The human nasopharynx is the only reservoir of this organism

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitides (Meningococcus). It cannot grow in ordinary culture media.

Meningococcus requires media enriched with blood, serum, or ascitic fluid which promotes growth by neutralizing certain inhibiting factors. Blood agar, chocolate agar, and Thayer Martin media are used to culture meningococci. They form smooth, bluish-grey, round, glistening colonies on solid media. They grow best at a pH of 7.4-7.6.

Meningococci are gram-negative, oval, or spherical cocci, usually found in pairs inside polymorphs (Image shown below). They are catalase and oxidase positive and utilize glucose and maltose, which helps them differentiate from gonococcus, which can only utilize glucose.

The human nasopharynx is the only known reservoir of meningococcus. It is implicated in diseases including cerebrospinal meningitis and meningococcal septicemia. It travels to the meninges from the nasopharynx through the perineural sheath of the olfactory nerve through the cribriform plate. On reaching the central nervous system, a suppurative lesion of the meninges is set up, involving the cortex and the spinal cord. Case fatality is high and survivors may suffer from deafness or blindness as long-term sequelae. 

It can also lead to septicemia which presents as fever with chills, shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and multi-system failure. This is also known as Waterhouse- Friderichsen syndrome.  

Treatment of meningococcal meningitis includes intravenous Penicillin G. Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime can be used to initiate the treatment before the etiology is known. 

Chemoprophylaxis is given to the household and other close contacts of a patient with meningococcal disease. Rifampicin or ciprofloxacin is recommended for chemoprophylaxis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old IV drug user presents with new blistering skin rashes on his face, upper back, and hands, along with excessive hair growth on his eyebrows and ears. On physical examination of his hand, the findings are as shown in the image. Which of the following infections is most likely to coexist in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of an IV drug abuser with new onset blistering skin rashes on sun-exposed areas and a history of hypertrichosis along with an image showing blistering, erosions, and hyperpigmentation of hands points towards a diagnosis of Porphyria Cutanea Tarda(PCT). It shows a high association with the Hepatitis C virus.

Porphyria Cutanea Tarda (PCT) is the most common form of porphyria, caused by a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. The hallmark feature of PCT is the development of blistering skin rashes that rupture and form crusts in sun-exposed areas, such as the hands, face, and upper body. Hypertrichosis, particularly on the face, is also a common finding.

On laboratory evaluation, urinary ALA (aminolevulinic acid) levels are markedly elevated, while urinary PBG (porphobilinogen) levels remain normal, which helps differentiate it from other types of porphyria.

Management involves phlebotomy, which is the first-line treatment, as it helps reduce iron stores and lowers the production of porphyrins. Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are effective second-line treatments due to their ability to reduce porphyrin synthesis.
