questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient had to undergo a cesarean section in a hospital due to a complicated delivery. She was discharged on her 5th-day postpartum. How many visits by an ASHA worker is recommended in this case?
questions.solution:
As this case is an institutional delivery through LSCS, the patient would be discharged after 5-6 days from the hospital, therefore 5 visits by the ASHA worker are recommended here.

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs. 250 if she completes all her visits.

ASHA visits all newborns on proper schedule up to their 42 days of life. The number of home visits will be,

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42).
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1).
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3).

In case a newborn is discharged from SNCU, then ASHA will receive a full incentive after completing the remaining visits. ASHA will do additional follow-up visits every month for low-birth-weight newborns up to two years, and SNCU discharged babies up to one year. For each follow-up visit, ASHA will receive an additional Rs. 50.

If the woman delivers at her maternal house and returns to her husband’s house or vice versa, the visits might have been done by two ASHAs at the two different places. In such cases, if each ASHA completes at least 3 visits, they will receive Rs 125 each. If ASHA completes less than 3 visits, they will not receive any incentive.

In the case of twins/triplets, then ASHA will receive twice (Rs. 500) or thrice (Rs. 750), the regular payment.

The payments are made to ASHA on the 45th day, subject to the following conditions:

  • The birth weight is recorded in the Maternal and Child Protection (MCP) Card.
  • Ensuring that the newborn is immunized with BCG, first doses of OPV and DPT/Pentavalent, and entered into the MCP card.
  • Enabling birth registration.
  • Both mother and newborn are safe until the 42nd day.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought in by her parents due to recurrent lung infections and an abnormal gait. Examination revealed myoclonic jerks, graying hair, café au lait macules, and cutaneous lesions in her eyes and face as shown below. On which chromosome is the gene for this disorder located?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young girl with recurrent lung infections, and neurological findings along with the image depicting telangiectasia suggests a diagnosis of Ataxia telangiectasia for which the responsible gene is located on chromosome 11q22-23.

Ataxia telangiectasia, also known as Louis–Bar syndrome, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a defect in the ATM gene(ataxia telangiectasia mutated). This gene is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair causes combined immunodeficiency (defective isotype switching and association with thymic hypoplasia) and predisposes to an increased risk of lymphoreticular neoplasms such as lymphoma/ leukemia.

 Ataxia telangiectasia present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions in the conjunctiva and skin, associated with progressive ataxia, recurrent sinopulmonary infections, hypogonadism, premature aging, café au lait macules, sensitivity to ionizing radiation, insulin resistance(DM type 1), and raised AFP levels. The neurologic manifestations include Truncal and limb ataxia, dysarthria, nystagmus, extensor plantar responses, myoclonic jerks, areflexia, and distal sensory deficits. death occurs early in the second decade.

The image below shows ocular telangiectasia in a patient with ataxia telangiectasia:

Other options:

Option A: The expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 9q13 causes an autosomal recessive disorder called Friedreich ataxia. clinical features include progressive ataxia, dysarthria, sensory neuropathy, depressed deep tendon reflexes, pes cavus, cardiomyopathy, and an x-ray showing scoliosis. The CNS features are similar to those in ataxia telangiectasia so it is an important differential diagnosis.

Option B: Neurofibromatosis 1 is caused by the autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutations in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11. It is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes neurofibromin, a negative RAS regulator. It can present with café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, pseudoarthrosis, and optic gliomas.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis 2 is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder due to a mutation in the Merlin gene on chromosome 22q12, which is a tumor suppressor gene. It presents as bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, ependymomas, and meningiomas.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with primary hyperparathyroidism is undergoing a focused parathyroidectomy. How can one confirm that adequate parathyroid gland has been removed?

choices.text: PTH falls >20% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >50% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >10% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >30% within 10 minutes of removal of gland

questions.solution:
Adequate removal of parthyroid gland can be confirmed by a fall of >50% in PTH levels within 10 mins of removal of the gland.

Most patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. Therefore, they undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay as suggested by Miami criteria.

Miami criteria are based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. When multiple parathyroids are resected, parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted.

Related Pearl: Indications for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary HPT (2013-2014 NIH Consensus Conference Guidelines)

  • Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limit of normal
  • Renal: 
    • Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30%
    • 24-h urine calcium >400 mg/day
    • Presence of nephrolithiasis or nephrocalcinosis
  • Skeletal: 
    • Decreased bone mineral density (T score <-2.5)
    • Presence of vertebral fracture
  • Age <50 years

questions.text:
A group of researchers wanted to evaluate the efficacy of statins in lowering the risk of heart attack in patients with dyslipidemia using a statistical technique that combined the data from multiple independent RCTs. Which of the following guidelines do they have to follow to improve the quality of reporting?

RCT- Randomised Controlled Trial
questions.solution:
The statistical technique that combines the data from multiple independent RCTs to arrive at a generalised conclusion is called a meta-analysis, and the set of guidelines followed here is PRISMA (Preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses).

Meta-analysis is a quantitative method to study the previous research studies of a selected topic/ research question. It uses statistical methods to summarise results, and its validity relies upon the quality of the studies used and reviewed.

Other options:
Option A: CONSORT (consolidated standards of reporting trials) are guidelines used for improving the reporting of the results of RCT.

Option C: MOOSE (Meta-analysis of observational studies in epidemiology) is a guideline for improving the reporting meta-analysis of observational studies.

Option D: STROBE (Strengthening the reporting of observational studies in epidemiology) is a guideline for improving the reporting of observational studies (cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies).

Guideline Expansion Area

TREND Transparent reporting of non-randomized designs Behavioural and public health interventions with non-randomized designs
STROBE  Strengthening the reporting of observational studies in epidemiology Cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies
STRAEGA Strengthening the reporting of genetic association studies Modification of STROBE for genetic studies
STARD Standards for the reporting of diagnostic accuracy studies Diagnostic tests
CARE Case reporting Clinical case reports and reports of patient encounters
SAMPL  Statistical analyses and methods in published literature Basic statistical reporting for articles published in biomedical journals
PRISMA Preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses Meta-analyses of randomised controlled trials
MOOSE Meta-analysis of observational studies in Epidemiology Meta-analyses of observational studies

Many of these guidelines are available via the EQUATOR network.

Related Pearl: Meta-analysis in Research

  • Meta-analysis is a set of statistical techniques for combining quantitative results from multiple studies to produce a summary of empirical knowledge on a given topic.
  • It refers to a method of systematic review.
  • It is one of the most relevant methods in evidence-based medicine and ranks high on the evidence pyramid.
  • Limitations
    • When testing is done before hypothesis generation, spurious results are found.
    • Sample size may be misrepresentative.
    • Publication bias due to suppression of some important information leading to file drawer effect.
    • Heterogeneity of studies may force mashing together of disparate effects and lead to selection bias. This is also called apples and oranges effect.
    • Dissimilarities in control groups.
    • Its validity is dependent on the quality of the systematic review and the original data used.

questions.text: A patient with chronic pain was prescribed a drug that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog. Mechanism of action is a combination of effects as mentioned below-

  • Weak agonist action on the mu-opioid receptor
  • Inhibition of serotonin reuptake transporter (moderate action) and norepinephrine reuptake transporter (weak action). 

It is used to induce analgesia for moderate pain and can be used as an adjunct to opioid therapy in chronic pain conditions. 

Other options: They do not affect serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

Option A: Hydromorphone is a phenanthrene drug with strong mu-opioid agonist action with a variable affinity for delta and kappa receptors. It is similar to morphine.  

Option C: Buprenorphine is also a phenanthrene derivative that has mixed opioid agonist-antagonist activity. It is a partial mu-agonist and has antagonist activity at delta and kappa receptors. While it can serve as an analgesic, it antagonizes the action of strong mu-agonists such as morphine. It is used to treat moderate pain and reduced cravings in patients recovering from alcoholism.

Option D: Hydrocodone is a phenanthrene drug with mild-moderate mu-opioid agonist action. It is less efficacious than morphine.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old tall girl is brought to a physician with complaints of severe headaches. Her BP was found to be 150/100 mm Hg. Her mother tells you that she has not started menstruating yet. On exam, she has bilateral palpable inguinal swellings. Her electrolyte panel is as follows. Which of the following is not a feature of her above condition?

Serum Na+ : 148 mEq/L

Serum K+ :    2.8 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female patient presenting with primary amenorrhea, bilateral inguinal swellings, hypertension, and hypokalemia is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency.  Deoxycorticosterone levels are elevated in this condition.

In a patient with primary amenorrhea, tall stature, and bilateral inguinal swellings suggestive of undescended testes, the likely diagnosis is a genotypically 46 XY individual with a female phenotype, a hallmark of 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. This disorder results from impaired production of glucocorticoids and androgens, leading to inadequate virilization and the development of a female external appearance despite a male genotype.

The enzyme deficiency causes a diversion of progesterone and pregnenolone into the aldosterone synthesis pathway, leading to excess production of 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC), a key marker for 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Elevated levels of mineralocorticoids, particularly DOC, result in hypertension, hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Ultrasound findings typically show undescended testes with a poorly developed uterus and a blind-ending vagina, consistent with this condition.

Management includes glucocorticoid therapy to correct the glucocorticoid deficiency and reduce mineralocorticoid excess. Additionally, sex hormone supplementation is necessary to address the lack of androgens and normalize electrolyte imbalances and hypertension.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents for a prenatal checkup at 10 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history includes a vaginal delivery at 39 weeks with a healthy baby girl, a spontaneous abortion at 8 weeks, twins delivered at 36 weeks via cesarean section, and delivery at 32 weeks where the baby required neonatal care but survived. What is her GTPAL score?
questions.solution:
The GTPAL score for this 36-year-old woman is G5 T1 P2 A1 L4.

  • Gravida (G) = 5: 5 total pregnancies.
  • Term (T) = 1: 1 pregnancy delivered at 37 weeks or later.
  • Preterm (P) = 2: 2 pregnancies delivered between 20-36 weeks+6 days.
  • Abortions (A) = 1: 1 spontaneous abortion.
  • Living (L) = 4: 4 living children (1 from a vaginal delivery, 2 from twins, and 1 from a preterm delivery).

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history of a pregnant woman.

GTPAL system is currently used -

  • G - Denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • T - Any delivery that happens at or beyond 37 weeks
  • P - Number of deliveries that happen between 20 to 36 weeks+6 days
  • A - Abortion - any pregnancy loss that occurs before 20 weeks. This includes induced abortions, spontaneous miscarriages, and ectopic or molar pregnancies
  • L - Living children at present

Note: Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and term/preterm.

questions.text: A person involved in a road traffic accident has a peculiar posture as given in the image below. Which of the following is associated with this posture?
questions.solution:
The described posture is seen in decorticate rigidity caused by lesions rostral to the midbrain.

There is flexion of the upper limbs at the elbow and extension of the lower limbs. Flexion is due to rubrospinal excitation of the muscles of the upper extremities.

 

Other options:

Option A- Extensor muscle hyperactivity becomes exaggerated if the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is damaged. This is called decerebellate rigidity.

Option B- In decerebrate rigidity, the lesion involves motor tracts caudal to the midbrain. Hence, all four limbs are extended in this condition.

Option C- Uncal herniation is associated with decerebrate posturing.

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a patient to evaluate the patency of fallopian tubes, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube, which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis: The leading presenting complaints include infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well.

Investigation:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography- If genital tuberculosis is suspected, it should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette-type of appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular-like outpouchings surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

3. Endometrial histology and PCR testing: Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The late premenstrual phase is the ideal time to schedule this procedure. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. PCR is a rapid, sensitive, and specific method of detecting mycobacterial DNA.

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

The image below shows the "pipe stem" or "lead pipe" appearance. There is an absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe-like appearance shows the fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

The image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

All the other options - N. gonorrhea, C. trachomatis, and Mycoplasma hominis are causative agents for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Acute PID presents with abdominal pain and tenderness where sonography is a primary imaging tool. Normal fallopian tubes are rarely imaged. Characteristic acute findings include: a distended, ovoid-shaped tube filled with anechoic or echogenic fluid, fallopian tube wall thickening, incomplete internal septa, and a "cogwheel" appearance when inflamed tubes are imaged in cross-section.

questions.text: A gardener presents with multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to cutaneous tissues. On microscopy of tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia are seen. Which of the following statements is false about this disease?

choices.text: Medlar bodies are seen in this condition
It is caused by a dimorphic fungus
Itraconazole will be effective in this case
It is an example of subcutaneous mycoses

questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on the hands and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.  In sporotrichosis, medlar bodies will not be seen. Medlar bodies or sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection caused by many species. In tissue, the lesions appear as spherical brown cells termed muriform or sclerotic bodies that divide by transverse septation.

S. schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. It occurs in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. The septate hyphae appear very thin and carry flower-like clusters of small conidia borne on delicate sterigmata. Asteroid bodies seen in sporotrichosis consist of a central basophilic yeast cell surrounded by radiating extensions of eosinophilic material.

Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S. schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. The initial lesion appears following a trauma or thorn prick. The infection then spreads via the lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes. This results in secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes.

Treatment: 

  • Cutaneous form can be treated with oral or topical potassium iodide
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole is effective in over 90% of patients with lymphocutaneous infection
  • For disseminated infection, amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

questions.text: According to National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment which of the following is correct about the reach in approach?

choices.text: Total number of surgeries should not exceed 50 per day
Recommended surgery is SICS with ACIOL
Emphasis is to shift from reach in to reach out
Anesthesiologist is not needed for this approach

questions.solution:
The correct statement about "reach in"  approach as per NPCBVI  is that Total number of surgeries should not exceed 50 per day

The Base Hospital approach, also known as the reach-in approach, and the Peripheral Eye Camp approach, also known as the reach-out approach, are two community-oriented strategies implemented within the framework of the National Programme for the Control of Blindness. These techniques aim to address the existing backlog of cataract-related blindness.

Based on recent developments, there is a shift in emphasis from the 'Reach-out' approach to the 'Reach-in' approach. The Reach-in Approach focuses on organizing screening camps in rural and remote areas without access to eye care institutions. Comprehensive eye care, including refraction, is provided, and cataract surgery patients are referred to nearby hospitals with the necessary resources, following the base hospital strategy. Ocular surgeries must adhere to the Government of India's guidelines.

  • It is imperative to have at least one anesthesiologist who is well prepared to address typical crises to ensure patient safety and optimal care.
  • It is recommended that a minimum of one, ideally two, operating surgeons be present, with each surgeon limiting their daily caseload to no more than 30 procedures.
  • Currently, the preferred approach for cataract extraction is extracapsular surgery, with a preference for manual small incision cataract surgery (SICS) or phacoemulsification, together with the implantation of a posterior chamber intraocular lens.
  • It is ideal to limit the number of surgical procedures conducted in a day to no more than 50.
  • Simultaneous surgery on both eyes should be avoided. 
  • Patients who have a high surgical risk due to conditions such as severe diabetes, severe hypertension, and cardiac issues should not undergo surgery in camp settings. Cases related to such issues should be appropriately referred to the base hospitals. 

Other options:

Option B: Recommended surgeries done are either SICS or phacoemulsification with implantation of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) not ACIOL.

Option C: Emphasis is to shift from 'Reach-out' approach to the 'Reach-in' approach not vice versa.

Option D: At least one anesthesiologist is needed.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of dermatomyositis, except:
questions.solution:
Salmon rash is not a dermatological manifestation of Dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle. The following are various manifestations of Dermatomyositis:

A. Pathognomonic manifestations

  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules

B. Characteristic manifestations

  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms(Shawl distribution)
  • Heliotrope rash: Purplish color rash, often itchy, associated with swelling around the eye.
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

C. Compatible manifestations

  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

D. Less common Manifestations

  • Facial swelling
  • Malignancy
  • Erythroderma
  • Lichen planus

The salmon rash is seen in guttate psoriasis and still's disease.

Picture of the patient with still's disease showing salmon rash on her face and trunk:

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A dead body was found in a muddy field. The suspect's house was searched and the following evidence was obtained. Which principle is involved in the study of this evidence?
questions.solution:
The principle involved here is Locard's exchange principle, and the true statement about this principle is two objects coming in contact always transfer material.

Locard's exchange principle states that when two objects, biological or non-biological, come in contact with each other, some material is transferred from one object to the other. This means that there will be some traces of objects left on the crime scene (as the footprint), and the criminal will also take a trace of the crime scene at the same time (e.g., muddy shoes as in this case). This exchange does not necessarily apply to crime scenes alone.

These fingerprints, footprints, hair, cloth fibre, broken glass, tool marks, paint, blood stains, and seminal stains are considered actual evidence, and their presence is absolute proof of crime.

Other options: 

Option A- Alec Jeffrey developed the study of DNA fingerprinting.

Option B- Galton systemized fingerprinting and proposed Galton's system.

Option C- Tsuchihashi developed cheiloscopy.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl presented with ascending left-sided flank pain during micturition and recurrent episodes of urinary tract infections. The urologist suspects vesicoureteric reflux. Which of the following investigations can be done to confirm this condition?

DMSA: Dimercapto succinic acid
questions.solution:
A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) can be done to confirm vesicoureteric reflux.

Vesicoureteric reflux is the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder back to the ureter and kidney. The condition is usually congenital and familial. It is more commonly seen in females during evaluation for a urinary tract infection. It predisposes the child to pyelonephritis resulting in renal injury or scarring. This is known as reflux-related renal injury or reflux nephropathy.

The international reflux study (IRS) classification divides it into grades I-V based on the severity as shown below. This is based on the appearance seen in contrast voiding cystourethrogram.

Recurrent urinary tract infections are commonly seen in cases with grade III or IV vesicoureteric reflux. The condition is diagnosed by a voiding cystourethrogram. This is done by catheterization of the bladder followed by instillation of an iodinated contrast. Vesicoureteric reflux done during voiding is known as high-pressure vesicoureteric reflux. A low-dose radiation contrast VCUG provides anatomic information such as a duplex collecting system, ectopic ureter, and bladder diverticulum.

The image below shows dilated ureters seen in a case of vesicoureteric reflux.

Antibiotic prophylaxis and behavioral modification can be used for management. Surgical correction can be done laparoscopically or by the endoscopic route. It should be considered in cases of recurrent acute pyelonephritis despite antibiotic therapy and in the presence of surgically correctable malformations.

Other options:

Option A: A DMSA scan can be done to assess the degree of renal scarring.

Options B and D: An ultrasound and MRI are not required to diagnose vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

  • Usually affects the middle-aged

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of recurrent episodes of bloody stool. The following investigation is performed, and the child was found to have Meckel diverticulum. Which of the following radionuclide agents is used for this investigation?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of  99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy, which is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticulum in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but can present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Radionuclide like the 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum.

 Other uses of 99mTc-pertechnetate:

  • Thyroid imaging
  • Parathyroid imaging to distinguish it from the thyroid gland
  • Testicular imaging

questions.text: A drug having a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally thrice daily. How much time will be taken for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, so it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is completely eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

A graph is plotted between plasma drug concentration and time as shown below. The given graph depicts the plateau principle of drug accumulation on repeated oral dosing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has sudden, rapidly progressing pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision in his left eye. He often wrestles in the mud with friends. Examination reveals a superficial corneal ulcer with a wreath-shaped grey-white infiltrate and an undermined necrotic edge. Which organism is likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of a corneal ulcer caused by Nocardia.

A bacterial corneal ulcer caused by the gram-positive filamentous bacteria Nocardia is usually seen following trauma or after soil contamination. The ulcer is characteristically superficial, with a wreath pattern and an undermined necrotic edge, with the base having a cracked windshield appearance. Nocardia keratitis often clinically resembles a fungal corneal ulcer, with a filamentous-appearing border and satellite lesions as shown below. 

Other options:

Option A: The corneal ulcer caused by the actinomyces appears dry and necrotic and is surrounded by a yellow demarcating gutter. Ring abscesses can also be found here. Inflammation can be severe, with iritis and a hypopyon. It is usually a part of mixed infection with other organisms.

Option C: Pneumococcus typically causes hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens). The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer near the centre of the cornea. The ulcer tends to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion.

Option D: Pseudomonas causes an irregular sharp ulcer with thick greenish mucopurulent exudate with diffuse liquefactive necrosis. It is a frequent cause of contact lens–associated keratitis.

questions.text: At the post-transplant follow-up clinic, a patient who is on an immunomodulator presents with alopecia, diarrhoea, new onset tremors, and insomnia. What would be the likely drug he has been prescribed?
questions.solution:
Among the options, Tacrolimus has a relatively more predisposition to cause alopecia, gastrointestinal discomfort and neurotoxicity (in the form of tremors and insomnia).

Neurotoxicity, although seen in both cyclosporine and tacrolimus, the presence of alopecia(which is unique to tacrolimus) along with it - points it more towards tacrolimus rather than cyclosporine(which has hirsutism instead of alopecia)

Cyclosporine and tacrolimus act by inhibiting calcineurin. Tacrolimus blocks FKBP 12. This immunophilin ultimately inhibits calcineurin phosphatase and exerts its actions. Cyclosporine is an immunomodulatory drug that inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein in target cells, forming a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex.

The following would be a comparison of the likelihood of the development of adverse effects among the two drugs:

More common with Tacrolimus  

 More common with Cyclosporine
  • Neurotoxicity including tremors, paresthesia and insomnia
  • Alopecia
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and other gastrointestinal symptoms
  • New onset diabetes mellitus
  • Hypercholesterolemia (especially LDL)
  • Hypertension
  • Hirsutism
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gum hyperplasia

 

Mycophenolate mofetil main side effects include gastrointestinal issues, leukopenia, and pure red cell aplasia. It also increases the risk of infections, especially cytomegalovirus and BK virus-related nephritis, and can cause congenital defects and miscarriage during pregnancy.

The primary side effect of azathioprine is bone marrow suppression, which can lead to leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, or anemia. Other notable adverse effects include increased vulnerability to infections like varicella and herpes simplex, liver damage, alopecia, gastrointestinal issues, pancreatitis, and a higher risk of cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of events in the Moro reflex?

choices.text: Extension and adduction of the arms → Flexion of the arms → Audible cry
Adduction of the arms → Flexion of the arms → Audible cry
Extension and abduction of the arms → Flexion of the arms → Audible cry
Adduction of the arms → Flexion of the arms → Extension of the arms → Audible cry

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events in the Moro reflex is Extension and abduction of the arms → Flexion of the arms → Audible cry.

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backwards onto the examiner's hand. In response to this, the fingers and upper extremities are initially extended and abducted. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth.

questions.text: Ferroptosis and pyroptosis are mediated respectively by?
questions.solution:
Ferroptosis and pyroptosis are mediated by lipid peroxidation and caspase activation respectively.

Ferroptosis is a pathway of cell death induced by membrane lipid peroxidation. It is induced by high intracellular levels of iron or reactive oxygen species and can be prevented by reducing iron levels. The most prominent features of ferroptosis are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and disrupted outer mitochondrial membrane.

Ferroptosis has been linked to cell death in a variety of human pathologies including cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and stroke.

Pyroptosis is the mode of death in cells infected by microbes. It is a form of apoptosis and occurs in the following sequence:

  1. Activation of the inflammasome complex
  2. Activation of caspase-1(interleukin-1β converting enzyme).
  3. Generation of IL-1 results in fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

  • There is cellular swelling
  • There is a loss of membrane integrity 
  • It is associated with inflammation
  •  Caspases 1, 4, and 5 are involved

Necroptosis is triggered by the ligation of TNFR1 and by proteins present in RNA and DNA viruses. Necroptosis is caspase-independent and depends on the RIPK1 and RIPK3 complex. RIPK1–RIPK3 signaling leads to the phosphorylation of MLKL, which then forms pores in the plasma membrane.it is also called programmed necrosis.

questions.text:
A primi mother gave birth to a newborn by normal vaginal delivery. You are posted in the NCC, and about to administer the birth dose of a particular vaccine in the anterolateral thigh. In which zone of the following device will the vaccine be placed?

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards the administration of the birth dose of the hepatitis B vaccine in the anterolateral thigh. It is placed in the upper portion of the ILR (Ice line refrigerator) - zone 1.

ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like cholera, hep B, rotavirus (liquid), etc while the lower zone is for heat-sensitive vaccines like OPV, measles, etc.

All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. Vaccines like DPT, TT, hepatitis B, IPV, pentavalent vaccines, and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket, while vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket.

questions.text: A young patient comes to the emergency with pain in the right leg after falling from a height. The radiological image shows a physeal injury fracture extending to epiphysis. What is the type of Salter-Harris physeal injury mentioned above?
questions.solution:
The type of Salter-Harris injury mentioned above is type III injury.

Type II fracture is an intraarticular fracture. In a type III Salter harris fracture, the fracture splits the epiphysis and divides transversely to the other side through the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This damages the growth plate and results in growth disturbance. 

The fracture lower end of the tibia is an example of a Salter-Harris type 3 fracture.

Salter-Harris type III fracture needs an accurate reduction to restore the joint surface.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female patient presents to you with complaints of greenish nipple discharge for the past few months. Examination reveals the presence of discharge from multiple ducts with para-areolar lump and advised for mammography. Which of the following mammography findings, you would expect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of duct ectasia and mammogram of a patient with duct ectasia shows typical Broken-needle type of calcification.  This is due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation.

Other options:

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

questions.text: The body of a woman found in a water body was brought for autopsy. There is frothing at the mouth, the hand is clenched with soil and weeds, and bloodstained froth is present in the lungs. The Gettler test reveals that the chloride content is 30 mg% lower on the left side of the heart compared to the right. With the above case scenario, which option best describes the drowning?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario shows the features of antemortem drowning in freshwater.

Frothing and cadaveric spasm are suggestive of antemortem drowning. The Gettler test findings are consistent with freshwater drowning.

Gettler test - Normally, the chloride content is 600 mg% on either side of the heart. A difference of more than 25 mg% between the right and the left sides is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.

Freshwater drowning - The chloride content is lower on the left side of the heart due to dilution by freshwater.

Saltwater drowning- The chloride content is higher on the left side of the heart due to the entry of saltwater and hemoconcentration.

Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.


Options A, C, and D are not correct as the case does not show the findings of postmortem or saltwater drowning.

questions.text:
Which of the following substances inhibit oxidative phosphorylation in the electron transport chain?
  1. Atractyloside
  2. Arsenite
  3. 2,4-dinitrophenol
  4. Thermogenin
  5. Flouroacetate
questions.solution:
Atractyloside, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and Thermogenin inhibit oxidative phosphorylation in the electron transport chain.

Thermogenin and 2-4-dinitrophenol are uncouplers. Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions, thereby collapsing the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. 2, 4 dinitrophenol is a synthetic uncoupler. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in newborns.

Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transport of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondria.

Oligomycin blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by stopping the flow of protons through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

questions.text: You conduct a study to determine the association between computer use and visual impairment and get a correlation coefficient of +0.4. Which of the following scattergrams best represents your findings?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario having a correlation coefficient of +0.4 shows a positive weak correlation and the scattergram that best represents this finding is graph number 2.

Correlation is used to assess the strength and direction of the association between two variables (such as smoking and lung cancer). The correlation coefficient (denoted by r) is represented by a plus or minus sign, followed by a number (Example: -0.88). The correlation coefficient ranges from -1 to +1.

The numerical indicates the strength of correlation:

  • Correlation coefficients greater than ± 0.5 are considered strong and are likely to establish (if positive correlation) or disprove (if negative correlation) the association between two factors.
  • Correlation coefficients between 0 and ± 0.5 are regarded as weak.

The sign indicates the direction of the correlation.

  • Plus sign (+) suggests that both the variables being studied are positively correlated. This means that the high value of one variable is associated with a high value in another. An example is an association between salt intake and blood pressure readings.
  • Minus sign (-) suggests that both the variables being studied are negatively correlated. A high value of one variable such as cigarette consumption is associated with a low value of another variable such as life expectancy.

The relationship between two correlated variables can be represented graphically in the form of a scattergram. Each point represents one observation including both the variables and so would be equal to the sample size.

The following image shows the scattergram plotted for different values of the correlation coefficient:

To combine correlations of two or more samples, averaging methods can be used. It is recommended only when several different samples are independently drawn from the same population and the interest is in aggregating those values.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: You are monitoring a 45-year-old female patient in the postoperative ward. Her 24-hour urine output is 1.5 mL/min, serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and urine creatinine is 60 mg/dL. What is the patient's creatinine clearance rate?
questions.solution:
The creatinine clearance in this patient is 90 mL/min.

Creatinine clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which creatinine is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

 UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine (mg/dL)

PCr - Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

V - Urine volume (mL/min)

Note: The creatinine clearance is usually expressed in mL/min; hence, the preferred unit of urine volume is mL/min, which is calculated based on the 24-hour urine volume. While calculating, ensure that both the urine creatinine and serum creatinine have the same units (either mg/dL or mg/mL).

In the given question,

UCr = 60 mg/dL

PCr = 1.0 mg/dL

V  = 1.5 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

Creatinine clearance =  UCr × V ⁄ PCr ,

= (60 x 1.5)/1

= 60 x 1.5

= 90 mL/min

Creatinine is a by-product of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body fluids almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their usual joint predilection.
Condition Joint
 1. Rheumatoid arthritis a. Distal interphalangeal joint
2. Osteoarthritis b. Metacarpophalangeal joint
3. Systemic lupus erythematosus c. Proximal interphalangeal joint
4. Psoriatic arthritis d. First carpometacarpal joint
questions.solution:
The correct combination of conditions with their usual joint predilection is 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a.

Condition Joint
Rheumatoid arthritis Metacarpophalangeal joint
Osteoarthritis First carpometacarpal joint
Systemic lupus erythematosus Proximal interphalangeal joint
Psoriatic arthritis Distal interphalangeal joint

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Being a systemic disease, RA also causes various extraarticular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities. Testing for serum antibodies to anti-citrullinated protein antibodies and rheumatoid factor can help in the quick diagnosis and management of suspected RA.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most common type of arthritis, mainly affecting the hip, knee, and first metatarsal phalangeal, first carpometacarpal, and distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. The incidence of OA is very high in the elderly and more common in women. It is diagnosed based on structural abnormalities, like cartilage loss (seen as joint space loss on X-ray) and osteophytes, which occur due to failure of joint protective mechanisms.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease characterized by autoantibody- and immune complex-mediated tissue destruction. It is a multisystem disease, resulting in musculoskeletal, cutaneous, renal, hematologic, cardiopulmonary, and neurologic symptoms and signs. Diagnostically, the most important autoantibodies are antinuclear antibodies because they are positive in >95% of patients.

Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory type of arthritis mainly affecting the distal interphalangeal joints. In most cases, psoriasis precedes arthritis. Other features include nail changes (pitting, horizontal ridging, onycholysis, yellowish discoloration, hyperkeratosis), dactylitis, enthesitis, and tenosynovitis. The Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria are a useful tool for early diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man underwent a routine colonoscopy, during which an incidental finding was noted. What classification is used for the lesion shown in the image?
questions.solution:
A polyp with a small stalk is visible in the given colonoscopy image for which Haggitt classification is used.

Haggitt’s classification helps measure the extent of cancerous cell invasion into pedunculated colorectal polyps.

All sessile polyps come under level 4.

Other options:

Option A: Spigelman classification is done for duodenal polyposis in Familial Adenomatous Polyposis(FAP). This is used to classify patients for direct surveillance and treatment. Parameters are the number and size of polyps, histology, and degree of dysplasia.

Option B: Park classification is used to classify Fistula-in-ano. It can be classified as:

questions.text: Which wave of JVP corresponds to point D in the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Point D in the given left ventricular pressure-volume loop corresponds to the V wave of JVP.

The V wave is produced by atrial filling during diastole. It is preceded by the second heart sound caused by the closure of the semilunar valves and point D in the pressure-volume loop represents the closure of the aortic valve thus point D corresponds to the V wave of JVP. 

Jugular venous pressure (JVP) is measured in the right internal jugular vein. It is a reflection of changes in the central venous pressure or right atrial pressure. The JVP waveform has three waves (a, c, and v) and two descents (x and y) and appears as follows:

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

Related Pearl: Cardiac pressure - volume loop

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure(Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

Phase I: Period of filling (between A and B)

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction (between B and C)

Phase III: Period of ejection (between C and D)

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation (between D and A)

where,

  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, naked granuloma can be seen on lymph node biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Stellate granulomas are granulomas containing central granular debris and neutrophils. They are characteristically seen in cat-scratch disease caused by B. henselae.

The image below shows stellate granuloma

 

Option B: Foreign body granulomas are incited by relatively inert foreign bodies, such as talc, sutures. Epithelioid cells and giant cells are apposed to the surface of the foreign body. The foreign material can usually be identified in the center of the granuloma.

The given image shows suture granuloma. The suture material is surrounded by lymphocytic infiltration

Option C: Durck granulomas are seen in cerebral malaria.

The image below shows a Durck granuloma

questions.text: A 10-month-old female baby with an abdominal mass is diagnosed with Wilm's tumor. On examination, the following findings are seen in the baby. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given images  show macroglossia and omphalocele which when considered with the Wilm's tumor points to the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting.The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) called WT2 locus , distal to the WT1 locus. It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, and tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

The below image shows macroglossia seen in a baby diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Other options-

Option A: WAGR is a contiguous gene syndrome that is characterized by Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation.

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis. It is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angioma of the face, choroid, and leptomeninges. In the facial territory of the trigeminal nerve capillary, a vascular malformation called port-wine stain or nevus flammeus is usually seen. 

Option C: Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

questions.text: You are a second-year surgical resident assisting in a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The operating surgeon asks you to point the camera at the R4U line and asks you about its clinical significance. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this line?

choices.text: It acts as a reference point in identifying the location of common hepatic duct
Common bile duct injury can be minimized by maintaining dissection ventral to this line
The R4U line serves as an important landmark point in gastric resection surgeries
It helps in the intra-operative staging of gallbladder carcinoma

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B as common bile duct injury can be minimized by maintaining the dissection ventral to the R4U line during laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

R4U line is an imaginary line drawn from Rouvière’s sulcus along the base of segment IV of the liver to the umbilical fissure. The area cephalad to the R4U line is considered a safe zone and caudal to it is a danger zone.

The cystic duct and the cystic artery lie ventral (anterosuperior) to the line and the common bile duct lies below (posteroinferior) to the line. It has been increasingly recognized as a useful anatomical landmark during hepatic resection (option C) and in laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It also acts as a reference point in identifying the location of common bile duct. (option A)

Rouvière’s sulcus is a minor fissure of the liver, also called as fissure of Gans or incisura hepatis dextra. It lies on the undersurface of the right lobe of the liver posterior to the gallbladder fossa and anterior to Couinaud segment I of the liver. It overlies the division of the right posterior (lateral) portal pedicle.

questions.text: A 48-year-old IT worker with a BMI of 31kg/m2  presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the lower back associated with swelling. On examination, you find an abscess over the natal cleft. Treatment was initiated but patient failed to respond. What is the next step in the management of this patient.?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful swelling over the natal cleft is suggestive of a pilonidal sinus. Given that the abscess is refractory to initial treatment, the next appropriate step is drainage through a lateral incision.

Pilonidal sinus disease is commonly seen in the natal cleft, more in men, usually after puberty. Drivers and hairdressers are more commonly affected.

It occurs due to buttock friction and shearing forces in this area allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can also form and are lined with granulation tissue and discharge. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine.
  • A foreign-body-type reaction may then lead to the formation of an abscess.
  • Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.

Management:

  • Conservative management includes strict hygiene measures and regular shaving of hair in the affected area.
  • For abscesses, rest, warm baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are recommended.
  • If the abscess is refractory to conservative treatment, drainage with a lateral incision, followed by thorough curettage of granulation tissue and removal of hair, is advised.
  • For chronic pilonidal disease, surgical options include the rhomboid flap (Limberg flap), Bascom’s procedure, Karydakis procedure, Z-plasty, and V-Y advancement flap.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby boy had recurrent episodes of bacterial infection. There is also a history of bloody diarrhoea and eczema during the first month of life. Peripheral smear showed abnormally small-sized platelets. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome.

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia and small-sized platelets. Patients often present in infancy with bruising, bloody diarrhea, eczema, and susceptibility to recurrent infections. It occurs due to mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23 that encodes Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

Along with microthrombocytopenia, peripheral smear shows loss of T lymphocytes. Patients are also unable to produce antibodies to antigens, thereby making them immunocompromised. As a result, there is also an increased risk of autoimmune disorders and cancers like B-cell lymphomas.

Splenectomy improves platelet counts in these patients since increased platelet destruction in the spleen is prevented. However, the only definitive treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Other options:

Option A: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition due to a defect in IIb/IIIa leading to defective platelet aggregation.

Option B: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is a condition characterized by low platelet count due to autoantibody-mediated destruction. Patients present with easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and bleeding into the skin and soft tissues. Laboratory findings typically show isolated thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition occurring due to defective adhesion of platelets to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. It is due to a deficiency of the glycoprotein complex Ib–IX on the platelet membrane. Patients often present with bleeding tendencies.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby with a congenital inguinal hernia was posted for herniotomy. Inhalational induction was performed using the circuit as shown in the image below. Identify the circuit.
questions.solution:
The image given shows Jackson Rees or Mapleson F circuit. It is most commonly used for paediatric patients.

Points of identification include:

  • Fresh gas flow near the patient’s end
  • Presence of corrugated tubing
  • Absence of APL valve
  • Reservoir bag with relief system/ open tail away from the patient end

Mapleson breathing systems include circuits from A to F, which are classified based on the position of fresh gas flow, APL valve, reservoir bag and corrugated tubing. They can be subclassified into 3 functional groups:

  • Mapleson B and C
  • T piece group which includes Mapleson D, E and F – Best for controlled ventilation

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents to the medicine OPD with cough and hemoptysis. The sputum culture done on the culture media is shown below. What is the usual method of sterilization used for this medium?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Lowenstein-Jensen medium. The medium is sterilized by inspissation.

Inspissation is used for the sterilization of heat-labile culture media containing eggs or serum. This method of sterilization involves heating at 80–85 °C for 30 minutes on 3 consecutive days. Another medium for which this method is used is Loeffler's serum.

Lowenstein–Jensen medium is commonly used, egg-based, selective culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Other Options:

Option B: Pasteurization - Milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes (the holder method) or at 72°C for 15–20 seconds (the flash process), followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower. 

Option C: Autoclaving is a method of sterilization by moist heat.

Option D: Hot air oven is a method of sterilization by dry heat.

Moist heat causes coagulation and denaturation of proteins, while dry heat causes oxidation and charring of proteins. Hence not preferred for egg-containing culture media like the Lowenstein-Jensen medium.

questions.text: A patient is being administered IV aztreonam for a nosocomial infection. Which of the following β-lactam antibiotics does not show cross-allergy with aztreonam and can be safely administered?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Ceftaroline does not show cross-allergy with aztreonam and can be safely administered in this patient.

Monobactams are β-lactams with a single fused β-lactam ring and no thiazolidine or dihydrothiazidine ring. Aztreonam is the sole therapeutic member of this class. Aztreonam is generally safe for penicillin-allergic patients as there is no allergic cross-reactivity with beta-lactam antibiotics, except ceftazidime, ceftolozane, and cefiderocol as they have comparable or identical side chains to aztreonam. (other options).

Aztreonam has activity only against gram-negative bacteria. it has no activity against gram-positive bacteria and anaerobic organisms. therefore, Aztreonam is useful for treating gram-negative infections among patients with severe hypersensitivity reactions to other β-lactam classes. other uses include the treatment of Metallo-β-lactamase–producing organisms and pseudomonas-associated pulmonary exacerbations in patients with cystic fibrosis.

Aztreonam is generally well tolerated; however, hepatotoxicity may occur, particularly in infants and young children.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presenting with photophobia, sweating,  joint pains, and puffy, painful, pinkish hands and feet, is suspected to have pink disease caused due to a chronic metal poisoning. Which of the following is not associated with the poisoning by this metal?
questions.solution:
Pink disease is seen in chronic mercury poisoning. Aldrich mees lines are characteristic of chronic arsenic poisoning, not mercury.

Pink disease or acrodynia occurs due to an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction resulting from chronic exposure to mercury and is seen particularly in children. The onset is insidious with anorexia, sweating, skin rash, insomnia, and photophobia. Hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated joint pain, paresthesia, shedding of teeth, and skin peeling are also seen.

Other eponymous features associated with mercury poisoning:

  • Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.
  • Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury. The industrial discharges of mercury into Minamata Bay in Japan became biomethylated to form methyl mercury, which then accumulated in fish. On consumption of these fishes, people developed visual deficits and several neurological manifestations such as loss of sensation, gait, memory, cognition, etc.
  • Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

The image below shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning.

questions.text: A professional violin player presents with well-defined plaques on his neck with comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The lesion consistent with the given clinical history is acne mechanica, which is also known as fiddler's neck.

Acne mechanica describes acne that occurs at the site of repeated mechanical trauma and/or frictional obstruction of the pilosebaceous outlet resulting in comedone formation. Examples include fiddler’s neck, which may occur on the neck of violin players, and is characterized by well‐defined plaques with the presence of comedones, lichenification, and pigmentation.

Other Options:

Option B: Acne fulminans or acne maligna is a rare and severe destructive form of acne presenting primarily in adolescent males. It most frequently affects the trunk but can affect the face and presents acutely in association with systemic symptoms.

Option C: Acne conglobata represents a rare and severe form of acne characterized by multiple and extensive inflammatory papules, tender nodules, and abscesses that commonly coalesce to form malodorous draining sinus tracts.

Option D: Acne excoriee is regarded as a self‐inflicted skin condition in which the sufferer compulsively picks real or imagined acne lesions predominantly on the face. It is predominantly seen in adolescent girls. 

Other psychiatric disorders associated with acne are

  • A small number of patients with body dysmorphic disorder have acne as their prime symptom. The perceived acne is out of proportion to physical signs.
  • Acne has been reported in anorexia nervosa. Acne itself may be a predisposing factor for anorexia in vulnerable teenage age groups who adopt a diet in an attempt to control their acne.
