questions.text:
In patients with coronary artery disease, there can be a worsening of angina due to marked vasodilation of the coronary arteries. Among the given options, which intravenous agents can be implicated in this phenomenon?
  1. Nitroprusside
  2. Nitroglycerine
  3. Adenosine
  4. Isoflurane
  5. Dipyridamole
questions.solution:
Nitroprusside, Adenosine and Dipyridamole are the intravenous agents that can result in coronary steal phenomenon.  

The coronary steal phenomenon occurs in patients with partial coronary artery obstruction, where ischemia develops in the affected myocardial region. In the absence of drugs, the arterioles in the ischemic area are typically maximally dilated as a compensatory mechanism to improve blood flow. However, when a nonselective arteriolar dilator is administered, such as adenosine, dipyridamole, or nitroprusside, it dilates the vessels in the normal, healthy myocardium but has little effect on the already maximally dilated vessels in the ischemic region. As a result, blood flow is redirected away from the ischemic area toward the normal myocardium.

This phenomenon worsens the perfusion of the ischemic myocardium. The dilated arterioles in the healthy myocardium, which are relatively constricted compared to those in the ischemic region, become more dilated under the influence of the vasodilators. Consequently, blood flow is redistributed, with more blood being delivered to the normal myocardium, further compromising the already reduced perfusion in the ischemic area. This process is known as the "steal phenomenon."

Nitroglycerine causes NO-mediated vasodilation of large vessels preferentially, thus causing preload reduction without any steal phenomenon.

Isoflurane, which is administered via the inhalational route, does not cause coronary steal or myocardial ischemia, as long as coronary perfusion pressure is maintained.

Note: The reverse steal phenomenon (or Robin Hood phenomenon) is seen with beta-blockers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with gestational age 39 weeks and a single fetus in a cephalic lie has presented to the ER with pain in her lower abdomen radiating to her back and thighs. She experiences pain every 30 minutes. On doing per vaginal examination you find that the cervix is 2 cm dilated. After 20 hours you find no change in the cervical dilation. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case of a primigravida female with the gestational age of 39 weeks with an initial 2 cm cervical dilatation and the same dilatation even after 20 hours is suggestive of a prolonged latent phase of labor.

The first stage of labor is divided into the latent and active phases. The latent phase is defined as the period of cervical dilation up to 4 cm. If the latent phase exceeds 20 hours in a primigravida or 14 hours in a multigravida, it is termed a prolonged latent phase. It is not an indication of a C-section.

  Normal latent phase Prolonged latent phase
Primigravida 10-12 hours >20 hours
Multigravida 6-8 hours >14 hours

Causes of a prolonged latent phase include:

  • An unripe cervix
  • Malposition or malpresentation of the fetus
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Induction of labor
  • Early use of regional anaesthesia

Expectant management is typically recommended, as a prolonged latent phase does not cause distress to the mother or fetus. If necessary, labor can be augmented using oxytocin to facilitate progress.

Other options:

Option A: Arrest of active stage is when the cervix has not dilated despite more than 4 hours of adequate contractions or more than 6 hours of inadequate contractions after 6 cms of dilation. It is diagnosed by plateau on partograph. This is an indication of C-section.

Option C: Since cervical dilatation is the same for more than 20 hours. It is unlikely to be a normal labour.

Option D: The protracted active phase of labor refers to a slower-than-expected rate of cervical dilation during the active phase. It is defined when the rate of cervical dilation is <1.2cm/hr for primipara and <1.5cm/hr for multipara. It indicates inadequate contractions or other causes of ineffective labor progression like malpresentations, or cephalopelvic disproportion.

questions.text: A 1-month-old male infant is brought to the OPD with vomiting. History suggests a usage of maternal erythromycin. A USG abdomen was done and is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the USG showing cervix sign and nipple sign is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS).

CHPS is associated with hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus resulting in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. It is common between 3-6 weeks of age. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Maternal intake of macrolide antibiotics during pregnancy has been associated with an increased risk of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) in infants.

Infants usually present with projectile, non-bilious vomiting. Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. The characteristic metabolic abnormality is hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. The following findings may be seen:

  • The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm
  • The nipple sign is produced by the double-layered hypertrophic mucosa that protrudes into the stomach 
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is therefore called the cervix sign.

questions.text: A female presents to the emergency room with a 15-day history of fatigue, bleeding gums, and menorrhagia. Investigations show pancytopenia on CBC, prolonged PT, and aPTT with low levels of fibrinogen. The peripheral blood smear shows myeloblasts with numerous Auer rods. Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The given patient with symptoms of bleeding tendencies with pancytopenia, a deranged coagulation profile along Auer rods on peripheral smear suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation associated with Acute promyelocytic leukemia which is treated by All trans-retinoic acid (ATRA/ Tretinoin).

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML/APL) is associated with a reciprocal translocation t(15;17) producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. Clinically, the patients present with symptoms resulting from pancytopenia. There is generalized fatigue, bone pain, bleeding tendencies, and an increased risk of recurrent infections. These patients land up in disseminated intravascular coagulation(DIC) very often.

Bone marrow/ peripheral smear shows numerous granulocytic promyelocytes. Auer rods are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes. Multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell is called a faggot cell.

The image shows faggot cells below.

Other options:

Option A: Anthracycline and cytarabine are given in all types of AML other than acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)/(AML-M3)in which ATRA is the preferred drug, the regimen consists of cytarabine administered as a continuous intravenous infusion for 7 days, and daunorubicin administered intravenously on days 1, 2, and 3. This is known as the 7 + 3 regimen. 

Option C: Imatinib is a first-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI). it is used in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

Option D: Vincristine and prednisolone are used during the induction phase of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).

questions.text:
A woman presents with difficulty in breathing and right-sided chest pain that worsens on deep breathing. An X-ray revealed a right-sided pleural effusion. An intercostal drain was inserted and the analysis of the fluid sample revealed the following results. Which of the following is a possible cause for pleural effusion in this patient?
  • Serum protein - 7 g/dL
  • Pleural fluid protein - 3 g/dL
  • Serum LDH - 140 U/L
  • Pleural fluid LDH - 75 U/L
questions.solution:
The given pleural fluid parameters do not satisfy Light's criteria, indicating a transudate pleural effusion. Hence, myxedema is the most likely etiology for the pleural effusion in this patient.

  • Pleural fluid/serum protein ratio = 3/7 = 0.429 (<0.5)
  • Pleural fluid/serum LDH = 75/140=0.536 (<0.6)
  • Pleural LDH = 75 (<⅔*140= 93)

Light's criteria for the diagnosis of exudative pleural effusion require the fulfillment of at least one of the following criteria-

  1. PE protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
  2. PE LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  3. PE LDH > 2/3rds the upper limit of the reference range of serum LDH

Other options:

SLE, sarcoidosis, and pancreatitis result in exudative pleural effusion by disrupting the integrity of pulmonary parenchyma/interstitium/vasculature or pleura.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a painless beefy-red ulcer on the labia that bleeds when touched. There is no lymphadenopathy. Microscopic findings are shown below. What is the first-line management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy, with microscopy showing Donovan bodies points to a diagnosis of granuloma inguinale. It is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, also known as Klebsiella granulomatis. First line treatment is azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily.

The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days.

Four types of lesions have been described in this condition:

  • Ulcerogranulomatous - most common type with painless beefy red ulcers. They are also highly vascular and bleed on touch.
  • Hypertrophic - usually with a raised irregular edge
  • Necrotic - offensive smelling ulcer that causes tissue destruction
  • Sclerotic or cicatricial - with fibrous or scar tissue

The image below shows a beefy-red ulcer characteristic of donovanosis.

Primary lesions can occur on genital and extragenital sites. Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change.

Prolonged treatment with antibiotics is generally advised for donovanosis, usually for a minimum period of 6 weeks.

Treatment ladder for Donovanosis:

  • First line
    • Azithromycin 1 g orally on the first day followed by 500 mg daily
  • Second line
    • Doxycycline 100 mg orally on the first day followed by 100 mg twice daily, (or) 
    • Co‐trimoxazole 960 mg twice daily

  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He gave a history of a similar episode before, but his vision was quickly restored. The fundus image is shown below.  What is the cause for this characteristic fundus picture in this patient?

choices.text: Proliferation of blood vessels at the retina
The fovea centralis is extremely thin
Collection of fluid in the outer plexiform layer
Eosinophilic deposits between Retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden painless vision loss and a history of a similar episode with quick restoration of vision and fundus examination cherry-red spot suggests a diagnosis of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). In CRAO,  the fovea centralis is extremely thin, allowing the red reflex from the choroid to be visible as a round cherry-red spot against the strong contrast of the cloudy white background. 

CRAO presents with sudden painless loss of vision, amaurosis fugax, absent direct pupillary reflex and a positive relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. CRAO is nearly always at the lamina cribrosa, where the vessels normally become slightly narrowed.

Fundus examination reveals thread-like arteries, a cattle track appearance of the veins and arteries, and an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot. This appearance is likely due to ischemia-induced retinal edema in the ganglion cell layer, which spares the fovea centralis (as it lacks a ganglion cell layer), or the naturally thinned-out fovea, both contributing to the distinct cherry-red spot.

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by intravenous acetazolamide or ocular massage. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases.

Other options:

Option A: Proliferation of blood vessels of the retina is seen in conditions like proliferative diabetic retinopathy and central retinal vein occlusion.

Option C: Collection of fluid and metabolites in the outer plexiform layer is seen in diabetic retinopathy, where lipids leak out in the outer plexiform layer to form hard exudates.

Option D: Deposition of eosinophilic extracellular deposits (drusen) between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane is seen in age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the hospital with complaints of fatigue, frequent headaches, blurry vision, and recurrent nose bleeds. On examination lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly are present. Both Direct Coombs test and Cold Agglutinin test are positive. The immunofixation electrophoresis report of the patient is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly male presenting with hyperviscosity symptoms with a positive Coombs test and cold agglutinin test along with monoclonal IgM protein on immunofixation electrophoresis is suggestive of Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.

Waldenström's macroglobulinemia is a plasma cell disorder that originates from a post–germinal center B cell which results in increased proliferation of memory B cells. it comes under the category of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. The cells produce large amounts of IgM antibodies leading to hyperviscosity syndrome which is characterized by visual impairment, Neurologic problems such as headaches, dizziness, deafness, and bleeding manifestations along with cryoglobulinemia resulting in Raynaud phenomenon and cold urticaria and ophthalmoscopic examination may reveal vascular segmentation and dilation of the retinal veins characteristic of hyperviscosity states normocytic, normochromic anemia, rouleaux formation, and a positive Coombs test is often present. 

The presence of MYD88 mutation status is diagnostic. It can also be used to discriminate WM from marginal zone lymphoma, IgM myeloma, and CLL. (option A, C)

Physical examination reveals lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.

Unlike myeloma, it does not cause bone lesions or hypercalcemia. Bone marrow shows >10% infiltration with lymphoplasmacytic cells (surface IgM+, CD19+, CD20+, CD22+, CD10− and CD23−) with an increase in the number of mast cells and an M component is present in the serum more than 30 g/L (3 g/dL). (option D) Renal failure is rare.

This patient with acute presentation of hyperviscosity syndrome can be treated by plasmapheresis. However, most patients do not require therapy unless they are symptomatic (anemia, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly.) It can be treated with ibrutinib which acts against BTK. Rituximab with cyclophosphamide can also be used.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought to her pediatrician with complaints of repeated hand-wringing movements and finger-licking. Detailed history revealed regression of language milestones. Microcephaly was noted on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rett syndrome based on the stereotyped hand-wringing movements, repetitive behavior with regressed language milestones, and microcephaly.

Rett syndrome is a progressive condition predominantly seen in girls. Under the international classification of diseases, the tenth revision falls under pervasive development disorder. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, 5th edition (DSM-5) considers it an autism spectrum disorder, though there are marked differences between them.

Between the ages of 6 months to 2 years, affected children develop progressive encephalopathy. Other clinical features include stereotypic hand movements such as wringing, biting, or licking the fingers, and poor muscle coordination. Marked regression of all language skills and plateaued communicative and social skills can also be seen. Microcephaly develops as age progresses. Head circumference is normal at birth, but growth begins to decelerate between the ages of 6 months to 1 year. Seizures are an associated feature in a large number of cases. 

Supportive treatment is given. Physiotherapy is beneficial for muscular dysfunction. Anticonvulsants may be required to control seizures.

Other options:

Options A&D: Heller's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. It is also known as childhood disintegrative disorder. It is predominantly seen in boys. They have marked regression in intellectual, social, and language functions after 2 years of apparently normal development. 

Option B: Asperger's syndrome is a type of autism spectrum disorder. There are marked nonverbal communicative gestures and failure to develop relationships with peers. No significant delay in language milestones or cognitive development is seen. The intelligence remains normal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with swelling and pain in the right leg, which is worse at night. Pain relieves on NSAIDs. You suspect osteoid osteoma. Which of the following instruments is used to remove the entire nidus of the osteoma?
questions.solution:
The instrument used to remove the entire nidus of osteoid osteoma is the curette shown in image B.

A curette is used for curetting a cavity in bone or removing fibrous tissue from the ends of the fracture. It is used in enchondroma, giant cell tumors, tubercular cavities of the bone, and osteomyelitis.

The instruments in the image are:

  • Image A: Periosteal elevator
  • Image B: Curette
  • Image C: Osteotome
  • Image D: Bone gouge

Osteoid osteoma is a benign neoplasm most often seen in young men. A typical patient presents with pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or NSAIDs. Plain radiographs are sufficient to make the diagnosis, but CT is the best technique to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes medical management with long-term anti-inflammatory medications, percutaneous radiofrequency ablation, and surgical treatment. Surgical treatment involves removal of the entire nidus, this can be accomplished by curettage or en bloc resection.

Image A is the periosteal elevator. It is used to elevate the periosteum as nerves, and vessels are generally on this plane, and once this has been elevated the surgeon is on a safer plane.

Image C represents an osteotome that can be used to cut bone while performing an osteotomy. An osteotome has both sides beveled.

Image D is bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting on round bone surfaces or making round holes in the bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text: A young woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. MRCP reveals cystic dilatation of the biliary tree, indicating a choledochal cyst. According to the Todani classification, which type of choledochal cyst would be managed with the Modified Kasai procedure?
questions.solution:
According to the Todani classification, Type IVb of choledochal cyst would be managed with the Modified Kasai procedure.

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. it is a type of Anomalous Pancreaticobiliary Junction (APBJ) which may allow reflux into the biliary tract, leading to inflammation, increased biliary pressure, and cyst formation.

Choledochal cysts are more common in women. Clinical features of choledochal cysts include The classic triad of abdominal pain, right upper quadrant mass, and jaundice (the most consistent symptom). Nausea, weight loss, fever, and pruritus may be seen. Complications like cholangitis, pancreatitis, bile peritonitis and may progress into cholangiocarcinoma.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasonography- Define the dimensions of the cyst and its relationship to the porta hepatis and the intrahepatic ductal configuration.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI/MRCP) is the investigation of choice. It delineates the anatomy of the biliary tree.
  • CT - delineates the extent of the intra or extrahepatic dilatation.
  • ERCP - defines the distal biliary tree

 Todani classification of the choledochal cysts along with their management is as shown below:

Type of choledochal cyst Surgical management
Type I complete surgical excision, cholecystectomy, and Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy
Type II Diverticulectomy, cholecystectomy, and CBD repair
Type III ERCP + sphincterotomy (Only cyst in which reconstruction is not required)
Type IVa Liver transplant
Type IVb Kasai procedure (Portoenterostomy)
Type V  (Caroli's disease) Liver transplant

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features would be seen in a patient with right medial medullary syndrome?
  1. Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion 
  2. Contralateral tongue weakness with deviation away from the lesion

questions.solution:
The characteristic triad of the medial medullary syndrome includes:

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature would be seen, in a lesion of the ventrolateral spinothalamic tract. Medial medullary syndrome spares the lateral spinothalamic tract, hence contralateral pain and temperature sensations are preserved.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent infections and progressive muscle weakness. On examination, the child is found to have cardiomyopathy, and laboratory tests reveal neutropenia. Genetic testing reveals defects in cardiolipin remodelling. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with recurrent infections, progressive muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, neutropenia and defects in cardiolipin remodelling is Barth syndrome.

Barth syndrome is a rare X-linked disorder characterized by cardiomyopathy (specifically dilated cardiomyopathy), skeletal myopathy, neutropenia, and short stature. The syndrome is caused by mutations that impair the normal remodelling of cardiolipin, a phospholipid that is crucial for mitochondrial function. The impaired cardiolipin metabolism leads to mitochondrial dysfunction, which is responsible for the multisystemic manifestations seen in Barth syndrome, including muscle weakness and recurrent infections due to impaired immune function.

Cardiolipin, also called Diphosphatidyl glycerol, is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a critical role in maintaining the structure and function of the membrane. It is essential for the optimal function of several mitochondrial enzymes that are involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism. Moreover, cardiolipin’s antigenic properties can cause a false-positive VDRL test.

Other options:

Option A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive genetic disorder with progressive muscle weakness due to an absence of the protein dystrophin. Dystrophin is a peripheral protein that connects cytosolic actin to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan. 

Option C: Pearson syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder characterized by features such as anaemia and pancreatic dysfunction.

Option D: Becker muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease that causes progressive weakness and wasting of cardiac and skeletal muscles. It is caused due to mutations in the DMD gene coding for dystrophin.

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to follow-up and is brought to you 2 years later. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years old, posteromedial soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line of management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A male patient comes with a history of diplopia and convergent squint of the right eye. You note that his head is tilted to the right for better vision. When asked to close his left eye and locate an object placed on his right side, he points it out farther right than it actually is. Forced duction test is negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of diplopia, convergent squint, compensatory head posture, and false projection, along with a negative forced duction test suggests a likely diagnosis of paralytic strabismus. 

Paralytic squint can be caused by many etiological factors such as neurogenic lesions (involving the nucleus, nerve root, or peripheral nerve), myogenic lesions, or neuromuscular junction lesions (myasthenia gravis). 

Diplopia is the primary complaint in this condition. There may be associated nausea and vertigo due to diplopia. Signs include primary deviation, secondary deviation, compensatory head tilt, and false projection/orientation.

Primary deviation is the deviation of the affected eye and it will deviate away from the action of the affected muscle, e.g. Secondary deviation is the deviation of the normal eye when the patient fixates with the squinting eye. Compensatory head posture means that the head tilts toward the action of the paralyzed muscle. False projection/orientation occurs due to increased impulse conveyed to the paralyzed muscle. 

A forced duction test is done to differentiate between restrictive and paralytic squint. Apart from that, investigations done for all cases of strabismus (refractive error testing, cover test, etc) as well as diplopia charting, and Hess screen test should also be done.

Diplopia is treated by using an occluder on the affected eye.  Chemodenervation of the contralateral muscle using botulinum toxin and surgical treatment if there is no improvement after 6 months can also be done to manage the condition.

Other options:

Option A: Accomodative esotropia is a convergent squint that occurs as a result of overaction of convergence related to accommodation reflex. It is the most common type of squint present in children and develops around 2 - 3 years of age. 

Option C: Restrictive squint occurs when there is a restriction to extraocular movement rather than paralysis of extraocular muscles. It can be seen in conditions such as thyroid ophthalmopathy, entrapped inferior rectus muscle in blow-out fracture and orbital mass lesions. Forced duction test will be positive. 

Option D: Primary exotropia is a form of divergent squint and may be intermittent or constant. It is usually seen in children. The deviation can be precipitated by conditions such as bright light and ill-health.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl complains of intense scalp itching following a recent change of school. Examination findings are as shown. What treatment option is approved for this condition?

choices.text: Permethrin 1% lotion application, repeated after 7 days
Permethrin 5% lotion application, repeated after 7 days

questions.solution:
The image shows the nits (eggs) of head louse Pediculus capitis, for which the approved treatment is permethrin 1% cream application, repeated after 7 days.

Head louse infestation is very common in children. The majority of the transmission is by head-to-head contact, which is frequently observed with overcrowding(as in schools), poverty, and poor hygiene.

Symptoms include severe itching of the scalp. On examinations, nits are seen, which are firmly attached to hair shafts on which they can be freely glided (as shown in the image below). Adults of lice are difficult to detect.

Treatment :

All infested households and close contacts should be treated at the same time. 1% permethrin lotion is applied to freshly shampooed hair for 10-15 minutes and reshampooed. Nits are removed with a fine-toothed comb. This is repeated after 7 days to kill the newly hatched lice, as permethrin is not ovicidal. Avoid sharing combs, brushes, hair accessories, and towels. To avoid reinfestation, fomites that have been used within 2 days before pediculicide treatment should be washed with hot water and dried with hot air.

Other treatment options include - Malathion 0.5% lotion, ivermectin 0.5% lotion, spinosad 0.9%, gamma benzene hexachloride 1% lotion and abametapir 0.74% lotion.

Other options:

Option A - Oral griseofulvin, for 4-8 weeks is the treatment for tinea capitis.

Option C - Permethrin 5% lotion application, repeated after 7 days is the treatment for scabies.

Option D - Ketoconazole shampoo 2%, applied for 7 days is not a treatment option for pediculosis. Ketoconazole shampoo is used for the treatment of seborrheic dermatitis and tinea versicolor.

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old rape victim was brought by the lady constable to the gynaecologist for examination. Which of the following tests need to be performed on her vaginal sample to identify it as semen?
questions.solution:
An acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains.

The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations upto 36 hours after it's deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. The acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case of the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia.

The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.

Teichmann, Benzidine, Takayama, and Kastlemayer tests are used to detect bloodstains. The below image shows the microscopy findings of tests used for sperm and blood stains. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient comes to the emergency department complaining of high fever, chills, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. Laboratory tests of blood and stool cultures show an oxidase-negative, motile, gram-negative bacillus which is cultured in the media pictured below.  Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism, in this case, is Salmonella typhi. Salmonella is a gram-negative rod that is motile, oxidase negative, and shows large black colonies, with a metallic sheen when cultured in Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulfite to sulfide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulfite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. Typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen and S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

Other options-

Option A - Shigella can cause bloody diarrhea and present similarly to Salmonella species infection. They also are oxidase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods. However, Shigella species are non-motile, while Salmonella species are motile.

Option B - Escherichia coli (EHEC, EIEC) can cause bloody diarrhea. They are also gram-negative rods that are oxidase-negative. However, E. coli does not produce black colonies in a bismuth sulfite medium.

Option D- Pseudomonas aeruginosa does not cause bloody diarrhea. Although it is a gram-negative bacillus, it is oxidase-positive.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a left eye cataract is planned for phacoemulsification surgery. During the surgery, the eye surgeon injects trypan blue into the eye just before performing the following surgical step as the dye stains which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the step of capsulorhexis, which is done for anterior capsulotomy and trypan blue is used before capsulorhexis to stain the anterior capsule of the lens. 

Trypan blue is commonly used during cataract surgery to enhance the visualisation of the anterior lens capsule before performing anterior capsulotomy via a continuous curvilinear pattern. It stains the anterior lens capsule without affecting the corneal endothelium (Option C). It is used routinely, however, it is specially indicated in mature and hyper-mature cataracts when the red reflex is not visible.

A cautious effort should be made to avoid any contact of the dye with the corneal endothelium. A bubble of air is injected into the anterior chamber, and a few drops of trypan blue dye are injected underneath the air bubble on the anterior lens capsule and spread evenly on the surface, which stains in a few seconds. Then, the air and residual dye are irrigated and washed out of the eye using a balanced salt solution (BSS) and then replaced with viscoelastic to fill the anterior chamber before proceeding with the capsulorhexis.

In phacoemulsification, this is combined with foldable posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation in a bag, which is now the preferred cataract surgery. The correct sequence of the surgical steps in phacoemulsification surgery includes clear corneal incision → continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis→ hydrodissection→ hydrodelineation→ irrigation-aspiration→ implantation.

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text: A young male patient presents to the outpatient department after sustaining a blow to his face during a fistfight. You are suspecting a tripod fracture. All of the following statements are correct except?

choices.text: Anesthesia in the distribution of infraorbital nerve
Trismus due to depression of the bone on the odontoid process below
Presence of step deformity of the infraorbital margin

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding tripod fracture is option C as Trismus is due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process, not the odontoid process. 

Clinical features for fracture of the zygoma/ tripod fracture are:

  • Flattening of malar prominence (Option A)
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin (Option D)
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of infraorbital nerve (Option B)
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament.
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.
  • Periorbital emphysema

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone after nasal bones. The lower segment of the zygomatic bone is pushed medially and posteriorly resulting in a flattening of the malar prominence and a step deformity at the infraorbital margin. Orbital contents may herniate into the maxillary sinus.

The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency room with profound drowsiness. On examination, he is found to have respiratory depression, with a respiratory rate of 5 cycles/minute. His symptoms are traced back to a drug derived from the plant shown below. Which of the following is the antidote to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The suitable antidote to this patient presenting with features of opiate intoxication is naloxone. The derivative drug, opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant as shown in the clinical vignette.

Toxic parts of the plant include the unripe fruit capsule and the latex juice. Active principles of opium are grouped under phenanthrenes (morphine, codeine, heroin) and benzyl-isoquinolones (papaverine, narcotin).

These drugs act on mu, kappa, delta receptors in the CNS and mediate the effects of euphoria, analgesia, respiratory depression, gastrointestinal dysmotility, and miosis. 

The antidote to opiate intoxication is a competitive opiate antagonist named naloxone which competes with opioids at their receptor sites. Dose: 0.4-2 mg IV (It may be repeated every 10-15 minutes up to a maximum dose of 10 mg).

Other options:

Option A - Flumazenil is the antidote to treat benzodiazepine (BZD) intoxication. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, flunitrazepam) are sedative-hypnotics and symptoms of intoxication include normal vital signs, sedation, diplopia, ataxia, slurred speech, and impaired motor function. Flumazenil acts as a competitive antagonist at the site of BZD action, which is the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor. 

Option C - Physostigmine is used in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity due to atropine. Atropine is the anticholinergic active principle derived from tropane alkaloids such as Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna. Toxidrome consists of features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, agitation, delirium, mydriasis, dry flushed skin, and urinary retention. Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholine esterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine concentrations in the synaptic cleft to mitigate the effects of atropine toxicity. 

Option D - Atropine is used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity due to organophosphates (DDT, parathion, malathion). Symptoms of cholinergic toxicity include bradycardia, respiratory depression, and autonomic symptoms of salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation. Atropine used in association with pralidoxime act as competitive inhibitors at the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors to neutralize the toxicity.

questions.text:
Select the correct sequence of clamping of structures in an abdominal hysterectomy.

1- Uterosacral ligament

2- Round ligament

3- Cardinal ligament

4- Uterine artery
questions.solution:
The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy is Round ligament->Uterine artery->Cardinal ligament->Uterosacral ligament.

The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy:

  • The first clamp includes the round ligament and infundibulopelvic ligament. (when ovaries are to be removed)
  • The second clamp includes the uterine artery.
  • The third clamp includes the cardinal ligament and uterosacral ligament.

The sequence of clamping of structure in vaginal hysterectomy:

  • The first clamp includes the uterosacral ligament, Mackenrodt’s ligament, and the descending cervical artery.
  • The second clamp includes the uterine artery and the base of the broad ligament.
  • The third clamp includes the round ligament, fallopian tube, mesosalpinx, and ligament of the ovary.

Note: In abdominal hysterectomy, the Mackenrodt (cardinal) ligament is clamped before the uterosacral ligament. whereas, in vaginal hysterectomy, the uterosacral ligament is clamped before the Mackenrodt (cardinal) ligament.

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese woman with type II diabetes presents to the OPD with raised postprandial blood glucose levels despite optimised lifestyle changes. She is currently on metformin but has not achieved adequate glycemic control. She also has diabetic kidney disease. The physician is considering adding another oral agent to her regimen. Which of the following agents would be most appropriate for this patient to target postprandial hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with persistent postprandial hyperglycemia despite optimal metformin use. It is essential to choose a renal-safe oral agent given the presence of diabetic kidney disease. The most appropriate treatment for this patient's postprandial hyperglycemia would be repaglinide.

Other Options:

Option A: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea drug. It is unsuitable as it causes weight gain and is unsafe in renal disease.

Option B: Mitiglinide, like repaglinide, belongs to the class of meglitinides. However, unlike repaglinide, Mitiglinide is unsafe in renal disease.

Option C: Exenatide, a long-acting GLP-1 agonist, is an injectable and not an oral agent.

questions.text: In the image of the bacterial RNA polymerase given below, which subunit  enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA?
questions.solution:
The σ subunit (sigma factor) enables RNA polymerase to recognize promoter regions on the DNA and thus helps to position it correctly on the template DNA. Thus, the σ subunit enables the core enzyme to recognize and bind the promoter region to form the preinitiation complex (PIC).

Following this, the RNA Polymerase catalyzes the formation of the first phosphodiester bond, and the nascent chain is attached to the polymerization site on the β subunit of RNA Polymerase. This reaction is termed initiation. The β subunit also binds to the Mg ion.

questions.text: Spinal anaesthesia was administered to a 40-year-old female patient with an umbilical hernia who was scheduled for anatomical repair. Six hours after the procedure, she developed a headache along with nausea and vomiting. Which type of needle could have helped avoid this complication?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of headache associated with nausea and vomiting following spinal anaesthesia is suggestive of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH). Whitacre’s spinal needle, which is a dura-splitting needle, has a decreased chance of causing PDPH.

PDPH is defined as a headache arising out of intentional or unintentional puncture of the dura membrane. Pathogenesis involves loss of CSF through the puncture and compensatory cerebral vasodilatation which produces headaches. Spontaneous resolution occurs within 7 days.

Spinal needles are of 2 types: dura cutting and dura splitting needles.

Dura cutting needles include Pitkins and Quincke-Babcock needles. They have a sharp, bevelled, cutting tip, which cuts through the layers of dura.

Dura-splitting needles include Sprotte, Whitacre, and Greene. They have a pencil-point, rounded and conical tip which splits the layers of dura. Thus, the loss of CSF is reduced and PDPH is lesser with these needles.

Option C: Tuohy needle is used for epidural anaesthesia. It is not meant for dural puncture. However accidental dural puncture with this needle can cause PDPH.

Related Pearl: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

  • Supine position
  • IV fluids
  • Caffeine and analgesia
  • Epidural blood patch

Related Pearl: Factors That Can Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Age: Younger, more frequent
  • Sex: Females > males
  • Needle size: Larger > smaller
  • Needle bevel: Less when the needle bevel is placed in the long axis of the neuraxis Orienting a needle bevel parallel with the axis of the spine, such that the longitudinal fibers of the dura would more likely be separated than cut, results in a lower incidence of postspinal puncture headache
  • Pregnancy: More when pregnant
  • Dural punctures: More with multiple punctures

Factors That Do Not Increase the Incidence of Headache After Spinal Puncture

  • Insertion and use of catheters for continuous spinal anesthesia
  • Timing of ambulation

Related Pearl: Complications of neuraxial (spinal and epidural) anesthesia

Adverse or exaggerated physiological response:

  • Urinary retention
  • High block
  • Total spinal anesthesia (with epidural)
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Anterior spinal artery syndrome
  • Horner's syndrome

Complication related to needle or catheter placement:

  • Backache
  • Dural puncture/leak
    • Post dural puncture headache
    • Diplopia (6th cranial nerve most commonly affected)
  • Neural injury
    • Nerve root/spinal cord damage
  • Bleeding
    • Intraspinal/epidural hematoma
  • Misplacement
    • Inadequate anesthesia
    • subdural block
    • intravascular injection
  • Inflammation 
    • Arachnoiditis
  • Infection
    • Meningitis
    • Epidural abscess

Drug toxicity

  • Systemic local anesthesia toxicity (epidural > spinal)
  • Transient neurological symptoms (Lidocaine, chloroprocaine with preservative)
  • Cauda equina syndrome (Lidocaine)

questions.text: IVU in a child with recurrent UTI appeared as below. What is the likely cause of the condition seen in the radiograph?

choices.text: Medially drawn ureters due to fibrosis
Fusion of lower poles of the two kidneys

questions.solution:
The given image shows a handshake sign indicating a horseshoe kidney which is caused by the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney.

The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. The ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery.

The episode of urinary tract infection in a patient with a horseshoe kidney should raise suspicion of vesicoureteral reflux as it is a common association.

The common associations of horseshoe kidneys are:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Wilms tumor
  • Multicystic dysplastic kidney
  • Turner’s syndrome

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely represented by the findings observed in the given fundus picture, who has a history of blow to the eye?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis from the findings observed in the given fundus picture is the Commotio retinae.

Commotio retinae or Berlin’s oedema manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region. It occurs following a blow to the eye.

Blunt trauma to the eye produces:

  • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.
  • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.
  • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema)

Other options:

Option A: Fundus examination of CRVO reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus( as shown below).

Option B: CRAO presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot as shown below.

Option D: ARMD is a degenerative disorder of the macula, characterized by the presence of drusen and retinal pigment epithelium changes. It is the most common cause of permanent central vision loss in the elderly. Drusens are observed in slit lamp examination, which shows yellowish-white spots in the macular region(as shown below).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man, status post craniotomy for a subdural hematoma developed 2 episodes of new-onset seizures. His volume status is represented by the following Darrow-Yannet diagram. Which of the following drugs can be used for the management of his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a patient with new-onset seizures post craniotomy and darrow yannet diagram showing reduced plasma osmolality and increased volume of ECF and ICF is suggestive of SIADH - Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic hormone production. Conivaptan is the best-suited drug for the management of this condition.

SIADH is characterized by excess production of ADH irrespective of serum osmolality, which can occur due to head trauma, postoperatively, drug-induced, malignancies, etc. Excess reabsorption of free water from the collecting duct without solute reabsorption results in excess sodium loss in urine and the production of concentrated urine. Clinically the patient remains Euvolemic because the excess fluid is redistributed proportionately in the ECF & ICF. (Euvolemic hyponatremia)

Bartter and Schwartz diagnostic criteria of SIADH

  • Hyponatremia
  • Clinically euvolemic
  • Serum osmolality less than 275 mOsm/Kg
  • Urine osmolality more than 100mOsm/Kg
  • Urine sodium of more than 40 mmol/L
  • No use of diuretics

Management of SIADH:

In an acute symptomatic setting, 3% NaCl infusion is recommended at a rate of 1% per hour to gradually raise serum sodium levels, targeting 130 mEq/L. In addition, aquaretic agents can be used, such as Conivaptan, a combined V1a/V2 antagonist available for IV administration, or Tolvaptan, an oral V2 antagonist suited for short-term use.

For the management of chronic SIADH, the preferred approach is fluid restriction, limiting total fluid intake to less than the combined urinary and insensible losses. Oral Tolvaptan is an appropriate choice for longer-term management, particularly when fluid restriction alone is insufficient to maintain sodium balance.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that may exacerbate the hyponatremia of SIADH as in induces solute & water loss.

Option C. Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent that itself causes SIADH and can worsen the seizures

Option D. Fludrocortisone although promotes reabsorption of sodium from the renal tubules, is more useful in a setting of hypovolemia as in Cerebral salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text: A 68-year-old female with AIDS comes to the emergency department with a painless, rapidly growing lesion as shown below. A lesion biopsy shows small round blue cells, salt and paper chromatin with  scant cytoplasm. The tumor markers for this disease are:
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Merkel cell carcinoma and its tumor markers are CK7-, and CK20+.

This is a primary neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin originating from Merkel cells are located in the epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions. This disease typically presents as a rapidly growing, flesh-colored to red or purple papule or plaque which is most commonly found in sun-exposed areas such as the head, neck, or extremities.

Clinical features of Merkel cell carcinoma can be summarized by the acronym AEIOU: asymptomatic/nontender, expand rapidly, immune suppression(AIDS), older than 50 years, and ultraviolet-exposed site. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma.

The image below shows Merkel cell carcinoma composed of uniform small round cells having granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm.

questions.text: Injury to the membranous urethra leads to accumulation of urine in _______:
questions.solution:
Injury to the membranous urethra (content of deep perineal pouch) leads to accumulation of urine in the deep perineal pouch.

Injury to the spongy urethra leads to the accumulation of urine in the superficial perineal pouch. Since the superficial perineal fascia (Colles’ fascia) is in continuity with Scarpa’s fascia of the anterior abdominal wall and the fascial layer that contains the dartos muscle, urine can accumulate in the scrotum, perineum and lower abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

Option A- The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.

Option B- The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.

Option C- Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman diagnosed with Grave's disease was started on an anti-thyroid drug that does not inhibit the conversion of T4 to T3. Which of the following drug would have been used?
questions.solution:
Methimazole would have been used as an anti-thyroid drug in this patient as it does not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 (levothyroxine) to T3 (triiodothyronine). It acts by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase enzyme.

Drugs inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 are propranolol, glucocorticoids, propylthiouracil, and amiodarone. These drugs are used in combination in the management of thyroid storm.

Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It acts to prevent hormone synthesis by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase catalyzed reactions - iodine organification and coupling of iodotyrosine residues. It has a long intrathyroidal t1/2 and allows once-daily dosing. The usual starting dose for methimazole is 15–40 mg per day.

It is the drug of choice for Grave's disease. It can be used in conjunction with radioactive iodine, to fasten the recovery and to bring the patient to a euthyroid state before preparation for surgery. 

It is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy including fetal aplasia cutis which is shown below.

Methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

  • Thiocyanates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: The fracture shown in the given image may cause all of the following except
questions.solution:
The image shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Malunion of this fracture leads to cubitus varus (gunstock deformity) and does not cause cubitus valgus.  

Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is most common in children 5-7 years after falling on an outstretched hand with the elbow in full extension. The most common complication of supracondylar fracture is malunion. This leads to cubitus varus or gunstock deformity. Malunion occurs due to improper reduction and not due to physeal damage, as the fracture is extraphyseal Other complications include myositis ossificans, compartment syndrome, and Volkmann ischemic contracture. 

Nerve and vessel injury:

  • The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve > median nerve (leading to pointing index sign)> Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (option C)
  • The most common nerve to be injured in the flexion type is the ulnar nerve.
  • The most common vessel to be injured - the brachial artery. (Vascular injury and impaired circulation causing Volkmann’s ischemic contracture)(option B)

Radiological findings: An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma. Baumann’s angle (humeral-capitellar angle) can help in assessing the degree of medial angulation before and after reduction.

Gartland classification is used for supracondylar fractures. The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture. 

Undisplaced supracondylar humerus fractures are treated by an above-elbow plaster slab with the elbow in 90º flexion. Displaced fractures are treated by closed reduction and K-wire fixation since they tend to slip after reduction. Open fractures or those associated with brachial artery injury are treated by open reduction and internal fixation.

The image of gunstock deformity is shown below.

Note: Cubitus valgus deformity results from the non-union of the fractured lateral condyle.

questions.text:

PHC- Primary Health Centres

choices.text: They are PHCs at the level of block headquarters
They are present only in the rural areas
They usually serve as the first point of contact for the patient
They promote decentralization of health services

questions.solution:
Block Public Health Unit (BPHU) help to promote decentralisation of health services.

BPHUs are CHCs (Community Health Centres) at the block headquarters (Option A) level in both rural and urban areas (Option B). The BPHU are expected to have four functional areas- clinical service delivery, public health functions, a block public health laboratory to serve both clinical and public health functions, and a Health Management Information System unit. The clinical and diagnostic services are delivered as per Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS). 

They serve as a hub for referrals from the PHCs and SHCs (Option C) of the block to reduce crowding at higher-level facilities and provide comprehensive primary health care ( clinical and public health services). The BPHUs also promote decentralised planning and the preparation of block health plans that feed into district health plans.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida comes to the OPD at a gestational age of 42 weeks. The AFI is 6 cm. Her bishop's score was found to be 4. Which of the following methods of induction cannot be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical case with a female with a gestational age of 42 weeks indicating postmaturity with an AFI of 6 cm (normal) and bishop's score of 4 indicating an unfavorable cervix. Artificial rupture of membranes cannot be performed in an unfavorable cervix. 

Indications for induction of labor:

  • Postmaturity with AFI (5-25 cm)
  • Pre-eclampsia/eclampsia
  • Intrauterine fetal death
  • Premature rupture of the membranes
  • Congenital malformation of the fetus
  • Antepartum hemorrhage

Stripping of membranes and ARM are two surgical methods of labor induction. The advantages of ARM include relief of maternal distress in cases of hydramnios, control of bleeding in antepartum hemorrhage, and relief of tension in abruptio placentae, as well as initiation of labor.

The complications of ARM include umbilical cord prolapse (though the risk is low when the head is engaged or the membranes are ruptured with the head fixed at the brim), amnionitis, and accidental injury to the placenta, cervix, uterus, fetal parts, or vasa previa.

Note : Oxytocin, Dinoprostone gel and Misoprostol tablet can be adopted in case of an unfavorable cervix in a case of postmaturity without complications. In cases of complicated postmaturity i.e. elderly primigravida, pre-eclampsia, Rh-incompatibility, fetal compromise, oligohydramnios, an elective C-section is preferred.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A human femur recovered from a crime scene is brought to you for identification. Which of the following can be used to estimate the stature of this individual?
questions.solution:
Trotter and Glesser’s formula can be used to estimate the stature of the individual using long bones such as the femur.

Various formulae are used to estimate stature when one or the other long bones are available instead of the entire skeleton. These formulae are regression equations. The femur is the most reliable bone for stature estimation. Other formulae for stature estimation from long bones include- Karl Pearson’s formula, Dupertain & Hadden's formula, and Steele's formula.

Other options:

Option B- Krogman's accuracy index provides accuracy of sex determination from bones. The pelvis is the most reliable bone (95%), followed by the skull (90%) and long bones (80%).

Option C- Modified Brooke formula is used for fluid resuscitation in burns patients.

Option D- Ashley's rule of 149 is used for sex determination using the sternal length (manubrium+ body). A length >149 mm indicates a male sternum and < 149 mm indicates a female sternum.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic due to failure to thrive, irritability, and episodes of vomiting after consuming fruit juices. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia and genetic testing confirms a deficiency in an enzyme involved in the fructose metabolism. Which of the following reactions is mediated by the enzyme affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The 6-month-old infant is presenting with symptoms of hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI), which occurs due to a deficiency in aldolase B, an enzyme involved in fructose metabolism. This enzyme normally catalyses the reaction - Fructose-1-phosphate → Dihydroxyacetone phosphate + Glyceraldehyde.

Aldolase B is the enzyme affected in HFI, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency. This enzyme is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine, and it catalyses the hydrolysis of fructose-1-phosphate. The deficiency in aldolase B leads to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate, causing metabolic disturbances.

Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well.

Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.

A reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of fructaldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.

The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.

questions.text: As a surgeon, you plan to perform the following surgeries on four of your patients. In which of the following procedures will you be extra cautious due to the higher risk of surgical site infection (SSI)?
questions.solution:
Extra precautions should be taken while performing a colorectal surgery as it belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) with an expected infection rate of 4-14%.

Elective cholecystectomy also belongs to the category of clean-contaminated wound (class II) but it is associated with a lesser infection rate of 2-9%

Class I: Clean wounds: Surgical site infection (SSI) rate is least in clean wounds, i.e. in operations where there is no inflammation and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Examples include:

  • Elective herniorrhaphy is a clean wound categorized as class I (as the prosthetic mesh is placed)
  • Breast biopsy 

Class II: Clean-contaminated wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Examples include:

  • Elective cholecystectomy
  • Elective gastrointestinal surgeries (eg: Fundoplication)
  • Colorectal surgery (higher infection rate)

Class III: Contaminated wounds include open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered.

Class IV: Dirty wounds include old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera.

Related Pearl: Surgical wound classifications as defined by ACS NSOP

  • Clean: Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered
  • Clean/Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination
  • Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks insterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered
  • Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera

questions.text: The torture method shown in the image below is known as?
questions.solution:
The given torture method depicts the dunking which is a type of torture where the whole body is put under water.

The World Medical Association defines torture as "The deliberate, systematic or wanton infliction of physical or mental suffering by one or more persons acting alone or on the orders of any authority, to force another person to yield information, to confess or for any other reason".

The methods of torture can be (1) Physical abuse, (2)  Mental torture, (3) Sexual torture, (4) Pharmacological torture

Eponymous methods of physical abuse commonly employed:

  • Dry submarine: It is a type of torture where a plastic bag is tied over the head up to the point of suffocation. Asphyxial signs will be present. 
  • Chepuwa: This form of torture involves tying the thighs and legs very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain. (Option C)
  • Waterboarding: A form of torture in which water is poured over a cloth covering the face and breathing passages of a victim who is immobilised, causing the sensation of drowning (Option B)
  • Wet-submarine: Forcefully immersing the victim's head into water, sewage, or any other fluid (Option D)
  • Falanga: Also known as Falaka or Bastinado, it is a method of torture that involves repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an object such as a truncheon, iron rod, cable, bamboo cane, wooden pole, or rifle butt.
  • El quirofano: Beating on the abdomen while the victim is lying on a table with the upper half of the body unsupported
  • Cattleprod: Passing a high voltage current through a pointed object (cattle prod). The genitals are usually targeted.
  • Telefono: This form of torture involves repeated slapping of the sides of the head (over the ears).
  • Jack/Parrot's perch: Head down from a horizontal pole placed under the knees with the wrists bound to the ankle.
  • Black slave: Inserting heated metal skewers inside the victim's anal canal.
  • Sawhorse: Forcing the victim to straddle on a bar
  • Ghotna: This form of torture involves rolling a wooden log or an iron rod up and down the thigh, while the log is being weighted by one or two individuals standing on it.

questions.text: Using the procedure depicted in the given image, all of the following can be measured, except _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the procedure of spirometry and Functional residual capacity (FRC) cannot be recorded using it. 

The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after the expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume. As residual volume cannot be measured by spirometry, lung capacities that include the residual volume also cannot be measured by spirometry (i.e., FRC and TLC).

Spirometry cannot measure the following lung volumes and capacities:
  • Residual volume (RV)
  • Closing volume (CV)
  • Functional residual capacity (ERV +  RV)
  • Total lung capacity (TLC)

In the modern dry spirometer, the patient is asked to breathe in and exhale forcefully. The spirometer calculates the volume of air passing through it as a function of time. Therefore, it gives us various parameters useful for the diagnosis of pulmonary/airway disease.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was subjected to hysterosalpingography and the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis and classification of the anomaly seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Uterus didelphys, Class III of Mullerian duct anomalies is seen on hysterosalpingography in the image given above.

Uterus didelphys occurs as a result of the non-fusion of paramesonephric ducts of both sides. Structures developing from the paramesonephric duct are the fallopian tube, uterus, cervix, and upper 2/3rds of the vagina and hence a patient with uterus didelphys will have 2 of each, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, and upper vagina.

The following classification of Mullerian duct anomalies was proposed by Buttram and Gibbons :

  • Class I—Müllerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Müllerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

A-Normal, B-Unicornuate, C-Arcuate, D to G-Septate uterus of different grades, H-Bicornuate, I-Didelphys

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman in her first trimester is planning to travel to a yellow fever-endemic region in the upcoming month. Which of the following would be the appropriate advice regarding yellow fever vaccination?

choices.text: Avoid vaccination, as live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy
Vaccination has to be given at least 72 hours before the travel date
Vaccination has to be given at least 10 days before the travel date
Vaccination can be given anytime before or during the travel in the endemic area

questions.solution:
For the patient in the given scenario, the appropriate measure would be to give the vaccine at least 10 days before the travel.

Yellow fever vaccine, despite being a live vaccine, has to be given to pregnant women as the benefits outweigh the risks. It is given as a single dose (17 D strain) via subcutaneous way. Immunity is demonstrated 10 days after the vaccination. The yellow fever vaccine certificate is valid throughout the lifetime. 

Vaccines contraindicated in pregnancy include live attenuated ones like: 

  • Mumps, Measles, rubella
  • Varicella and vaccinia (small pox)
  • BCG
  • HPV vaccines

Vaccines that are safe in pregnancy: "ABC Rabies"

  • Hepatitis A & B
  • Cocci: Meningococcal and pneumococcal vaccines
  • Rabies 

The incubation period for yellow fever is 3 to 6 days, and many people remain asymptomatic. Common symptoms include fever, muscle pain, headache, loss of appetite, and nausea, usually lasting 3 to 4 days. In a small percentage of cases, a more severe toxic phase develops within 24 hours of initial recovery. This phase is marked by high fever, liver and kidney dysfunction, jaundice, dark urine, abdominal pain, and bleeding. About half of those who enter the toxic phase die within 7–10 days.

The quarantine period is limited to 6 days, starting from the passenger's departure from the airport in the endemic country or until the yellow fever vaccination becomes effective (whichever is shorter).
