questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presented with sudden onset headache with 10/10 intensity. She does not have any vision disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. A non-contrast CT of the head was performed and found to be normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as she has a sudden onset, intense headache of 10/10 intensity without any visual disturbances, photophobia, or watering eyes. Patients usually describe these headaches as ‘the worst headache they’ve had in their entire life.’ The best next step in management is to perform a lumbar puncture.

Most cases of SAH are usually diagnosed with a non-contrast head CT. However, if high suspicion for SAH remains after an initial negative non-contrast head CT, then a lumbar puncture should be performed. Visual inspection of the CSF will reveal xanthochromia. However, this can only be seen 6-12 hours after the onset of SAH. However, lumbar puncture should only be performed as first-line testing if CT facilities are unavailable. 

If the SAH is due to a ruptured aneurysm, the patient must undergo a 4-vessel x-ray angiography (both carotids and both vertebral arteries) to localize the aneurysm and identify other potential unruptured aneurysms. Alternatively, CT angiography can be performed. Definitive treatment includes endovascular coiling or aneurysmal clipping. 

Other options: 

Option A - A repeat non-contrast head CT is unlikely to reveal new information and will just subject the patient to unnecessary radiation also CT scan is more sensitive in the initial hours for SAH.

Option C - 100% oxygen inhalation is used to treat cluster headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a cluster headache as it is not an episodic retro-orbital headache. Cluster headache is usually associated with conjunctival injection or excessive lacrimation.

Option D- Sumatriptan is a selective 5HT 1B/1D receptor agonist that can be used in combination to treat acute migraine headaches. This patient is unlikely to have a migraine as she does not have any of the accompanying symptoms (aura) of visual disturbances or photophobia and 10/10 intensity is more characteritsic of SAH

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy had a throat infection, which was treated by a local physician. After 5 days of recovery, he developed a rash, as shown in the image, along with joint pain affecting multiple joints. Which of the following is correct about your diagnosis?

choices.text: Systemic deposition of primarily IgG immune complexes.
Steroids are given in all cases

questions.solution:
A young boy presenting with a history of multiple joint pains and rash in the image showing palpable purpura within 5 days of a throat infection  is highly suggestive of Henoch Schonlein Purpura(HSP). Serum complement levels are normal in this condition.

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterized by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis. (Option A)

The exact etiology of HSP remains unknown. But, it usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection caused by group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Mycoplasma, and Adenovirus.

Children usually present with the following features:

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks.
  • Arthralgia and arthritis- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and intussusception.
  • About 30% of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, presenting as microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis.

Laboratory studies generally show mild leukocytosis, a normal platelet count(Option B), and occasionally eosinophilia. Serum complement components are normal with a non-specific increase in total serum IgA level. A skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence

Management- It is largely a self-limiting disease with an emphasis on ensuring hydration, analgesia, and nutrition. Steroids are given in significant GI involvement or other life-threatening manifestations. Steroids do not prevent renal complications. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. (Option C)

questions.text:
A 45 yr old man, non-smoker & non-alcoholic complained of right upper quadrant pain. His liver function tests are given below. USG abdomen reveals grade 2 fatty infiltration of the liver. Which of the following drugs has recently been FDA-approved for treating this condition?

S. AST - 110 IU/L
S. ALT- 123 IU/L
questions.solution:
A non-alcoholic with elevated liver enzymes & evidence of fatty infiltration of the liver suggests a diagnosis of Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH). The newest FDA-approved drug for the same is Resmetirom.

Resmetirom is a thyroid hormone receptor beta (THR-β) agonist that acts by decreasing lipogenesis & promoting fatty acid beta-oxidation. This reduces the inflammation & fatty infiltration in the liver.

It is taken at doses of 80-100mg orally once daily. Side effects include an increased risk of gallstones, cholecystitis & hepatotoxicity.

Other drugs that are of use in NASH are:

  • Vitamin E
  • Thiazolidinediones
  • Obeticholic acid
  • Semaglutide, tirzepatide

Other options: 

Option A: Teduglutide is a GLP2 analogue used for Short bowel syndrome.

Option B: Alogliptin is a DPP4 inhibitor and oral hypoglycemic agent for T2DM.

Option C: Ursodeoxycholic acid is a bile acid that is used in cholestatic diseases.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old female who has been diagnosed with cervical cancer now presents with blood in her stools and painful defecation. Severe dysfunction of the right kidney was detected on Tc-99m DTPA scintigraphy. There is no evidence of distant metastasis on the PET scan. What is the most likely stage of the cancer?

Tc-99m DTPA scan: diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate scan
questions.solution:
The given case of a 38-year-old female, diagnosed with cervical cancer, now presenting with blood in her stools and painful defecation with severe dysfunction of her right kidney is most likely stage 4A cancer cervix. 

Stage 4A cervical cancer refers to advanced cancer that has spread locally beyond the cervix to nearby structures such as the bladder, rectum, or pelvic wall, but it has not yet spread to distant organs. Symptoms of Stage 4A Cervical Cancer include:

  • Pelvic pain or discomfort.
  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding, including postcoital bleeding or spotting.
  • Urinary problems, such as blood in urine (hematuria) or difficulty urinating.
  • Rectal symptoms, like blood in stool, painful bowel movements, or constipation.
  • Back or leg pain due to nerve or spinal involvement.
  • Fatigue and unexplained weight loss.
  • Swelling in the legs (edema).
  • Foul-smelling vaginal discharge.
  • Increased urgency or frequency of urination.

Carcinoma cervix is the 4th most common gynecological cancer worldwide, with human papillomavirus infection being the most important risk factor. Treatment modalities include surgery, chemoradiation, or palliative care depending on the stage and fertility concerns.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with ECG showing  irregular RR intervals with absent P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70), he is symptomatic for > 48 hours, and there is presence of a left atrial thrombus thus requiring initiation of anticoagulation.  

The major source of thromboembolism and stroke in AF is the formation of thrombus in the left atrial appendage due to stagnant flow. Hence thromboembolism must be prevented by giving anticoagulants, along with an appropriate rate/rhythm control strategy with the help of electrical or pharmacologic cardioversion. 

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: the duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke. The patients who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This can be done in 2 ways as shown below:

The severity of atrial fibrillation refers to the presence of symptoms such as hypotension, pulmonary edema, or angina that are reflective of the cardiac health prior to the onset of fibrillation, and requires emergency cardioversion.

For long-term treatment of patients, the risk of stroke is calculated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score, and anticoagulation is given to those with a score of 1 or more.

Note: Electrical cardioversion is contraindicated in this patient due to the presence of a left atrial thrombus and therefore high risk of stroke.

questions.text: In a rural village, a community health worker uses a puppet show to educate the local population about the importance of sanitation and hygiene. Which method of communication is being used here?
questions.solution:
The method of communication being used here by the community health worker is Folk media.

Folk media are an integral part of mass communication. The term "mass communication" encompasses all forms of communication, ranging from electronic media to folk and indigenous traditions, such as keerthan, Katha, folk songs, dance dramas, and puppet shows that are deeply rooted in our culture. Additionally, Muslims have their own traditional folk forms, including ghazals and qawwali.

Unlike folk media, demonstrations, roleplays, and exhibits are a part of a group approach.

Related Pearl: Methods of Health Communication

questions.text: A neonate with vomiting, irritability and progressive lethargy was investigated and was found to be deficient for ornithine permease enzyme. All the below laboratory findings are associated with this disorder, except _______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a deficiency of ornithine permease points towards a diagnosis of HHH syndrome. Hyperargininemia is not a component of this disorder.

Components of HHH syndrome:

  • Hyperammonemia
  • Hyperornithinemia
  • Homocitrullinemia

The given scenario is HHH syndrome, due to a mutation of the gene coding for ornithine permease (ORNT1). This is an autosomal recessive condition. The import of ornithine from the cytosol to the mitochondrial matrix does not occur, which leads to the accumulation of cytosolic ornithine and, consequently, hyperammonemia and hyperornithinemia. 

Since ornithine is not present, mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate converts lysine to homocitrulline, leading to homocitrullinuria. 

Hyperargininemia is an autosomal recessive defect in the gene for arginase. Unlike the case with urea cycle disorders, the first symptoms of hyperargininemia typically do not appear until the age of 2 to 4 years. Blood and cerebrospinal fluid levels of arginine are elevated.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text:
A city is planning to improve its water filtration system to provide safe drinking water. The authorities are considering the implementation of either a rapid sand filter or a slow sand filter. Which of the following options indicates the key difference between these two filtration methods?
  Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
1 Remove sediments alone Filters microorganisms
2 Rely on plain sedimentation before filtration Require chemical coagulation and sedimentation
3 Use backwashing to remove accumulated debris Rely on scraping to maintain filter efficiency
4 Unskilled labor is enough Skilled labor is required
questions.solution:
Among the following options, the key difference between these two filtration methods is that slow sand filters rely on scraping to maintain filter efficiency, while rapid sand filters use backwashing to remove accumulated debris(option C).

Slow sand filters:

These are also called biological filters. They are accepted as the standard method of large-scale water purification.

In a new filter, the sand bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But, over time the sand bed becomes covered with schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms, and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter, and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through, and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free. Until the vital layer is fully formed (which takes several days), the filtrate of the first few days is usually run to waste.

Rapid sand filters:

They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large-scale purification of water. Two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).

Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200 m.g.a.d 2–3 m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4–0.7 mm 0.2–0.3 mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation 
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2–2.5 m/6–8 feet 1.5 m/4 feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good

 Fair 
Removal of bacteria 98–99% 99.9–99.99% 

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: An elderly male with a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with complaints of pain abdomen and fever. Upon abdominal examination, there was guarding and rigidity. During laparotomy, a diverticular perforation is seen with gross purulent peritonitis.  What is the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Purulent peritonitis in an elderly male patient who is a known case of diverticulosis should be managed with Hartmann's procedure.

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

A colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema confirm the diagnosis of diverticulosis. A barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall, giving the sawtooth appearance.

Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey's classification of complicated diverticulitis is as follows:

Stage

Description

Management

Stage 1

 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess

IV antibiotics and image-guided drainage

Stage 2

 Pelvic abscess

IV antibiotics and image-guided drainage

Stage 3

 Purulent peritonitis

Laparotomy

Stage 4

 Fecal peritonitis

Laparotomy
 
Management of diverticulosis includes a high-fiber diet, bulk-forming laxatives, and antispasmodics.
Acute diverticulitis has been treated with intravenous antibiotics and bowel rest. Localized abscesses are managed with intravenous antibiotics and image-guided drainage. Stages 3 and 4 are considered a surgical emergency and a laparotomy with a thorough washout of contamination is performed.
Hartmann procedure is the mainstay of treatment in which the involved colon is excised and an end colostomy is formed. Resection with primary anastomosis is considered only in young fit patients without gross contamination or sepsis. (option C)
 
Other options:
Option A: Laparoscopy-assisted Soave procedure is the most common surgical procedure for Hirschsprung disease.
Option B: Bianchi's procedure is performed in short bowel syndrome.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the ER with complaints of abdominal pain and confusion. Investigations reveal serum calcium of 12mg/dl and serum PTH is elevated. X-ray of the abdomen shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with abdominal pain and confusion with hypercalcemia (normal Ca levels 8.5-10.5mg/dl) and elevated PTH indicates hyperparathyroidism. The above X-ray image shows calcium deposits in the kidney due to hypercalcemia and is suggestive of nephrocalcinosis.

Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemic conditions like hyperparathyroidism. In this radiograph, it shows deposits of calcium in the renal medulla.

Hyperparathyroidism is caused by elevated parathyroid hormone and is classified into primary, secondary, and tertiary types. The clinical manifestations of hyperparathyroidism can be summarised as “painful bones, renal stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans.” Skeletal manifestations of hyperparathyroidism include bone resorption, osteitis fibrosa cystica, and brown tumors. Renal changes include nephrolithiasis (stones) and nephrocalcinosis.

Nephrocalcinosis refers to the presence of calcification in the renal parenchyma. Nephrocalcinosis can be seen in various conditions like hyperparathyroidism, medullary sponge kidney, renal tubular acidosis, hypervitaminosis D, chronic glomerulonephritis, and primary hyperoxaluria.  Stippled patterns of calcification are observed on X-rays in the cortical and medullary regions of both the kidneys due to cortical and medullary nephrocalcinosis, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Putty kidney is a characteristic pattern of renal calcification seen in the case of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB). It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is always a secondary TB (reinfection or reactivation of old TB). Genitourinary TB usually presents as sterile pyuria.

A putty kidney appears as large, dense, and homogeneous calcifications, often with a ground-glass appearance, resulting from calcified caseous tissue within dilated renal calyces. An atrophic calcified kidney (auto nephrectomy) with calcified non-enhancing cystic lesion is appreciated in one or both kidneys. CT can also detect scarring and Fibrotic strictures of the infundibula, renal pelvis, and ureters are highly suggestive of TB.

The radiograph below shows a putty kidney.

Option C: Polycystic kidney disease is best visualized on ultrasound and CT scans where the cysts are usually hypodense relative to the renal parenchyma. It may appear hyperdense if there is a presence of hemorrhage.

X-ray has no role in the diagnosis. However, it may reveal features such as renal enlargement, multilobulation, and multiple calcifications with ring configurations.

The image given below shows CT findings seen in childhood polycystic kidney disease

Option D: Medullary sponge kidney represents a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts. Intravenous pyelogram showed ectatic distal collecting ducts contain the microcalcification which is called bouquet of flowers appearance, as shown below in the radiograph.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought with complaints of nasal obstruction. After a detailed examination, he was diagnosed to have adenoid hypertrophy and was planned for adenoidectomy. Which of the following options is not an indication for the surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
All the options mentioned above are indications of adenoidectomy, except the submucous cleft palate. It is instead, a contraindication for adenoidectomy.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnea syndrome, or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media with recurrent ear discharge associated with adenoiditis/ adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion.

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of pressure epiphysis?
questions.solution:
Head of the femur is an example of a pressure epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis is articular in nature and takes part in the transmission of weight. Examples are head of the femur, the lower end of radius, etc.

Other options

Options A and D: Tubercles of humerus and trochanters of femur are examples of traction epiphysis.

Option C: Coracoid process of scapula is an example of the atavistic epiphysis.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders

A. Stickler syndrome
2. Type II B. Alport syndrome
3. Type III C. Ehler Danlos syndrome (vascular subtype)
4. Type IV D. Osteogenesis imperfecta
questions.solution:
The correctly matched type of collagen with its associated disease entity is 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B. 

Collagen is the most abundant protein and approximately 28 types have been isolated. The structure of collagen is a triple helix composed of 3 polypeptide chains having glycine residues at every third position.

In osteogenesis imperfecta, there is a severe decrease in bone mass that makes bones brittle, associated with blue sclerae, dental abnormalities, progressive hearing loss, and positive family history.

Stickler syndrome is characterized by skeletal changes, orofacial abnormalities, and auditory abnormalities.

Alport syndrome is characterized by the presence of a genetically abnormal basement membrane giving rise to proteinuria and hematuria.

questions.text: Children display pseudoparalysis of Parrot in which infectious disease?
questions.solution:
Pseudoparalysis of Parrot is a clinical sign in children with congenital syphilis.

Bone involvement in congenital syphilis leads to pain due to osteochondritis, which results in children refusing to move the affected limb. This is phenomenon is named pseudoparalysis of Parrot. Other features of congenital syphilis include thrombocytopenia, persistent rhinitis, and vasculitis.

Some manifestations of late-stage congenital syphilis are summarized in the table below.

SYMPTOMS/SIGNS DESCRIPTION/COMMENTS
Olympian brow The bony prominence of the forehead caused by persistent or recurrent periostitis
Clavicular or Higoumenakis sign Unilateral or bilateral thickening of the sternoclavicular portion of the clavicle
Saber shins Anterior bowing of the midportion of the tibia
Scaphoid scapula Convexity along the medial border of the scapula
Hutchinson Teeth Peg-shaped notches under central incisors. They erupt during 6th yr of life with abnormal enamel, resulting in a notch along the biting surface
Mulberry molars Abnormal 1st lower (6yr) molars characterized by small biting surface and excessive number of cusps
Saddle nose Depression of the nasal root, a result of syphilitic rhinitis destroying adjacent bone or cartilage
Rhagades Linear scars that extended in a spoke-like pattern from previous mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia
Juvenile paresis Latent meningovascular infection; it is rare and typically occurs during adolescence with behavioral changes, focal seizures, or loss of intellectual function
Juvenile tabes Rare spinal cord involvement and cardiovascular involvement with aortitis
Hutchinson triad Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and 8th nerve deafness
Clutton joint Unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling (usually involving knees) from synovitis with sterile synovial fluid; spontaneous remission usually occurs after several weeks
Interstitial keratitis Manifests with intense photophobia and lacrimation, followed within weeks or months by corneal opacification and complete blindness
8th nerve deafness Maybe unilateral or bilateral. Appears at any age, manifests initially as vertigo and high-tone hearing loss, and progress to permanent deafness
A perforated nasal septum may be an associated abnormality.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator for long-term nutritional status?
questions.solution:
Height for age is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status (chronic malnutrition).

The influence of malnutrition is seen earlier in a child's weight. This means that changes in weight are more indicative of acute status, and weight-based indices are used to assess acute malnutrition. Weight for age is the most commonly used index. Changes in height occur as a result of long-term nutritional deprivation and is hence, an indicator of chronic malnutrition. A low weight for height, or wasting, also indicates acute malnutrition.

questions.text:
An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the TCA cycle. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate after adding malonate. Which of the following graphs represents the type of inhibition expected here?

V: Reaction velocity

[S]: Substrate concentration
questions.solution:
The enzyme catalyzing the conversion of succinate to fumarate is succinate dehydrogenase. Its inhibition by malonate is a competitive inhibition which is represented by image 1. (option B)

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate.

The below graph is called the 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot. 1/V is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors.

 

Inhibition Km Vmax
Competitive Increases Same
Non Competitive Same Decreases
Uncompetitive Decreases Decreases

Although image 4 also corresponds to noncompetitive inhibition, the graph shows a plot of 1/V (Reaction Velocity) vs. concentration of inhibitor across various concentrations of substrate (S). Hence, it is a Dixon Plot.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a history of sore throat two weeks ago presents with sudden onset of motor tics and emotional lability. A diagnosis of PANDAS was made. Which of the following may also be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection (PANDAS) is associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder in children.

PANDAS results from the immune response of the body to Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection. The antibodies directed against the bacteria cross-react with self-tissues due to molecular mimicry. The pathophysiology behind PANDAS is postulated to be the same as that of Sydenham chorea which occurs during acute rheumatic fever.

The diagnosis of PANDAS is based on:

  • Abrupt onset and episodic course of symptoms
  • Pediatric onset (age between 3 years and adolescent)
  • Temporal relation between Group A  β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection and the symptoms
  • Presence of OCD and/or a tic disorder (such as a motor or a vocal tic)

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with complaints of swelling and pain in the left ankle and knee and fever for 3 days. He had a history of sore throat 3 weeks ago. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral regurgitation. Histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen
Condition can occur after group A streptococcal pharyngitis
Subendocardial irregular thickenings are called MacCallum plaques
Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the lesion in the heart

questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is acute rheumatic fever. The rheumatic fever phase of rheumatic heart disease is marked by small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

Rheumatic fever is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease that classically occurs a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. (Option B) Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active rheumatic fever. It may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease.

Aschoff's bodies are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon.

Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cord. (Option D) Over these necrotic areas, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques. (Option C)

Some major manifestations of rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish-mouth appearance (buttonhole).

Image showing button hole appearance is seen in mitral stenosis in case of rheumatic heart disease.

Image showing Aschoff bodies seen in RHD.

Note: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen in Libman-Sacks endocarditis. (option A)

questions.text: An elderly multiparous postmenopausal woman presents with an inability to empty the bladder completely. She also complained of mass descending per vagina. Upon examination, a bulge in the upper two-thirds of the anterior wall is observed, as depicted in the image below. Which level of DeLancey support will exhibit the following damage?
questions.solution:
Damage to DeLancey’s level II support( pelvic fascia and arcus tendinus) can lead to cystocele which appears as the anterior vaginal wall bulge as shown in the image.

The descent of one or more of the genital organs below their normal anatomical position is called pelvic organ prolapse (POP). It occurs when the muscles and tissues that support the pelvic organs become weakened or damaged, leading to one or more organs bulging into the vaginal canal. 

Clinical types are:

1. Vaginal prolapse

a) Anterior vaginal wall

      • Upper two-thirds – Cystocele
      • Lower one-third – Urethrocele

b) Posterior vaginal wall

      • Upper one-third – Enterocele
      • Lower two-thirds – Rectocele

2. Uterine descent

Treatment options may include pessary, pelvic floor exercises or surgery depending on the severity of prolapse.

DeLancey introduced a three-level system of genital tract supports:

 Delancey Level Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level I Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments Uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse
Level II Pelvic fascia, paracolpos, arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia Cystocele and rectocele
Level III Levator ani Urethrocele, gaping introitus and deficient perineum.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of headache, eye pain, and frequent change of glasses over the past few months. An eye examination was performed after dilating the pupil and it showed the following finding. Her intraocular pressure was raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features and the image given is pseudoexfoliation syndrome.

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is an age-related degenerative disorder, more commonly seen in elderly women. The pathogenesis involves the deposition of a grey-white fibrillary substance derived from abnormal extracellular matrix metabolism in ocular and other tissues.

The deposition of this exfoliative material occurs on the iris, ciliary region, and lens capsule. They appear as flakes on the anterior lens capsule and edge of the iris. There is radially indented peripheral layer of pseudoexfoliative material, separated by a clear zone maintained by pupillary abrasion (figure shows this). Pupillary dilation helps in visualizing this peripheral capsular deposition.

The material can get collected in the anterior chamber angle and impede the aqueous humor drainage, thus developing open-angle glaucoma. Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen. Gonioscopy may show these deposits.

Treatment involves laser trabeculoplasty to remove this material deposition.

Other options

Option A: Traumatic glaucoma will be associated with hyphema or ciliary body rupture leading to angle recession. The above does not correspond to either of them.

Option B: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised IOP associated with mild anterior uveitis. Males are more commonly affected than females.

Option C: Pigmentary glaucoma is common in young myopic males. Here the iris rubs against zonules posteriorly resulting in pigment dispersion causing blockadge of trabecular meshwork. It will be associated with iris tramsillumination defect and pigment deposits on the anterior lens, margins of iris etc.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters correlates with the severity of the malformation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
HbA1c levels correlate with the malformation given in the image, namely, caudal regression sequence/ sacral agenesis.

It is a rare anomaly. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and, to a lesser degree, the lumbar vertebrae, and occurs more frequently in an infant of a diabetic mother than in other infants.

The maternal condition that can give rise to this condition in the baby is pregestational diabetes. HbA1c levels correlate with the malformations. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes. Poorly controlled diabetes, both preconceptionally and in early pregnancy, is thought to cause this malformation.

Other options:

Option B- Folic acid deficiency in pregnancy increases the risk of spina bifida.

Option C- Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis if taken during pregnancy.

Option D- Lithium can cause Ebstein anomaly if taken during pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the fetal presentation shown in the following image :
questions.solution:
The image depicts anterior asynclitism where the anterior parietal bone is the presenting part.

The image shows the spine (dorsal part of the maternal body) and the pubic symphysis bone (ventral part of the maternal body) and it shows sagittal suture of the fetus deflected posteriorly towards the sacrum, thus making the anterior parietal bone the presenting part at the vaginal introitus.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder, causing the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

When the sagittal suture is deflected posteriorly, towards the sacral promontory the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

When the sagittal suture is deflected anteriorly, towards the symphysis, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism. With extreme posterior asynclitism, the posterior ear may be easily palpated.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labour. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.

questions.text: A young woman undergoing vaginal delivery started bleeding after the expulsion of the placenta. Medical management was unsuccessful in arresting the bleeding. So the device shown below was used. What amount of fluid should be instilled into this device to arrest hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The image shows a Bakri balloon. 300-500 ml of fluid should be instilled into it for it to be effective in arresting hemorrhage

A Bakri postpartum balloon may be inserted and inflated to tamponade the endometrial cavity and stop bleeding in patients with atonic PPH (postpartum hemorrhage) who are unresponsive to medical management. The Bakri balloon has a three-way valve and a separate tubing to drain the blood from the uterine cavity.

Insertion is achieved with help of two or three team members:

  • One to perform abdominal sonography during the procedure
  • Second member to place the deflated balloon into the uterus and stabilize it.
  • The third member instils fluid to inflate the balloon. Inflated rapidly by infusing at least 150 mL followed by further installation over a few minutes for a total of 300 to 500 mL to arrest hemorrhage.

The balloon is usually removed after 12 hours of insertion. It is successful in most cases of atonic PPH and helps to avoid hysterectomy in the majority of cases. 

Segstaken­ Blakemore, Rusch, and ebb balloons, Foley's catheter, and condom catheters can also be used instead. In the technique where Foley's catheter is utilised, a 24F-30F size catheter with a 30ml balloon is used, the tip is guided into the uterine cavity and filled with 60-80ml of saline.  Once the bleeding subsides, the catheter can be removed after 12 -24 hours.

The following are the steps used in controlling the postpartum haemorrhage:

  • Feel the uterus to know the cause of the haemorrhage. If the uterus feels flabby, bleeding is likely to be due to atonicity. If it is firm and contracted, it is likely to be traumatic in origin.
  • In case of an atonic uterus, massage the uterus and start the patient on oxytocin drips or methergine. 
  • If the uterus remains atonic, manual exploration of the uterus is done for removing any retained placental fragments. Blood transfusion is started and oxytocin drips are continued. Other uterotonic agents can also be given.
  • Uterine massage and bimanual compression
  • Uterine tamponade using a hydrostatic balloon catheter (balloon tamponade)
  • Surgical methods to control PPH are outlined as stepwise uterine devascularization procedures:
    • Compression sutures: B-Lynch suture
    • Ligation of uterine arteries
    • Ligation of ovarian and uterine anastomosis
    • Ligation of internal iliac artery
    • Angiographic embolization of the bleeding vessel
  •   Hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the stage marked by the red arrow________
questions.solution:
The marked stage is the late expanding phase (Stage 3) of the demographic cycle.

The birth rate starts declining alongside a death rate that continues to fall in stage 3 causing a decline in the demographic gap.

Note: India is currently in this stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A young man presented with bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever. Lab investigations showed leucocytosis and stool microscopy revealed gull-wing–shaped gram-negative rods with darting motility. Which of the following is a selective culture medium for this organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of diarrhea and smear showing gull-wing–shaped gram-negative rods with darting motility is suggestive of Campylobacter jejuni. The most suitable culture media for Campylobacter jejuni is Skirrow's medium.

Campylobacters are gram-negative curved, or spiral-shaped organisms having a sea gull’s wing appearance (Shown in the image below). It is microaerophilic (shows growth in 5-10% oxygen) and thermophilic (prefers higher temperatures and grows best at 42°C). It is oxidase-positive, catalase-positive, and nitrate reduction positive. They multiply at a slower rate when compared to other Gram-negative, enteric bacteria, hence require antibiotic-containing selective media such as Campy-Blood agar, and Skirrow’s media for isolation of campylobacters from stool specimens.

C. jejuni is the major pathogen and is primarily associated with febrile diarrhea. Contaminated food is the major source of infection. The loose stools may contain blood and leukocytes, as campylobacter species are invasive pathogens that can damage the small intestinal mucosa and disrupt fluid absorption. Usually, the illness is self-limited to a period of 5–8 days, but occasionally it continues for longer times. Certain serotypes of C. jejuni have been associated with post diarrheal Guillain-Barré syndrome.
